Custom Tours,custom-tours.html,"<div id=""item-493635133"" class=""templateComponent"" style=""display: inline
The Conservancy offers one-of-a-kind, private tours of the world's greatest urban park. Whether you&rsquo
column2: re visiting New York or are a local resident, see the City&rsquo
column3: s backyard from a new perspective through a custom tour designed to suit your needs. Walking and van tours are offered by Conservancy experts and can be customized to fit your group&rsquo
column4: s interest. Walking tours can be arranged for $150 minimum donation for up to 10 people and van tours (available Monday through Friday, only) can be reserved for a minimum of $350 for up to 6 people. Duration and capacity vary by tour option. At least three weeks advance booking required. Gift certificates are also available.</br>

column1: Custom Tour with Sara Cedar Miller, the Central Park Conservancy Historian and Photographer
Book a custom tour with Central Park&rsquo
column2: s official historian and photographer, Sara Cedar Miller. Tours can be tailored to your desired subject matter and required duration. Learn stories and secrets from the Park's amazing history, understand the Park both above ground and below, and appreciate some little-known landscapes and sculptures. In addition, you will receive one of Miller's autographed books as a keepsake of the wonderful experience. Van transportation for a maximum of 6 people is included. Tours start AT $500 per hour and may be lengthened for $250 for each additional half hour. Tour bookings are a tax-deductible donation to the Central Park Conservancy.</br>

column1:
More information: 212.310.6679.

Both walking tours and tours by vehicle are available with a donation.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 08, 2009 03:55 PM CST",/visit/tours/custom-tours/,Default,TRUE,,,tours,,/assets/images/tour/Supporttours-l.jpg,/assets/images/news-images/customtour-m.jpg,"tour, tours, custom, walking",,,,,,/assets/images/tour/custom-tours2013-s.jpg,/assets/images/news-images/customtour-t.jpg,

Learn the full story of the Park's history, design and ecology on the Official Central Park Tours. The Conservancy's expert guides provide an insider's view and unique access to this masterpiece of landscape architecture and the world's greatest urban park. Space is limited, arrive early for check in.

All tours take place rain or shine, except in extreme weather conditions (heavy rain, sustained winds of 30mph or more, snowstorms, and a wind chill below 25 or heat index above 95 degrees). Groups of seven or more should email tours@centralparknyc.org or call 212-360-2726 to schedule a Custom Tour.

Recreation Programs,recreation.html,"

The Central Park Conservancy offers a wide variety of Recreation Programs based out of the North Meadow Recreation Center, located mid-Park at 97th Street. The Center provides a safe, outdoor setting where people of all ages can play sports, participate in clinics and take part in healthful activities throughout the year.

Recreation Programs are supported in part by The Sherman Fairchild Foundation, Metzger-Price Fund and participants in our 3-on-3 Corporate Basketball Challenge.

column1: Professional Development Programs,professional-development.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""item-386616747"" style=""display: inline

The Central Park Challenge: A professional development program located in the heart of New York
Whether your company is large or small, success often depends on forming a cohesive group of people. Understanding the strengths, limitations, and potential of each team member is integral to improving a company's performance. The Central Park Challenge Professional Development Program can help your executives learn to create synergies and a sense of teamwork among diverse employees.
Building peak performance teams is what separates the best companies from the rest.

The Central Park Challenge Professional Development Program is designed to help you take your team to a higher level of performance. The heart of the program is learning through experience. Through a series of progressively more challenging activities, participants together as s team, they gain the interpersonal skills vital for success.

Using the North Meadow and Woodlands of Central Park as our classroom, we place groups of your executives in an unfamiliar environment giving them only the basic tools necessary for solving problems. We then challenge them with goals that demand teamwork, trust, and tenacity. Through group discussions, we tie these experiences together and develop a framework for understanding core team values. Each participant shares what he or she has learned and how it can be applied to the business environment.

Realize Your Potential
All exercises are designed to foster team dynamics, communication, leadership, flexibility, and risk assessment.

Programs Designed to Build Upon Your Strengths, Overcome Weaknesses, Help You Achieve Your Goals
A Program Coordinator will meet with you to tailor a program that fits your company's structure. In order to accommodate the unique character and needs of your organization, your culture and needs. You may select half-day, one-day, or two-day programs. Programs may be scheduled at any time of the year, in a variety of indoor or outdoor settings. Adventure components such as rock-climbing and orienteering can be added.

A Special Challenge Program is Available for Companies Involved in Youth Mentoring
While adventure activities help develop management and teamwork skills, they are also ideal for enriching adult-to-youth mentoring relationships. If your employees are currently involved in a youth mentoring program, our Challenge is ideal for growing relationships. Through a series of one-on-one and group exercises, the concepts and consequences of success, failure, self-esteem, and goal setting are addressed in a specially designed package. Group discussion follows each Challenge exercise, during which experiences and impressions are examined and applied to a broader life context.

Qualifications
All programs are well within the capabilities of those in moderate physical condition, regardless of age or gender. Safety is our highest priority. All program instructors are experienced group leaders with qualified first aid and CPR training.
For more information or to schedule a course, please contact our Program Manager at 212-348-4867.

Central Park Conservancy
The Arsenal
830 Fifth Avenue
New York, NY 10021

Professionals who participated in the Challenge Program Applaud Its Results
""The program was customized to give our group challenges which required development of teamwork efforts and trust. The financial management Associates were able to gain a better understanding of their colleagues' goals, values, and experiences through the group activities and facilitated discussions.""

column3: />Central Park offers a total of 26 baseball and softball fields located in three specific areas:

column1: • North Meadow: Seven baseball and five softball fields, restored in 2000.
• Heckscher Ballfields: Located at 63rd Street between the west and center drives. There are six ballfields, restored in 2006.
Permits for baseball and softball are issued from mid-April through mid-September. Opening and closing days will be posted. The ballfields may be closed for maintenance or when wet.

NYC Department of Parks/Recreation issues permits to leagues, teams and other groups to reserve specific athletic fields at specific times. The public can obtain athletic field permits for a session on one of the fields by completing and submitting a permit application to the permit office at the Borough Office (24 West 61st Street). A permit application also can be requested by phone by calling the Permit Office. Members of the public who wish to join or set up a league should call or stop by the permit office as well. For additional information, call the Permit Office at 212-408-0226.

For a list of all ballfields in New York City and permit information, visit the New York City Parks Department website.

",Central Park has a total of 26 ballfields available for use with a city permit. column4: />Whether you are in for a good game of basketball, or just want to practice your hook shot, come to Central Park to play. Basketball is available free of charge at two sites in Central Park - the Great Lawn and North Meadow Recreation Center. Basketballs are available with a photo I.D. at the recreation center only and basketball nets are supplied at both sites. No permit is required, and courts are on a first-come, first-served basis.

column1: The courts are open from 10am-8pm daily at the North Meadow Recreation Center and 9am to 8pm daily at the Great Lawn.

The New York City Parks Recreation Department website has a complete listing of all municipal basketball courts in New York City, and how to reserve them.

Bicycle Riding,bicycle-riding.html,"

Circling the entire Park and offering both hilly and flat terrain, the Central Park Drives provide cyclists with varying levels of difficulty.
column2: Cyclists may choose from three long-distance routes of 6.1 miles, 5.2 miles or 1.7 miles. Cross-Park routes at 102nd. St and 72nd St. allow cyclists to shorten the distance or to detour the most challenging hills which are in the north. &nbsp
column3: There is also a shared cross-path inside the Park at 96th Street for slow-riding commuters and groups of four and under. The Drives are ONE-WAY roads with arrows indicating the counter-clockwise direction for all vehicles and bicycles. All cross-routes are two-way for cyclists.

column4: />The Drives that circle the Park have a dedicated bicycle lane that is in the middle of the road. The bicycle lane is marked to direct slower cyclists to use the left side of the lane and faster cyclists to ride on the right side. Cyclists must use extra caution on the southern end of the Park where the Drive narrows and requires cyclists to share a lane with motor vehicles for a short stretch.

column1: The Drives are open to public vehicular traffic at different times on weekdays when cars will be traveling in the vehicle lane that is on the right side of the dedicated bicycle lane.
column2: On weekdays, the entire West Drive and 72nd St. cross are open to traffic from 8:00 am. &ndash
column4: the Center Drive from 6th Ave north to E. 72nd is open to traffic from 7:00 a.m. &ndash
column6: The East Drive from E. 72nd north to Adam Clayton Powell Blvd is open to traffic from 3:00 p.m.- 7:00 p.m. The Drives are all closed to traffic on weekends and holidays, but the vehicle lane is used heavily by service and Parks vehicles so cyclists should not travel in it except to cautiously pass other cyclists who are in the bicycle lane.

column1: No permit is required to bike in Central Park, however there are several laws and rules that every cyclist must obey:
• Pedestrians have the right of way at all times.
• At crosswalks, cyclists must slow down, yield to pedestrians and then proceed cautiously.
<li>Cycling is prohibited on all pedestrian paths&nbsp
column2: except the marked shared paths at 96th St and W. 106th-108th St.

column1: • Cyclists are required to obey all traffic laws, such as traffic signals, stop signs, and the maximum speed limit of 25 mph. The Drives are multi-use areas and can be very congested on weekends and nice days. Cyclists are required by law to travel at a slower safe speed in response to crowd, emergency, or weather conditions.
• NYC law requires that children under 14 years of age wear a helmet, but it is recommended that all cyclists wear a helmet.
• Obey all ONE WAY signs and arrows: Travel only counter-clockwise on the Drives that circle the Park.
Bicycles are available for rent at the following locations:

Bike and Roll NYC
Merchants Gate/Columbus Circle, Central Park West at 59th Street
8am-8pm summer
column2:
9am-7pm spring and fall
Tours leave daily at 10:30am and 1:30pm

column4:
and a list of events, visit the Century Road Club Association, a bicycle racing club for everyone, and the New York Cycle Club, an educational and recreational organization for bicycle enthusiasts in New York City.

","Offering both hilly and flat terrain of varying levels of difficulty, Central Park provides cyclists of all ages with a challenge as they navigate its 6.1 miles of drives. ",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 09, 2009 01:20 PM CST",/visit/things-to-do/sports/,Default,TRUE,,,recreation-sports,,,/assets/images/visit-images/bikerider1-m.jpg,"bicycling, cycling, bicycle, ride, riding",,"/visit/things-to-see/great-lawn/bicycle-rental.html,/visit/things-to-see/south-end/bike-and-roll-nyc.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/bikerider1-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/bikerider1-t.jpg,

/>Approximately 230 different species of birds can be found in Central Park during the year with some birds living in the Park year round and several species making an important stopover to rest and feed during spring and fall migrations. Most birds are more active in the early morning and late afternoon with some activity throughout the day. In late spring and summer you can watch for young birds learning to fly as many birds in Central Park build their nests, lay eggs and raise their young in the Park at this time of year.

column1: The best place to find warblers and other songbirds in early May are the Ramble (mid-Park from 74th to 79th Streets), the North Woods (mid-Park from 102nd to 106th Streets), and the Great Hill (West 104th Street off Central Park West). In the fall, visit Belvedere Castle (mid-Park at 79th Street) to look for migrating hawks from the upper terraces.

column3: every Sunday in the spring (March - May) and fall (September&nbsp
column4: - November) from 10:00 am - 11:00 am. Meet at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center with your family to go on a tour guided by the NYC Audubon Society as you observe all the feathered activity of migratory birds and those who are year-round residents of the Park

column1: Throughout the year you can also take yourself on a birding adventure with one of the Central Park Conservancy Discovery Kits available to borrow, free of charge, at Belvedere Castle from 10:00 am - 3:00 pm daily (must be returned by 4:00 pm). Each kit contains: binoculars, a guidebook, maps and sketching materials. Valid picture ID required and an adult must accompany children under 12 years of age. For more information, call 212-772-0288.

column2: ","Central Park is one of the best places for birding in the northeast. Approximately 230 different species of birds can be found in the Park during the year. It is a sanctuary, especially for migrating birds who need to find safe places to rest and feed along the way.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 09, 2009 01:36 PM CST",/visit/things-to-do/sports/,Default,TRUE,,,"nature-horticulture,recreation-sports",,,/assets/images/visit-images/birding-women-m.jpg,"bird, birding, birdwatching, bird watching, migrating, migratory",,"/visit/things-to-see/great-lawn/ramble.html,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/north-woods-3.html,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/great-hill.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/birding-women-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/birding-women-t.jpg,

column4: />Central Park is a wonderful venue for cross-country skiing. There are many areas where enthusiasts can enjoy beautiful scenery while feeling the swoosh and glide of the snow under their skis and the bite of the crisp cold air against their faces. The best places to ski are Sheep Meadow, the Great Lawn and other large meadows in Central Park.

column1:
Cross country skiing is allowed only when there is a base of snow of at least six inches deep.

","Feel the swoosh and glide of the snow as you cross-country ski in Central Park, and forget you are in the middle of Manhattan. The Park is a wonderful venue for cross-country skiing with many areas enjoy.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 09, 2009 01:43 PM CST",/visit/things-to-do/sports/,Default,TRUE,,,recreation-sports,,,/assets/images/visit-images/skiing-m.jpg,"ski, skiing, cross country, cross-country, winter, sports",,"/visit/things-to-see/south-end/sheep-meadow.html,/visit/things-to-see/great-lawn/great-lawn.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/skiing-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/skiing-t.jpg,

Catch-and-release fishing at the Harlem Meer is a favorite family and community pastime. Fishing poles are available to borrow at the Charles A. Dana Center, located on the north shore of the Meer. Picture ID required
column2: instruction and bait are provided with the poles.

column1: The Harlem Meer is a thriving aquatic ecosystem that supports a wide variety of fish, waterfowl, turtles, plants and microorganisms. Some of the fish living in the Meer include largemouth bass, pumpkinseed sunfish, bluegill sunfish, carp and chain pickerel.

column3: >Celebrate biodiversity in the Harlem Meer with fish crafts, a Magic Goldfish performance, microscopic exploration, catch &amp
column4: release fishing, face painting and fishy magic tricks!

column1: Catch-and-Release fishing program for 2013 runs from April 16 through October 5.
Mon-Sat: 10:00 am - 3:00 pm (poles must be returned by 4:00 pm)
Sun: 10:00 am - 1:00 pm (poles must be returned by 2:00 pm)

• Release fish gently. All fishing is on a ""catch-and-release"" basis only, meaning that all fish caught must be put back into the water immediately. Please wet your hands before handling fish, and release while the fish is underwater if possible.
• Use safe fishing equipment. The use of barbed hooks
column3: lead sinkers is strictly prohibited. Monofilament line should be properly discarded of in the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center to avoid harming wildlife.

column1: • Respect the turtles and waterfowl. If you see a turtle or bird near your hook, please move to another spot to avoid catching it.

• Please fish with complimentary fish bait from the Dana Center ONLY. The use of bread products and hot dogs as bait is discouraged as it has been found to be harmful to both the wildlife and the water bodies.
• Don't feed the wildlife. Feeding any other wildlife and digging for worms is strictly prohibited.

• Stay on pathways, ramps and steps next to the water. Excessive trampling of the natural shoreline and wading in the water kills the grass and causes soil erosion and compaction. This creates poor living conditions for plants, fish and other Meer dwellers.

column2: for families and individuals. Groups of&nbsp
column3: five or more people must make reservations at least two weeks in advance.&nbsp
column5: 212-860-1370. Group reservations are taken for Monday to Friday only, for either of the following two-hour sessions: 10:30 am - 12:30 pm, or 1:30 pm - 3:30 pm.

column1:
Recommended for children ages 5 to 15 and accompanying adults. Note: New York State Department of Environmental Conservation regulations require persons 16 years of age and older to obtain a fishing license. For more information on this regulation and where you can buy one, please visit www.dec.ny.gov.

","Catch-and-release fishing is allowed year-round in the Harlem Meer. During the warmer months of the year, you can even borrow a rod and bait for free through the Central Park Conservancy's Catch-and-Release Fishing program at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center. ",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 09, 2009 02:02 PM CST",/visit/things-to-do/sports/,Default,TRUE,,,recreation-sports,,,/assets/images/visit-images/family-fishing-m.jpg,"fishing, fish, catch, catch and release",,"/visit/things-to-see/north-end/harlem-meer.html,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/charles-a-dana-discovery-center.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/family-fishing-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/family-fishing-t.jpg,

Football,football.html,"

Only touch football and flag football can be played at the North Meadow from mid-September through mid-November. Permits are required and cleats are prohibited.

New York City Department of Parks and Recreation issues permits to leagues, teams and other groups to reserve specific athletic fields at specific times. The public can obtain athletic field permits for a session on one of the fields by submitting an application to the permit office. For more information call 212-408-0226.

","The North Meadow's wide-open, plush football fields are in peak condition after a $4.3 million restoration. They are the perfect setting for a game of touch football.

column4:
/>There are 12 handball courts available at the North Meadow Recreation Center 10am-7pm on a first come first serve basis. Handballs are supplied with a photo I.D. There is no permit needed for single use, but one is required for a tournament.

",There are 12 handball courts available in Central Park on a first come first serve basis. Players of any skill level are welcome.,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 09, 2009 02:16 PM CST",/visit/things-to-do/sports/,Default,TRUE,,,recreation-sports,,,/visit/things-to-see/images/handball-courts-m.jpg,"handball, court, courts",,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/north-meadow-recreation-center.html,,,,/visit/things-to-see/images/handball-courts-s.jpg,/visit/things-to-see/images/handball-courts-t.jpg,

Trail rides start at the North Meadow Recreation Center and go along the bridle path.

column4: />Feel the nip of New York's crisp winter air, enjoy the music, and take in the incomparable surroundings as you ice skate at either of Central Park's ice rinks. From November through March skating is available in the southern end of the Park at Wollman Rink and in the northern end at Lasker Rink. Skate and locker rentals are available at both locations.

column1:

Circling the entire Park, the drives provide three long distance routes - 6.1 miles, 5.2 miles or 1.7 miles, or shorter distances if you cross the Park at a number of scenic locations.

column1: One can skate in the Park at any time while it's open and no permit is needed. The most optimal times are when the drives are closed to traffic on Monday through Friday 10am to 3pm, and 7pm to 10pm, and weekends from 7pm Friday to 6am Monday. We do not recommend using the Park drives when they are open to traffic. Note that the Park is officially closed from 1am to 6am.
The law requires that children under 14 years of age wear helmets. and the 25 mph speed limit
column2: is strictly enforced on the drives.

column1:
Visit the Central Park Skate Patrol, a chapter of the International Inline Skating Association's National Skate Patrol which provides free stopping lessons to skaters, as well as general assistance to all users of Central Park. For dance skating information visit the Central Park Dance Skaters Association.

Kite flying is permitted without a permit anywhere in Central Park where ther are large, open landscapes away from trees. Please respect closures due to fences, red flags and Quiet Zones. Do not leave any string or other materials behind that might entangle wildlife.

column4: />Near Sheep Meadow, Central Park has two beautifully kept fields for lawn bowling and croquet, each 15,000 sqare feet in size. The season runs from May 1 to November 7 with hours of play from 8am until dusk. Fields, when not under repair or reserved for tournaments, are open daily, weather permitting. Order of play is determined by order of arrival at the field. Players are required to furnish their own equipment.

column1: Each player must hold a permit. Permits are strictly personal and non-transferable and duplicates will not be issued unless another fee is paid. Permits cost $30 and can be obtained in Room 1 of the Arsenal at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street. Office hours are Monday through Friday 9am to 4pm and Saturday 9am to 12pm. Saturday hours are valid for April, May and June only. For more information regarding permits call 212-360-8133.

For more information on lawn bowling visit the New York Lawn Bowling Club. For information on the New York Croquet Club call 212-369-7949.

Running and Jogging,running-jogging.html,"

Offering both hilly and flat terrain and a combination of surfaces, Central Park is a runner's paradise. The site of the New York Marathon's final 3.2 miles, Central Park offers many scenic distractions while providing a challenge to all levels of runners.

column3: MARGIN-LEFT: 10px"" src=""/preview!www.centralparknyc.org/assets/images/visit-images/running.jpg"">There are three optimal places to run in Central Park.

column1: • Park Drives: Circling the entire Park, the drives provide three long distance routes - 6.1 miles, 5.2 miles, or 1.7 miles, or shorter distances if you cross the Park at a number of scenic locations.

• The Reservoir: A soft surface, the Reservoir track is 1.58 miles around and offers some of the best skyline views in the Park and many scenic opportunities. In spring, cherry trees alongside the track are in bloom and in summer the evaporating water cools the surrounding air.

• Bridle Paths: There are three conjoined soft surface bridle paths to choose from. The Reservoir loop, adjacent to the Reservoir, totals 1.5 miles, the North Meadow loop totals 1.1 miles, and the southern spur totals 1.5 miles.
The best time to run on the drives is when the Park is closed to traffic
column2: Monday through Friday, 10am-3pm, and from 7pm10pm, and weekends from 7pm Friday - 6am Monday. When the Park is open to traffic a runners' lane is always available, but we do not recommend using the Park drives when they are open to traffic. Runners can run at any time, but the Park is officially closed from 1am-6am.

column1:
New York Road Runners is the premier sponsor of running events in Central Park. Visit NYRR.org for a list of upcoming events and centralparktc.org for information provided by the Central Park Track Club.

","With hilly and flat terrain over a combination of surfaces, Central Park is a runner's paradise. The site of the New York Marathon's final 3.2 miles, Central Park offers many scenic views while providing a challenge to all levels of runners. Find relief from New York's hazy, hot and humid summers with a dip in Lasker Pool. And to top it off, admission is free.
Please note that certain rules apply. For example, you must bring a lock and only a towel, shoes, a book and water bottle are allowed by the pool
column2: bags are not permitted. During the summer the pool is open 7 days a week from 11am-3pm and again from 4pm-7pm.

Permits are required only for tournaments or special events.

Walking and Speed Walking,walking.html,"

Central Park's 250 acres of lawns and 80 acres of woodland offer a multitude of landscapes, trails and pathways for everyone from the serious hiker to the recreational stroller. Central Park provides an unparalleled variety of picturesque landscapes for walkers of all levels.
Whether you are distance walking, hiking, taking a stroll or a Conservancy or other walking tour, you can walk on the drives, along pathways, the Reservoir, the bridle paths or any of the pathways.

column4:
/>Distance Walking and Speed Walking
Circling the entire Park, the Drives provide three long distance routes - 6.1 miles, 5.2 miles or 1.7 miles - or shorter distances if you cross the Park at a number of scenic locations.

column2: slope, the Reservoir running track is 1.58 miles around and offers some of the best skyline views in the Park and many scenic variations. In the spring the cherry trees along side it are in bloom and in the summer the evaporating water cools the surrounding air.

column1: There are three conjoined soft surface bridle paths to choose from. The Reservoir loop, adjacent to the Reservoir, totals 1.5 miles
column2: the North Meadow loop totals 1.1 miles
column3: and the southern spur totals 1.5 miles.

column1:
Hiking
There are 58 miles of trails in Central Park. Some of those trails can be found at the Ravine in the Park's North Woods and the Ramble with its 38 acres of woodlands, wild gardens and rock outcrops.

Strolling
In addition to the areas above, the Great Lawn's 15 acres and its surrounding paved pathway are perfect for a leisurely stroll. Sheep Meadow, Wien Walk, the Dene, Cedar Hill, the Mall and the Park's six-mile perimeter also provide beautiful vistas for a walk.

Walking Tours
The Central Park Conservancy offers a number of different guided
column2: walking tours free of charge to the public.

column1:
One can walk at any time in the Park though it is officially closed from 1 am-6am. If you are taking one of the many walking tours, be sure to check the schedule. The Drives are closed to traffic Monday through Friday, 10am-3pm and from 7pm-10pm, and on weekends from 7pm Friday to 6am Monday. When the Park is open to traffic a walkers' lane on the Park Drives is always available, but we do not recommend using the Drives when they are open to traffic.

","Central Park's 250 acres of lawns and 80 acres of woodland offer a multitude of landscapes, trails and pathways for everyone from the serious hiker to the recreational stroller.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 10, 2009 11:07 AM CST",/visit/things-to-do/sports/,Default,TRUE,,,recreation-sports,,,/assets/images/visit-images/walking-m.jpg,"walking, hiking, racewalking, race walking, speed walking, speedwalking",,"/visit/things-to-see/reservoir/running-track.html,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/ravine.html,/visit/things-to-see/great-lawn/ramble.html,/visit/tours/guided-tours/index.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/walking-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/walking-t.jpg,

column4: />There's nothing quite like a good game of chess or checkers while surrounded by the natural beauty of Central Park. At the <a href=""/preview!www.centralparknyc.org/visit/things-to-see/south-end/chess-checkers-house.html"">Chess&nbsp
column6: Checkers House, one of five Park visitor centers run by the Central Park Conservancy, players are welcome to borrow pieces from the Conservancy staff or bring their own. Dominos and backgammon are also available. Conservancy staff can even arrange a partner for you to play with.

column1:

Advance registration not required. Programs take place at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center and are ongoing between 2pm and 4pm

Looking for a free, after-work pick-me-up that offers stimulating conversation in a serene green setting instead of the crowded bars or restaurants of New York City? Join us for a fresh alternative to the tired old happy hour
column3: s view of Central Park at the Harlem Meer Social Hour, the Central Park Conservancy&rsquo
column4: s monthly series for adults. Year-round, one Thursday each month, the Conservancy hosts a different program from 6:30pm to 8pm on a seasonal or interesting topic.

column3: 2007, Social Hour programs have included nature walks, composting workshops, live Jazz music, seasonal cooking demonstrations, book readings and signings, discussion panels with landscape architects and Park historians,&nbsp
column5: stargazing, canoeing, dance performances, film screenings, wild mushroom programs, and more, facilitated by both in-house Conservancy experts and partnering&nbsp
column6:
cultural institutions along the Park's perimeter.

Programs happen at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center (located inside the Park on 110th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues). Plenty of time is included for mingling over complimentary refreshments. All programs are FREE and happen rain or shine. For more information, call 212-860-1370.

Chess Program,chess-program.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-216706239"" style=""float: left

The Central Park Conservancy's Fall Chess Series offers multiple opportunities for children and people of all ages to build skills over cumulative workshops, practice and play with their peers in our open sessions, and test their abilities -- all while enjoying views of gorgeous Central Park.
This fall, FIDE International Master Asa Hoffman will host programs at 11:00 am on the following dates:
For more information, call 212-794-4064. All programs are FREE.

Open Play Sessions:
Test your skills, meet new friends, and enjoy beautiful views of the Park while playing chess on the mosaic tables under the pergola. Chess pieces are also available to be borrowed between the hours of 10:00 am and 4:00 pm, with chess games and pieces returned by 4:30 pm.

column1:
Memorial Walk,memorial-walk.html,"

Offered on Memorial Day and Veterans' Day only, this tour combines a walk through Central Park with a look at how different generations of New Yorkers viewed the Park as a proper place to remember their veterans. Meet at Columbus Circle by the Maine Monument, Central Park West and 59th Street. Call 212-794-4064 for information and directions. Children under 16 must be accompanied by parent(s) or guardian. Event dates and times are subject to change without notice.

column2:
>Tour accessibility is rated as follows:
* Easy to negotiate
column3:
paths and few stairs - mostly accessible to the handicapped
** Moderate inclines and stairs, paths clear and negotiable - only parts accessible to the handicapped
*** Hilly, stairs, and a few Park-related obstacles to negotiate - not recommended for the handicapped

column1:
South End Self-Guided Tour,south-end-tour.html,"

The Dairy
Calvert Vaux, Park co-designer and architect, designed this Victorian Gothic Revival structure with an ample loggia as a respite for Park visitors, particularly for children and invalids, where they could buy a glass of fresh milk and catch the cool summer breezes coming off the northern lobe of the Pond (now Wollman Skating Rink). However, when the building finally opened to the public in 1870, city officials established it as thePark&rsquo
column4: eatery. In the 1950s, the dilapidated loggia was torn down, and the remaining stone structure was reduced to a maintenance storage shed. In 1979, under the new Central Park Administration, the restored Dairy became the Park&rsquo
column5: s first visitor center, and in 1981, the loggia was returned to its original Victorian elegance by the newly formed Central Park Conservancy. Today the Dairy is the Park&rsquo

column6:
BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1px solid"" border=1 src=""/preview!www.centralparknyc.org/assets/images/visit-images/selftour-south-1.jpg"">Chess and Checkers House
In 1866, Calvert Vaux designed the largest and most elaborate rustic summerhouse in the Park for children and their caregivers, known as the &ldquo
column9: s mountain). The open-air shelter, made from unmilled timber, was built atop a large rock outcrop. Children and their caregivers sat at rustic chairs and tables to play games that they could borrow from the Dairy. After many years of neglect and disrepair, the structure was torn down in the early 1950s. In 1952, the present brick Chess and Checkers House was built and chess tables were placed around it, making it a haven for enthusiasts of both time-honored games. In 1984, the Chess and Checkers House was refurbished and a wisteria pergola was added. In May 2007, it reopened as the official visitor center for the Park&rsquo
column10: s south end and as the volunteer headquarters. Visitors can borrow different games and sit at the 24 chess tables under a modern-day pergola to match wits and enjoy the summer shade.

column1:
Wollman Skating Rink
When the Park was being planned, New Yorkers demanded a place for the new sport of ice skating because the rivers surrounding the island of Manhattan rarely froze. Immediately, the Pond and the Lake
column3: - became the most popular winter destinations in the Park. Frustrated by the whims of Mother Nature, however, Park visitors wanted the guarantee of ice skating all season long. In 1950, Kate Wollman donated the money for the rink, which was placed on the northern arm of the Pond. In the 1980s, the rink was reconstructed by the City of New York with assistance from real estate developer Donald Trump, whose organization manages it today.

column1:
The Pond and Hallett Nature Sanctuary
The Pond is one of the Park&rsquo
column2:
s masterpieces of engineering and technology. Designed to resemble a quiet woodland lake, it is actually lined with geosynthetic materials and filled with city water by subterranean pipes. Concrete shelves, constructed along the naturalistic shoreline, feature many plants and shrubs that contribute to the impression of a bucolic lagoon set deep in the woods. From the 1870s until 1924, visitors to the Pond could ride on swan boats, still a famous attraction at the Boston Public Garden. The Promontory is a rocky woodland slope that juts into the Pond. In 1934 it was renamed the Hallett Nature Sanctuary, set aside for wildlife and closed to the public. Tours of the Sanctuary are given in season by members of the Central Park Conservancy youth programs.

","This tour, which takes you from East 59th Street to East 65th Street, includes the Dairy, the Chess and Checkers House, Wollman Skating Rink, the 59th Street Pond and the Hallett Nature Sanctuary.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 15, 2009 12:07 PM CST",/visit/tours/downloadable-tours/,Default,TRUE,,,tours,,,/assets/images/visit-images/pond-daffodils-m.jpg,"tour, south, southern, south-end, south end, self guided, self-guided, walking",,"/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-south.pdf,/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-south-spanish.pdf,/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-south-french.pdf",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/pond-daffodils-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/pond-daffodils-t.jpg,

column1:
Mid-Park Self-Guided Tour,mid-park-tour.html,"

Belvedere Castle
In 1867, Calvert Vaux, Park co-designer and architect, created this fanciful observation tower as a &ldquo
column5: . Placed atop Vista Rock, it overlooks the old reservoir (now the Great Lawn). Designed in the Norman Gothic style, the Castle is constructed of the same Manhattan schist as its promontory, giving it the magical appearance of rising out of the rock itself.

/>The United States Weather Bureau set up offices in the Castle in 1919 to monitor and report New York City's weather. In the early 1960s, the Weather Bureau installed automated meteorological instruments, and the staff vacated the building. The empty Castle deteriorated into a sad, graffiti-covered ruin. In 1983, it was restored by the Central Park Conservancy and became a popular visitor center and nature observatory. The weather instruments remain on the Castle's tower and monitor New York City's weather around the clock. When you hear &ldquo
column6: The weather in Central Park is&hellip
column8: on the radio or television, remember the information comes from Belvedere Castle in Central Park.

column1:
King Jagiello and Turtle Pond
This imposing statue by Polish sculptor Stanislaw Ostrowski (1879-1947) portrays King Jagiello, the Grand Duke of Lithuania, who united Lithuania and Poland after marrying the Queen of Poland. The monument depicts the moment preceding his victory at the Battle of Grunewald of 1410 when the King crossed the two swords - handed to him by his adversaries, the Teutonic Knights of the Cross - above his head.

The sculpture was chosen in 1939 for the entrance to the Polish Pavilion at the World's Fair in New York. That year, the Nazis invaded Poland, preventing the sculpture's return to its homeland. In 1945 it was placed in Central Park by the Polish government as a symbol of the proud and courageous Polish people.

The King Jagiello statue is located at the eastern end of Turtle Pond, which attracts migrating birds and waterfowl and three species of turtles. The snapping turtles can reach nearly 20 inches (50.8 cm) in diameter, and can be seen sunning themselves at the waterline of Vista Rock. The nature blind, a platform that juts out into the northern side of Turtle Pond, is a wonderful place from which to observe wildlife.

Obelisk
This 3,500-year-old monument stands directly behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art. To celebrate the 30th year of his reign, Egyptian pharaoh Thutmosis III (c. 1479-1425 B.C.) commissioned a pair of obelisks for the sacred city of Heliopolis. In 12 B.C., they were moved to Alexandria, where they stood until the 19th century, when all great cities around the world clamored for an ancient Egyptian obelisk. The Khedive of Egypt gave one obelisk to England in 1879 and the other to America in 1881, in exchange for foreign aid to modernize his country.
On a snowy January 22, 1881, thousands of proud New Yorkers celebrated the turning of Central Park's 220-ton obelisk (nicknamed &ldquo
column3: ) to an upright position. The renowned filmmaker Cecil B. DeMille, who fondly remembered playing in the area as a boy, donated the plaques that translate the hieroglyphics.

column1:
Great Lawn
Very few people know that the Great Lawn, a luxurious green area at the geographical center of Central Park, was originally the site of the Croton Reservoir completed in 1842, fifteen years before the construction of Central Park began. With the City's increasing need for water, plans for a new water system rendered this reservoir obsolete. The reservoir was drained in 1931, filled in, andopened as a luxurious green oval in 1937.
The Great Lawn is better known as the venue for famous concerts and events, beginning in the 1970s. Concerts by Elton John, Diana Ross, Simon and Garfunkel, and Luciano Pavarotti
column2: the exhibit of the AIDS Quilt
column3: the visit of Pope John Paul II
column4: and the film premier of Disney's Pocahontas drew enormous crowds, causing severe damage to the lawn. In addition, the site still held the subterranean walls of the old reservoir, which prevented adequate drainage, and by the 1980s the Great Lawn had turned into the &ldquo

column1: From 1995 to 1997, the Central Park Conservancy and the City of New York undertook the largest single restoration in Central Park's history - the 55-acre area covering the 13-acre Great Lawn Oval and its surrounding landscapes. The Great Lawn is once again the setting for ballgames, sunbathing, and picnicking
column2: the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic each give their two traditional performances a year. All these activities are carefully monitored in accordance with the management guidelines instituted to ensure the continuing health of the Great Lawn.

column1:
The Great Lawn is a particularly good place to admire some of the Park's more than 20,000 trees. The Arthur Ross Pinetum at the northern end of the Oval features 15 species and five varieties of pines. The twin linden trees inside the middle of the eastern edge of the Oval mirror each other, their intertwined branches forming an elegant heart-shaped silhouette.

","This tour includes Belvedere Castle, the King Jagiello statue, Turtle Pond, the Obelisk and the Great Lawn. It will take you from mid-Park at 79th Street to 85th Street.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 15, 2009 12:08 PM CST",/visit/tours/downloadable-tours/,Default,TRUE,,,tours,,,/assets/images/visit-images/turtle-pond1-m.jpg,"tour, mid-park, midpark, mid park, middle, self guided, self-guided, walking",,"/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-middle.pdf,/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-middle-spanish.pdf,/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-middle-french.pdf",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/turtle-pond1-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/turtle-pond1-t.jpg,

North End Self-Guided Tour,north-end-tour.html,"

Charles A. Dana Discovery Center
The Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, which opened in 1993, was the first building in the Park's history to be built as a visitor center. Environmental education and activities are offered, as well as community programs, seasonal exhibits, and holiday celebrations. In the warm months, enjoy the Central Park Conservancy's free catch-and-release fishing program and the free Harlem Meer Performance Festival, two popular outdoor programs.

column5:
/>Harlem Meer
The Park's co-designers, Olmsted and Vaux, called this man-made water body ""the Meer"" (a Dutch word meaning ""lake""), in recognition of the former swampland that was a part of Harlem, the 17th-century community established in this area by New York's first European immigrants.

column1: In the 1660s, the British governors constructed the Kingsbridge Road, an east side highway that linked the growing port at the southern tip of Manhattan Island to Harlem and the British colonies to the north. The road crossed over the swamp by a series of low-lying bridges and passed through the only narrow break in the wall of steep rocky cliffs that line the southern shore of the Meer today. That opening became known as McGown's Pass, a site that played a significant role in the American Revolution. When British ships attacked the indefensible New York colony in September 1776, the British army marched up the Kingsbridge Road to McGown's Pass and captured the fortification that was placed at the pass. For the next seven years, British and Hessian troops occupied this strategically important area until their defeat in the Battle of Yorktown in 1783.

Conservatory Garden
The majestic trees of North America were a source of great national pride in the 19th century and many of the entries for the 1858 design competition suggested that an arboretum be included in the Park. Olmsted and Vaux envisioned their arboretum for the northeast corner of the Park - now the site of the Conservatory Garden and the Harlem Meer. The arboretum was never established, but the Park's first formal garden - the Conservatory Garden - was created in 1898 when a large E-shaped greenhouse was constructed at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street. It featured an indoor winter garden of exotic tropical plants and outdoor decorative Victorian flowerbeds. In 1937, the deteriorated greenhouse was demolished and a new six-acre formal garden was designed for the site.

The garden is divided into three distinct styles: French, Italian, and English. The French-style garden - closest to the Meer - features an ellipse of meandering boxwood and pansies, and showcases spectacular seasonal displays of tulips in spring and chrysanthemums in autumn. In the center is the charming Three Dancing Maidens fountain by German sculptor Walter Schott. The central Italian garden features an elaborate wrought-iron entrance gate and a wisteria pergola, a large lawn surrounded by clipped hedges, a 12-foot-high jet fountain (3.7 meters), and two exquisite allé
column2: es of pink and white crabapple trees on either side of the lawn. To the south is the English-style garden, featuring sculptor Bessie Potter Vonnoh's lovely Burnett Memorial fountain surrounded by flowering trees, beds of perennials and annuals, and a woodland slope.

column1:
Fort Clinton
During the War of 1812 New Yorkers assumed that the British would attack from the southern tip of Manhattan Island, and they built forts in that area accordingly. But in fact the British stormed Long Island Sound at Stonington, Connecticut on August 1814. New Yorkers became fearful that the enemy would sail west through Long Island Sound and attack Manhattan from the north. In August and September several fortifications were built on the high cliffs that flanked the Kingsbridge Road (also known as the Albany/Boston Post Road). From that vantage point, the American troops could see any advancing ships from the Hudson and East Rivers and the Long Island Sound, as well as any armies coming from the northern end of Manhattan. Named after Mayor DeWitt Clinton, Fort Clinton was one of four fortifications on the site that is now Central Park. Although soldiers were stationed at the fortifications, the British never attacked New York City, and in 1815 the Treaty of Ghent ended the war.

","This tour includes Conservatory Garden, the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, Harlem Meer, and Fort Clinton at the northeast part of the Park between 104th Street and 110th Street.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 15, 2009 12:08 PM CST",/visit/tours/downloadable-tours/,Default,TRUE,,,tours,,,/assets/images/visit-images/harlem-meer-ducks-m.jpg,"tour, north, northern, north-end, north end, self guided, self-guided, walking",,"/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-north2.pdf,/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-north-spanish.pdf,/assets/pdfs/maps/selftour-north-french.pdf",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/harlem-meer-ducks-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/harlem-meer-ducks-t.jpg,

column1:
The History of Central Park,park-history.html,"

Central Park is one of the urban wonders of the world, a green oasis in the great concrete, high-rise landscape of New York City. It is so naturally part of the Manhattan environment that many people may not realize it is entirely man-made.

Pre-1858
In the mid-1800s, 500,000 people were living in New York City, with most city dwellers housed in crowded, cramped quarters below 38th Street. To escape the din of city life, people sought refuge in such pastoral spaces as Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn.

The first public figure to champion the need for open green space within the city was Evening Post editor William Cullen Bryant. In 1844, he called for the creation of a large public park. Landscape gardener Andrew Jackson Downing joined Bryant in his pleas and together they pressed officials to set aside land before it was swallowed up by the fast-developing city. In a moment of rare political consensus, both parties at that time endorsed the idea of a large public park. Between 1853 and 1856, the commissioners paid more than $5 million for land from 59th Street to 106th Street, between Fifth and Eighth Avenues.

Then, in 1857, the independent board of commissioners sponsored a public competition to design the new Central Park.

1858 - 1871
Out of 33 entries, the commissioners chose the Greensward plan by Frederick Law Olmsted, superintendent of the Park work crews and Calvert Vaux, the British architect who had convinced the commissioners to hold a design competition.

The varied terrain of the topography set aside for the Park invited pastoral, picturesque and formal landscapes, all of which were included in Olmsted and Vaux's plan. Achieving their vision, however, was a challenge to both architect and engineer, as the area was rocky, swampy and muddy. The soil was inadequate to sustain the trees and shrubs Olmsted and Vaux planned, so 500,000 cubic feet of topsoil was carted in from New Jersey. Lacking modern machinery, workers manually dug up earth and blasted out huge boulders with gunpowder. More than 10 million cartloads of materials and debris were carted in and out on horse-drawn carts. Thirty-six bridges and arches were built and six man-made water bodies, fed from the City's water supply, were created.

Andrew Haswell Green served as comptroller and treasurer of the board of commissioners from 1857 to 1871, when the Park was under construction. Green recognized the brilliance of Olmsted and Vaux's plan when other commissioners were ready to dismiss it. It is because of Green's support and protection of the Greensward plan that so much of Central Park is true to its original design.

1872 - 1933
Most of the landscapes of Central Park were completed twenty years after the design competition was announced. Hampered by an endless series of political battles, Olmsted and Vaux officially resigned many times for either aesthetic or political reasons. Olmsted was finally removed in 1877
column2: Vaux stayed on and off until his death in 1895. In his 1882 essay ""Spoils of the Park"" Olmsted noted that because of Central Park's uniqueness it needed an innovative form of management. He recommended that an executive office, a skilled landscape architect and an unpaid and informed board of directors oversee the decisions for the Park.

column1: Together, Olmsted and Vaux are considered to be the founders of the profession of landscape architecture in America. Despite the challenges of building the Park, its immediate success launched the urban parks movement of the 19th century.

Near the end of the century, the public demand for recreational space and the advent of automobiles placed new pressures on the Park. In the 1910s and 1920s, however, neglect posed an even greater threat to the Park than sporting events or cars. For decades after Vaux's death, there were only intermittent efforts to improve the lawns, replace dead trees and shrubs, or to end littering and vandalism.

1934 - 1966
The election of Fiorello LaGuardia in 1934 gave Central Park a powerful advocate. LaGuardia unified New York's five parks departments and handed the reins to Robert Moses, who had built Long Island's first parkways and created Jones Beach. Moses immediately set out to clean up the Park.

Soon, flowers bloomed where there had been bare dirt, reseeded lawns returned to lush green, walks were repaved and drinking fountains repaired. The City filled in the lower Reservoir with earth to create the Great Lawn. But Olmsted and Vaux's original vision for rural scenery was of minor interest to Moses, whose generation saw the need for recreational facilities. During the Moses' 30-year tenure, he secured New Deal funds to underwrite the costs for playgrounds, ballfields, handball courts and the Wollman Rink. He also raised money from individuals to create such popular attractions as the Hans Christian Andersen and Alice in Wonderland sculptures, the Chess and Checkers House and the Carousel. In 1964, Central Park was declared a National Historic Landmark.

The early 1960s saw the start of some popular annual performances in the Park. In 1962, the Public Theatre's ""Shakespeare in the Park"" debuted. In 1961 and 1965, the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, respectively, began their series of summer performances on Sheep Meadow.


1966 - 1978
Already declared a National Historic Landmark, Central Park was named New York City's first Scenic Landmark in 1974, although neither designation secured funds for the Park's much needed restoration or maintenance.

Moses's departure from his position as parks commissioner in 1960 marked the beginning of a twenty-year period of decline for the Park. The Park was the setting for summer concerts, New Year's Eve celebrations, peace rallies, protest marches, Love-Ins and Be-Ins. But these public gatherings took a heavy toll on the Park's landscapes. The once-green grass, trampled on and without proper maintenance, began to look more like a dust bowl than a great lawn. Broken park fixtures were strewn about, benches were missing their wooden slats and the tops of lampposts were missing. Graffiti covered almost every available stone or wood surface.

1979 - 1981
By the late 1970s, the condition of Central Park had so deteriorated that a number of advocacy groups were formed to raise money, volunteers and awareness of the situation. Chief among these groups were the Central Park Task Force and the Central Park Community Fund. Needing an entree into the direct care of the Park, they approached Mayor Edward Koch and Parks Commissioner Gordon Davis. Under their leadership, the Central Park Conservancy was founded in 1980. William Beinecke was named Chairman and Elizabeth ""Betsy"" Barlow (now Rogers) filled the newly created post of Central Park Administrator. Thus began a new phase of in the life of Central Park.

The City and the Central Park Conservancy worked together to begin the long process of restoring the Park. The City issued bonds to fund a variety of capital projects while the Conservancy sought private funding to complement the City contributions. Work unrolled on Sheep Meadow, the Dairy and the Pond.

1982 - 1992
In the early 1980s, the Central Park Conservancy commissioned ten studies of the Park, covering its topography, hydrology, architectural features, circulation, drainage utilities, trees and other vegetation, as well as a security analysis and a Park user study. The results of these studies were used to create Rebuilding Central Park: A Management and Restoration Plan. Published in 1985, this master plan focused public and private resources on three tasks: rebuilding the Park's architectural heritage (both structural and landscape)
column2: re-greening the Park and providing constant horticultural care for its meadows, woodlands and gardens
column3: and providing programs and security for Park visitors.

column1: Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, the Conservancy worked with the City on many joint restoration projects. The Parks Department's capital funds, for example, paid for the early restoration of Belvedere Castle while the Conservancy raised money for the surrounding landscape. The design work for the restoration of the Harlem Meer was funded in 1986 by a private grant. In 1990, public monies funded the dredging of the Meer and the removal of its Moses-era concrete curbing. Private monies then paid to plant a naturalistic shoreline and to build The Charles A. Dana Discovery Center.

This era saw the completion of many other projects, including the reopening of Conservatory Garden, the restoration of Shakespeare Garden, Strawberry Fields and the Conservancy's first woodland restoration project that included the cascades in the Ravine. Also during this period, the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy created its Adopt-A-Bench, Tree Trust and Playground Partners programs, all of which continue to raise private funds to support Conservancy initiatives.

1993 - 2009
1993 marked the start of the Central Park Conservancy's ""The Wonder of New York Campaign."" With the overwhelming support of thousands of individual New Yorkers, foundations and corporations, the three-year campaign raised nearly $77.2 million. At the centerpiece of this fundraising effort was the restoration project that would transform the ""Great Dust Bowl"" into the 55 acres surrounding the Great Lawn and Turtle Pond.

To effectively maintain the Park, the Conservancy instituted a revolutionary new zone management system in 1995. The Park was divided into 49 zones, each with a dedicated gardener who provides a uniformed presence and is held accountable for his or her zone.

In February 1998, a new era began when Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Parks Commissioner Henry Stern and Conservancy Chairman Ira Millstein signed a management contract between the City and the Conservancy intended to ensure the continuing maintenance, capital restoration and public programming for the Park. This contract affirmed the City's confidence in its nearly twenty-year partnership with the Conservancy. Under the agreement, the Conservancy receives an annual fee for services, determined by a formula based upon the Conservancy's success in raising and spending a specified minimum amount of private funds in the Park on an annual basis.

Since the creation of this public/private partnership, the Conservancy has completed many more projects as part of its mission to restore, manage and preserve Central Park for the enjoyment of present and future generations. These include the restoration of the Reservoir landscapes and fence, installation of the irrigation system at Sheep Meadow and the restoration of the Pond and the Pool. Most recently, the Conservancy completed the restoration of the Heckscher Playground and Ballfields, the West 110th Street Playground and Minton Tile Ceiling at Bethesda Terrace, a historic preservation project that entailed the detailed restoration and reinstallation of 49 panels with almost 16,000 elaborately patterned encaustic tiles.

On the night of August 18, 2009 a violent thunderstorm with straight-line in excess of 80 mph tore through the northern end of Central Park. In less than half an hour the storm cut a swath of destruction unlike anything seen in the Park's history. Some 500 trees were wiped out and another 1000 badly damaged. The estimated cost for clean up and recovery is approximately $3 million.

2010 and beyond
Thanks to the generosity of many individuals, corporations, foundations and the City of New York, the Conservancy has invested more than $450 million to date into the Park, making it a model for urban parks worldwide. The Conservancy provides 85% of Central Park's $27 million annual operating budget and is responsible for all basic care of the Park. In addition, the Conservancy funds many public programs in the Park, from cultural series such as the Harlem Meer Performance Festival, to sports and recreation activities like climbing and fitness programs and volunteer-led free walking tours. Educational programs such as Central Park Scholars and Camp Central Park promote learning and leadership to the next generation of Park stewards.

Just as in the time of Olmsted and Vaux, Central Park is once again a leader in the urban parks movement. The Conservancy model has set new standards of excellence in park care, with parks across the city and around the world replicating the model. While the Conservancy's primary mission is the care of Central Park, helping other parks is a natural extension of our core mission. The Conservancy's technical and managerial expertise in horticulture, design, construction and administration is helping to bring other parks to higher standards and, in doing so, improving the quality of life for communities across the city.

Today Central Park has never been more beautiful or better managed and the Conservancy is proud to be the leader of the Park's longest period of sustained health and beauty. Olmsted and Vaux would be gratified that their beloved masterpiece is at last under the expert care of an executive who is both an able manager and a professional landscape architect, Conservancy President and Central Park Administrator Douglas Blonsky and a caring Board of Trustees, under the leadership of Thomas L. Kempner Jr., that not only plans for the Park today but plans for the Park's future. Mistrustful of city government, Olmsted never could have imagined the consummate professionalism of today's Parks Department under the leadership of Commissioner Veronica White.

As we complete the transformation of the Park, the next challenge is to secure its future and stop the cycles of decline that have plagued the Park throughout its history. Through long-term planning and the establishment of an endowment for Park care, the Conservancy is working to ensure the continued maintenance of New York City's 843-acre oasis. With your support, the Conservancy can continue to restore, manage and preserve Central Park, for present and future generations.

",Central Park has a long and facinating history. From its palnning stages in the 19th century through today the Park has evolved and had its ups and downs.,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 17, 2009 12:06 PM CST",/visit/history/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"history, olmsted, vaux, design, planning, construction, milestones",,,,,,,,

Mission Statement,mission.html,"

The mission of the Central Park Conservancy is to restore, manage and enhance Central Park in partnership with the public, for the enjoyment of present and future generations.
The Conservancy aspires to build a great organization that sets the standard and spreads the principles of world-class park management &mdash
column3: to improve the quality of open space for the enjoyment of all.

column1:
The Conservancy is committed to sustaining this operating model to provide a legacy for future generations of park users.

","The mission of the Conservancy is to restore, manage, and enhance Central Park in partnership with the public.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Jan 06, 2010 10:44 AM CST",/about/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"mission, mission statement",,,,,,,,

More Ways to Give,more-ways-to-give.html,"

In addition to membership and gifts to honor someone you care about, the Central Park Conservancy has other ways to contribute to Central Park. These include restricted gifts and support for specific programs.

column2:
>Make a One-time Gift
Central Park is your big backyard. It's the city's greatest outdoor gym. It's a place to play with your pooch. It's a cultural mecca. It costs over $58 million a year to operate Central Park and the majority is paid for by the donors who give to the Central Park Conservancy.

column3:
>Playground Partners
Playground Partners was formed to keep our playgrounds clean, safe and well-maintained. The program funds a maintenance crew with their own truck and equipment dedicated solely to the upkeep and repair of Central Park's 21 playgrounds.

column4:
1360.donation=form1"">Fight Dutch Elm Disease
Dutch Elm Disease is threatening Central Park's precious elm trees. One of the few large stands of American Elms left in North America, they are one of the Park&rsquo
column5: s most important natural treasures. The Conservancy has already spent&nbsp
column7: fighting this disease and the battle is not over.

column2:
>Perimeter Association
The Perimeter Association provides funding for the improvement and maintenance of Central Park's six-mile perimeter, from the Park's wall to the street curb. The Association employs a crew who clean and maintain the perimeter seven days a week.

column1: ",There are may ways to give to the Central Park Conservancy.,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Jan 11, 2010 11:54 AM CST",/donate/more-ways-to-give/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"donate, give, gift, support, pals, dutch elm disease, educational programs",,,,,,,,

Honor Someone Special,honor-memorial-gifts.html,"

The Central Park Conservancy has several ways to give in honor of someone you care about. Give a gift membership for a birthday, make a donation in honor of a new college graduate, plant daffodils or tulips for Mother's Day or choose one of our other giving options for any other occasion. Your contribution is a great way to mark life's milestones while helping to
<!-- SEND AN HONOR OR MEMORIAL CARD-->

column2:
>Send an Honor or Memorial E-card
Make a gift honoring or memorializing someone special by sending an e-card. Your contribution will be acknowledged through your own personalized e-card sent to the honoree, or their family, informing them of your generous gift, though the amount will always remain confidential.

>Adopt a Central Park Pal
Send an adorable (and meaningful) gift to your favorite child, teen, or anyone young at heart. Central Park Pals are six-inch plushes representing the animals that enjoy the Park&rsquo
column3: s green spaces. By symbolically adopting a Central Park Pal, you are sharing your support of the Central Park Conservancy. Did we mention they&rsquo
column4: re adorable? Recommended for ages 3 and up.

column2:
>Plant Daffodils, Tulips or Mums
Each year in Central Park, thousands of flowers are planted. With a minimum donation of $50, the Conservancy will plant your daffodils, tulips or mums in the Park to mark an anniversary, birth or other occasion. For your donation, the individual(s) you are honoring, or their family, will receive an e-card with your own personalized note.

>Gilder Run
Gilder Run, located on the steps of beautiful, Bridge No. 24, is a beloved location by all Central Park runners and walkers as it connects the East Drive with the Reservoir&rsquo
column3: s 1.5 mile running track. A paving stone on Gilder Run offers the opportunity to engrave your name, in stone, in Central Park.

column2:
>Adopt a Bench
The Adopt-A-Bench program was established in 1986 as a permanent fund to maintain and endow the care of Central Park&rsquo
column3: s more than 9,000 benches and their surrounding landscapes. In recognition of contributions to the fund, the Conservancy installs a plaque engraved with a personalized inscription on a park bench in a location of the donor&rsquo

column2:
>Endow a Tree
The Central Park Conservancy's Tree Trust provides for the permanent care of Central Park's approximately 24,000 trees. From flowering cherries to statuesque elms, contributions to the Tree Trust ensure the Park's trees are pruned, fertilized and kept healthy and strong.

>Give a Gift Membership
Show you share a mutual love of Central Park with someone you care about by celebrating a holiday or special occasion with a gift membership to the Central Park Conservancy. The person you give the membership to will immediately receive a personalized
e-card - created by you - informing them of their gift membership, though the amount of the gift will not be disclosed.

column1: ",There may be no better way to remember a loved one or honor someone special than by making a memorial or tribute gift in support of the Central Park Conservancy.,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Jan 11, 2010 12:03 PM CST",/donate/honor-someone-special/,No Ad Member-No right Margin,TRUE,Default - No Ad Member-No Right Margin,,none,,,,"donate, give, support, honorary, memorial, truibute, in honor, in memory",,,,,,,,

column1:
Be a Green Guide,be-a-green-guide.html,"

There are many ways to join in the Central Park Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s mission to keep New York City&rsquo
column3: s premiere green space vibrant and lush.

column1: If you love helping people as much as you love the Park, volunteer your time as a Greensward Guide. These trained volunteers act as Park ambassadors, greeting and guiding the Park&rsquo
""Our Greensward Guides tell us how much fun they have volunteering in the Park,"" says Mary Cregg, the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s supervisor for volunteer services. ""They really enjoy meeting visitors from around the world, and get a lot of satisfaction from being able to help people &ndash
column3: whether directing them through the Park or explaining the Conservancy&rsquo

column1: Greensward Guides work in pairs, walking through pre-designated areas of the Park. They give directions, answer Park-related questions, educate users about good Park stewardship, and inform them about upcoming events. Best of all? They get to spend a few hours every week in one of the world&rsquo
Training is provided, and volunteers have the flexibility of working any day of the week between 9am and 5pm. A three-hour commitment is required.

Become part of the Conservancy's dedicated corps of volunteers and help us keep Central Park clean and beautiful. For more information about the Greensward Guide program and other opportunities, e-mail

// ]]> or call the Volunteer Hotline at 212-360-2751.

",Join the Central Park Conservancys corps of volunteer greeters and help visitors get the most out of Central Park.,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Mar 17, 2010 11:41 AM CDT",/volunteer/,Default,TRUE,,,volunteers,,,/assets/images/volunteer-images/greensward-guide-m.jpg,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation, strawberry fields, imagine, john lennon, carousel",,"/volunteer/greeter-programs.html,/volunteer/forms-and-applications/greeter-volunteer-app.html",,,,/assets/images/volunteer-images/greensward-guide-s.jpg,/assets/images/volunteer-images/greensward-guide-t.jpg,

column2: May, this three-part series celebrates Central Park's winged wildlife, from red-tailed hawks to fanciful Monarch butterflies. Through lectures and workshops you'll discover why the Park is one of Manhattan's best places to spot an impressive variety of winged creatures.

column6: Belvedere Castle, located mid-Park at 79th Street. Be sure to bring your own binoculars to do your own birding in the Ramble after the program, or borrow one of the Conservancy's Discovery Kits, which include everything you need for a basic birding adventure.

column1: All ages welcome. No advance registration. Space is limited

A Clearing in the Forest,a-clearing-in-the-forest.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-155148399"" style=""-moz-user-select: all

The Central Park Conservancy's ""A Clearing in the Forest"" series combines eco-education and multicultural family fun at interactive dance, music, art, storytelling, wildlife and puppetry performances. Programs happen in the Park's most natural playground, The Peter Jay Sharp Children's Glade (located inside the Park near West 106th Street). Pack a picnic, grab your blanket, and get ready to discover Central Park in a whole new way!
All programs are FREE. All ages are welcome. No advance registration. In the case of inclement weather, programs will be canceled, or, if noted in the links below,
column2: moved to a rain venue. For more information, click on the links below. For day-of weather-related changes and accessibility information, call 212-860-1370.&nbsp

column1: Here's a list of what's happening this spring and early summer. Check back often for a list of more
Celebrate Earth Month! Dance to the music of instruments made from recycled waste with Bash the Trash and bring your used granola bar wrappers to turn your trash into treasure with TerraCycle!
Celebrate Mother's Day as Tammy Hall ""Storyteller Supreme"" weaves a flowery tale about mother and child, then plant a flower pot to bring home and let your love grow!
Fly like a bird and move to the beat of Leaf Arrow Storytellers Native American inspired musical tales of migratory birds and all feathered beings!
Learn about the wonderful world of butterflies and go on an adventure with Wildlife Theater's ""Butterfly Boogie!""
<td>How can you be a superhero for the planet? Find out with Talking Hands Theater and their&nbsp

column2: shake your willies out as you sing about your love for nature like that found in Central Park with Monkey Monkey Music!

column5: nursed back to health as enchanting music weaves through the story and extraordinary puppeteers from Arm of the&nbsp
column6: Sea Theater really bring it to life!

column1: Transport yourself to a Caribbean Island with a chorus of upbeat and relaxing sounds by Steel Impressions. Learn how the steel drum is a symbol of environmental innovation.
Experience Central Park as a jungle amdist the concrete through Robin Bady's stories of tropical and urban adventure, then get hands-on with urban jungly themed craft!
Get up close and personal with turtles like those that live in the Harlem Meer and meet their reptile and feathered friends - snakes, lizards, and an owl &ndash
column2: as you learn about them and their role in our ecosystem!

column1: Be taken away to a fantastic world through Balinese and Spanish dances with epic animal and insect characters weaving tales set in the enchanted forest of Central Park.
Master Storyteller Bill Gordh with his banjo will share folktales and songs about the birds and other animals one might see in Central Park this fall.
Join fellow Central Park families for some outdoor fun and activity with nature-inspired CircusYoga including a blend of styles and basic acrobatics for all ages.

The Children's Glade and its ongoing maintenance and care are made possible by the Directors of the Peter Jay Sharp Foundation.

","Each summer, the Conservancy's ""A Clearing in the Forest"" series combines eco-education and multicultural fun for the whole family.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Mar 17, 2010 03:46 PM CDT",/visit/things-to-do/family-community/,Default Lightbox,TRUE,,,"cultural-activities,kids-family-activities",,,,"family, kids, activities, art, music, theater",,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/peter-jay-sharp-childrens-glade.html,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/clearing-forest-t.jpg,

column1:
Volunteer to work closely with a Conservancy Zone Gardener and other volunteers on a weekly basis to help meet the horticultural and maintenance needs of one of Central Park's 49 zones.

By always working in the same zone, you'll develop a great deal of knowledge and ownership about your area of the Park. All shifts are 9:00 am to 12:00 pm, Tuesday through Thursday, and volunteers are asked to commit to a minimum of one three-hour shift per week for at least one year.

column2: AppForm=1"" target=""_blank"">Apply online to become a Gardener's Assistant. An interview and mandatory training are required.

column1: Field Tidier,field-tidier.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-162489519"" style=""float: left
Assist Zone Gardeners with their early morning pick up of litter, and if time permits, move on to Park maintenance.
Monday through Saturday, from 7:30 am to 10:30 am. A commitment of three hours per week is required.
If you are interested in becoming a
• Long Term: Volunteers work 3 hours each week, year round for a minimum commitment of 48 hours. New volunteers need to fulfill this commitment in the first 6 months.
• Short Term: If you have time on your hands but expect your schedule to change, accelerate your 48-hour commitment by working two 3-hour shifts per week for 3 months.

",Assist Zone Gardeners with their early morning pick up of litter and Park maintenance.,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Mar 25, 2010 03:39 PM CDT",/volunteer/horticulture-programs/,Default,TRUE,,,"nature-horticulture,volunteers",,,/assets/images/volunteer-images/volunteer-tidier-m.jpg,"volunteer, volunteering, gardener, garden, clean, plant, flower",,,,,,/assets/images/volunteer-images/volunteer-tidier-s.jpg,/assets/images/volunteer-images/volunteer-tidier-t.jpg,
Saturday Green Team,saturday-green-team.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-162487943"" style=""float: left

Join our group of Saturday volunteers to complete large-scale horticultural and maintenance projects throughout the Park. Projects may include raking, mulching, pulling weeds and planting bulbs.

Sessions take place on Saturdays from 10:00 am to 1:00 pm. We provide on-site guidance and necessary tools. No commitment is required. Come once, or come many times! Please note this program is only available for individuals 18 years or older.

Sign-ups open approximately two weeks prior to each session, space is limited. A day before the session, you will receive an email about the meeting place and project details.

column1:
Keeping It Green - For Schools,keeping-it-green-schools.html,"

The Keeping It Green program provides an opportunity for school classes to give back to their community and help take care of Central Park.

Environmental educators lead these action-packed programs in which students learn the value of volunteering and get an idea of what it takes to keep the Park's 843 acres clean and green. Projects are located throughout the Park with school location and transportation taken into account.
column2: Projects include leaf raking and mulching.&nbsp
column3: Students should dress to get dirty and wear only boots or sneakers (no open-toed shoes or slip-ons).&nbsp

column2: two weeks in advance and each school is limited to&nbsp
- June, with registration beginning in December

column1: Fall Sessions: September - November, with registration beginning in June

column2: more information or are interested in registering&nbsp
column3: a group, please contact the Youth Programs department by calling 212-360-1439 or e-mail

column1: Families interested in participating in a Keeping It Green session, click here.
