ROOTS,roots.html,"

The ROOTS (Restoration of the Outdoors Organized by Teen Students) program is for individual teens in grades 9
column3: and it provides a longer-term engagement and deeper level of education. It is a fun way for high school students to learn about the environment, meet teens with similar interests and develop leadership skills.

column1: Led by environmental educators, ROOTS students learn about urban forests and ecology by participating in the ecological restoration and management of the Hallett Nature Sanctuary, a 3.5-acre woodland set aside for wildlife and closed to the public since 1934. Projects include the removal of invasive plants, planting native plants, and the construction and maintenance of woodchipped trails. Students earn community service hours for their time and regular attendance is required.
column2: For more information or to receive an application, email youth@centralparknyc.org.

column1: For more information please call 212-360-1439 or email

column2:
Woodlands Youth Education Programs: ROOTS, Saturday ROOTS, and Woodlands Youth Crew are sponsored by The Heckscher Foundation for Children.

","Students in this two-month-long spring after-school program learn about urban forest ecology and management through ecological restoration projects in the Hallett Nature Sanctuary, including removing invasive species, planting native species and maintenance and construction of woodchipped trails. ",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Mar 30, 2010 10:44 AM CDT",/volunteer/youth-programs/,Default,TRUE,,,"volunteers,nature-horticulture",,,/assets/images/visit-images/roots-m.jpg,"youth program, youth, kids, children, teen, teenagers, roots, education",,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/roots-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/roots-t.jpg,

column1:
Event Information
The Central Park Conservancy's annual 3-on-3 Corporate Basketball Challenge welcomes teams of all skill levels from New York City's leading companies to participate in a fun, fast-paced, single-elimination tournament.
column2: Team members will also have the chance to show off their skills in a 3-point shootout and other special activities.

column1: Proceeds from this event support youth sports and recreation activities at the North Meadow Recreation Center throughout the year.
column2: The Center is a vital resource that enables over 86,000 young people &ndash
column3: with more than 75 percent from neighborhoods surrounding the Upper Park including Harlem and Morningside Heights &ndash
column4: to participate in programs that encourage an active lifestyle and a positive outlook.

column1:
Sponsorship Opportunities
The Central Park Conservancy invites your company to become a sponsor of the 3-on-3 Corporate Basketball Challenge.
column2: Title and 3-Point Shoot Out sponsorships are available, featuring an attractive package of benefits, including exhibition space at the event.&nbsp
column3: Please contact Claire McClafferty at 212-310-6692 or cmcclafferty@centralparknyc.org for more information.

In with the Blue,in-with-the-blue.html,"

This spring and summer, you&rsquo
column2: ll notice a lot more blue in the green heart of Manhattan.

column1: The Conservancy is expanding its recycling program for parkgoers, placing the signature blue bins in even more Park locations since we initiated recycling in 2007. That means you&rsquo
column2: ll be able to recycle bottles and cans at Sheep Meadow, the Mall, Conservatory Water, Bethesda Terrace, all our visitor centers, and the Dene.

column3: - are also coming to Sheep Meadow, Conservatory Water, and the Dene. Look for paper recycling, too, at Great Lawn, Heckscher, and North Meadow ballfields&nbsp
column4: - sites where bottle and can recycling has already existed.

column1: The Conservancy maintains 98 recycling bins throughout the Park.
column2: This year, that number will more than double to 236 bins.&nbsp

column1: ""Every year we expand our recycling program, and this is the next step for spring 2010,"" says Maria Hernandez, the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s Director of Horticulture. ""Environmentally conscious New Yorkers and visitors understand the need to keep moving forward with recycling efforts, both in and out of the Park.""

column1: Help the Conservancy protect the environment and the Park&rsquo
column2:
s lawns and landscapes by disposing of your trash properly. Use the blue bins for your recyclable materials - or better yet carry out what you carried in.

","As recycling efforts expand, parkgoers will see the signature blue bins in even more locations throughout Central Park.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Apr 14, 2010 09:42 AM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,/assets/images/visit-images/recycling-m.jpg,"recycling, cans, bottles, newspaper, garbage, environment",,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/recycling-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/recycling-t.jpg,

column3: is here with the openings of Sheep Meadow, Great Lawn, Conservatory Water (Model Boat Pond)&nbsp
column5: s 26 ballfields. While Parkgoers flock again to their favorite warm weather spots, they might not realize all the behind-the-scenes prep it takes Conservancy staff to get Manhattan&rsquo
column6: s famous green space ready for its close-up.
column8: April is a big month for us,&rdquo
column11: Now is when the Park really comes alive.&rdquo
column14: s picnic blankets and recreation-seekers, about 250 acres of lawn needed prepping and mowing. In fact, the Park&rsquo
column15: s annual rite of spring came this week with the first mow of Sheep Meadow &ndash
column16: 15 lush green acres in the south end of the Park voted last summer&rsquo
column23: While March and early April are crunch-time for Conservancy field staff, a bulk of their lawn work actually takes place in the fall &ndash
column24: the best time to restore the Park&rsquo
column25: s turf and ensure it dazzles in the warmer months. Lawns are aerated and seeded, weeds eradicated, and the ground prepared for bulbs. This season, look out for the more than 70,000 tulips Conservancy gardeners and zone volunteers planted last fall.
column26: Another sure sign of spring in Central Park?
column28: opening of ballfields at Heckscher, Great Lawn and North Meadow West Side, fields 1 - 6. (North Meadow East Side ballfieds 6 - 12 will open Saturday, April 24). But before the crack of the season&rsquo
column29: s first bat, Conservancy staff must test the soils, regrade the fields, add clay, and put in the pitchers&rsquo

column1:
Wildlife Watch,wildlife-watch.html,"

With its 136 acres of woodlands and seven water bodies, Central Park isn&rsquo
column2: t just your urban escape - it&rsquo
column3: s also a delicate ecosystem that&rsquo
column4: s home to an array of birds, waterfowl, squirrels and other wildlife.

column1: With each season their numbers ebb and flow. In recent weeks the Park&rsquo
column2: s raccoon population has greatly expanded, and tests have come back positive for rabies. Since the discovery, the Central Park Conservancy has been reporting to the Department of Health and the Parks Department, who are closely monitoring the situation.

column1: More recently, the Conservancy is aware a coyote has been spotted in the Park. Such sightings are actually not uncommon - in 2006, a male coyote was rescued in the Park. The Conservancy is reporting sightings to the Parks Department and will update the public with any pertinent information.

column2: s backyard, and we want you to enjoy every acre of it. Please take these small, common sense steps to help us keep our natural habitats healthy while enhancing your own Park experience.

column1:
Respect the wildlife. Never feed or approach a wild, stray, or injured animal. If you see something, say something: call 311 or notify a Conservancy employee.
Keep all dogs leashed. Pets can run off-leash before 9 am and after 9 pm. All other hours, they must be leashed. Keep a close eye on your dogs at all times and kindly share with non-compliant pet owners the importance of following these rules.
column2: Carry in, carry out. Be sure to dispose all your litter in the trash and recycling bins located throughout the Park. Better yet, carry out all the items you carried in with you.

column1:
Learn more about rabies at the Department of Health

Before welcoming back spring&rsquo

s turf. Lawns are aerated and seeded, weeds eradicated, and the ground prepared for bulbs. On your next visit, be sure to take in the more than 70,000 tulips Conservancy gardeners and zone volunteers planted last fall.

/>Playground Captains are made up of dedicated members of the Central Park Playground Partners Committee. Every third Saturday, Playground Captains are stationed in 10 of Central Park&rsquo
column5: s most heavily trafficked playgrounds, promoting PGP by word of mouth and distribution of membership cards. Captains bring banners, email sign up sheets, and Central Park family activity information, along with hot chocolate, doughnuts, sidewalk chalk and other family friendly activities.

column1: The Playground Captains program, which started in the early 1990&rsquo
column2: s and was revived in the fall of 2009, empowers families to work together to improve their local playground: their &ldquo
column4: It is a great way to meet neighbors and build community ownership. Playground Captains promote teaching environmentalism and stewardship to children and families as a way of giving back to Central Park.

column2: is a group of families dedicated to keeping Central Park&rsquo
column3: s 21 beloved playgrounds clean, safe, and well-maintained. Playground Partners has raised more than $5 million to fund a crew specifically responsible for caring for the playgrounds &ndash
column4: duties such as maintaining equipment, regular safety inspections, cleaning sandboxes, removing litter and debris. Annually, the last Wednesday in May, Playground Partners holds it&rsquo
column5:
s Annual Family Party in Heckscher Playground. This event features face-painting, music, and other Central Park themed activities for children of all ages.

Every third Saturday, Playground Captains are stationed in 10 of Central Parks most heavily trafficked playgrounds, promoting PGP by word of mouth and information on Central Park's family activities.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Apr 20, 2010 01:27 PM CDT",/about/womens-committee/,Default,TRUE,,,kids-family-activities,,,,"playground, playground captains, playground partners",,/about/womens-committee/womens-committee.html,,,,,,

column4: />If you've visited the heart of Central Park recently, you've probably noticed Bethesda Terrace's Angel of the Waters fountain veiled in scaffolding. Don't fret: the iconic fountain is undergoing conservation work and is expected to be back in view with its waters flowing by mid-June.
column5: As part of the Conservancy's program of cyclical conservation and maintenance, staff will be working on the sculpture's bronze and masonry elements over the next few weeks. Our conservation team will strip the sculpture's existing lacquer, condition the bronze, ameliorate the weathered patina and restore a sustainable hot wax coating &ndash
column6: all to protect the bronze from the elements and preserve the celebrated fountain for generations to come.
column7: The masonry repair includes repointing, which is replacing mortar in the joints of the masonry, and restoring several sculptural elements in the bluestone base of the fountain. At the same time, staff will repair the surrounding carved sandstone elements and work on the bronze gonfalons &ndash
column8: the long, ornamental banners on the edge of the Terrace.
column10:
Did you know? Angel of the Waters dates to 1873 and is thought to be Central Park's most photographed monument. It commemorates the ""healing powers"" of the Croton water system, which first brought fresh water to New York City in 1842. Created by Emma Stebbins, it also marked the first time a woman received a public art commission in New York City.

",The Angel of the Waters fountain is undergoing conservation work as part of a cyclical maintenance program. ,jklimkiewicz@centralparknyc.org,"Apr 22, 2010 02:50 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,central-park-news,,,/assets/images/visit-images/bethesda-construction-m.jpg,"angel of the waters, fountain, bethesda fountain, conservation, preservation",,"/visit/things-to-see/south-end/bethesda-fountain.html,/visit/things-to-see/south-end/bethesda-terrace.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/bethesda-construction-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/bethesda-construction-t.jpg,

Home to more than 24,000 trees, Central Park is often referred to as the heart and lungs of Manhattan. How does this
column2: green oasis thrive in the center of one of the busiest cities in the world?

column1: Find out at the Central Park Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s newest gallery exhibit, Under the Canopy: Caring for Central Park&rsquo
column3: s Trees. The interactive exhibit of photographs, eco-displays and tree samples takes you through the trees&rsquo
column4: natural history and explains why Central Park&rsquo
column5: s beautiful canopies are so important to New York City&rsquo
column6: s urban environment. Learn about the Park&rsquo
column7: s 152 species of trees and how the Conservancy&rsquo
column8: s innovative tree care program ensures their health for future generations.

column1: The exhibit, which opened Earth Day, continues through Nov. 28 at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center.

Making a Better Place to Play,making-a-better-place-to-play.html,"
column5: Those have to be some of the saddest words to a kid, and probably just as disappointing to their parents or caretakers.
column6: When you see a closed playground, it means the Conservancy is hard at work making Central Park an even better place to play. Our staff maintains the Park's 21 playgrounds, making sure they're clean and safe. That upkeep includes major renovation and reconstruction when needed.
column7: The East 76th Street (James Michael Levin) Playground is the latest to get a Conservancy makeover. Through summer 2010, the playground will be closed as the Conservancy:

column1: • Works to create better, more accessible routes in the playground
• Adds new toddler equipment and an ADA-accessible swing
• Creates an accessible water feature around the base of the Sophie Loeb Fountain

column2: connect the playground to the surrounding Park landscape

column1: In the meantime, explore the Park's nearby playgrounds: the Pat Hoffman Friedman Playground at East 79th Street or the East 72nd Street Playground. Or, check out the Conservancy's recent reconstruction work at some of the Park's most innovative play spaces: Heckscher, Ancient and Tarr Family playgrounds.
column2:
How you can help:
Join the Playground Partners, a group of the Conservancy's Women's Committee that has to date raised more than $2.5 million to maintain and repair Central Parks playgrounds.

column1:

Friend us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter to get the latest news on playground closings and reopenings.

column1: At the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center (inside Central Park on 110th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues)

column3: by the Harlem Meer lately, you probably enjoyed a scenic view that was hard to imagine 20 years ago, when the land lay in deterioration. Since 1993, the Central Park Conservancy has made incredible&nbsp
column4: efforts to restore this forgotten landscape with the introduction of native plant and fish species.&nbsp
column5: The now-flourishing habitat supports many species of wildlife including largemouth bass, pumpkinseed sunfish, bluegill sunfish, carp and chain pickerel.

column1: Each June, the Conservancy celebrates fish and helps families learn about aquatic ecology at this free

Rock out in your favorite Central Park playground at free Sandbox Programs, the Conservancy's longest-running series of programming, celebrating its 24th consecutive summer in 2013! Featuring dance, music and stories, these Sandbox Programs happen in
column2: different playgrounds all over Central Park on weekdays at 11am and 2pm.

column1: Sandbox Dance: Feel the rhythm and learn some new moves! Co-presented with Museum for African Art.
Sandbox Music: Learn to accompany live brass instruments with your own percussion under the guidance of professional teaching musicians from Central Park Brass.
Sandbox Puppets: Watch Ant and Grasshopper, Cat and Mouse, and many other characters tell folk and fairy tales brought to life by puppeteers from Wonder Spark Puppets.
Sandbox Stories: Hear stories about goblins, shoemakers, witches, princesses, fools and much more performed by New York City based storyteller Dan Kitrosser.

column2:

When people ask why we live in NY, this is the reason. It's an informal introduction to culture that kids don't get elsewhere.""

Restoring the Shoreline: Cherry Hill,restoring-the-shoreline.html,"
column2: />The next stage of the ongoing restoration work at the Lake is underway, with the Conservancy now focusing on&nbsp
column3:
reconstruction of the Cherry Hill shoreline.

Work along this southeastern section of the Lake &ndash
column5:
is expected to take about three months and reopen to the public in the fall. Crews are working to stabilize the shoreline and restore its naturalistic character, while also rebuilding paths and overhauling storm drainage and irrigations systems. The phase will wrap up with restoration of the surrounding lawns and landscape and aquatic plantings.

The work at Cherry Hill is part of the Conservancy's comprehensive restoration of the Lake, begun in 2006 to rebuild the eroded shoreline and reclaim silted-in coves and inlets. Completed projects include Bank Rock Bay, the Point and Oak Bridge.

In restoring the Lake, the Conservancy found a smart, sustainable solution in a material called coir logs &ndash
column6:
interwoven coconut fibers bound together with biodegradable netting. Staked at the base of the slope where the normal water level meets the shoreline, the logs protect the Lake's edge from birds and wave action erosion until plants can become established.

While the restoration at Cherry Hill will conceal a treasured Park view through summer, the work will result in much-needed improvements to the Lake's ecology and its scenic beauty. That means a healthier habitat for Park wildlife and a more picturesque spot for visitors to enjoy.

","The next stage of the ongoing restoration work at the Lake is underway, with the Conservancy now focusing on reconstruction of the Cherry Hill shoreline.",jklimkiewicz@centralparknyc.org,"May 13, 2010 02:57 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,central-park-news,,,/assets/images/visit-images/cherry-hill-construction-m.jpg,"the lake, cherry hill, shoreline, erode, coir logs",,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/cherry-hill-construction-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/cherry-hill-construction-t.jpg,

Harlem Meer Performance Festival,meer-performance-festival.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-155146553"" style=""margin-bottom: 20px

Join us each Sunday afternoon, 2:00 pm - 4:00 pm from June 16 - September 1, 2013, for lakeside music on the plaza of the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center in Central Park's beautiful north end (on 110th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues).

The Central Park Conservancy's Harlem Meer Performance Festival, now in its 20th summer, features the best in local established and emerging artists in the genres of jazz, Latin, gospel, blues and world music. Some chairs are provided, or bring a blanket and picnic lunch to enjoy the music from one of the Park's nearby lawns. The concerts are free and there is no advance registration required. All ages are welcome. In the case of inclement weather, concerts will be canceled (no rain dates). For more details, day-of weather-related changes or cancellations and accessibility information, please call 212-860-1370.
The 2013 Harlem Meer Performance Festival Schedule is as follows:

Tucked in Central Park's north end, the six-acre Conservatory Garden is one of New York City's hidden gems. Thanks to the watchful eye of Garden curator Diane Schaub and the green thumbs of her talented staff, the Park's only formal garden is spectacular in every season.

We talk with Diane to find out how she creates this floral work of art, what inspires her and what it's like to work in one of the most enchanting places in the Park.
How did you come to be curator of Conservatory Garden - surely one of the most coveted horticultural jobs in New York City?
column5: In spring of 1994, I was a recent graduate of the New York Botanical Garden School of Professional Horticulture, having left the world of film editing &mdash
column6: a form of pruning another kind of deadwood. A friend working with Lynden B. Miller, director of the Conservatory Garden, who had rescued the Conservatory Garden from decades of neglect, told me about an open assistant curator position at the Garden. I applied and was hired.

column1: In December of that year, Sarah Price
column5: decided to relocate upstate. I took a shot at the position. Even though it had only been a few months, I had fallen in love with the Garden and the world of public horticulture&nbsp
column7: that is, gardening for everyone. I could see what a unique and cherished place the Garden held within Central Park and the City itself.
column8: I was hired, and 16 years have flown by!

column1: Tell us about the creative process and planning that goes into designing the Garden's seasonal plantings. What inspires you?

It's great fun to design the Garden's seasonal plantings. I'm fascinated by the forms of plants' flowers, foliage and nuances of color. I plan different displays every year. Once, I repeated a particularly effective design and visitors complained! New Yorkers are a discriminating lot.
column2: In the North Garden, for example, I pick tulips in colors that will enhance the Garden's backdrop of deep pink crabapples and the many shades of the neighboring lilacs: a basic palette of pinks, violets, darker purples and blues, creams, even tulips with green streaks. I'll use a minimum of two or three colors and devise a pattern that will read well en masse. That's the tricky part! I've done knots, stripes, chevrons, mixes of up to five different bulbs, you name it! Once I've decided on the design and colors, I'll order those bulbs by the end of July for the following spring bloom. So I'm actually thinking about the 2011 plan now. Then, a week before Thanksgiving, staff and volunteers will put 21,000 tulips in the ground.
I typically use about 100 different varieties of annuals in the South Garden displays
column4: always some new ones, as well as the old, irrefutable standbys.
column5: There are five annual beds, color-themed to reflect the beauties of the perennial beds across the paths. The largest bed, for example, is composed of cool tones of blue, purple, and pink. The four smaller beds are predominantly yellow, orange, red, pink, and purple. In all the beds, we use blue and purple flowers to complement the dominant color and burgundy, chartreuse, or silver foliage plants to provide contrast.
column6: These plantings also serve as a kind of laboratory for assessing how well they might perform in other places in the Park where we use annuals: the Mall urns, the new Bow Bridge urns, Runner's Gate, etc. I'll be looking forward to some new additions in the perennial beds, such as Blackberry Lily (Belamcanda) and blue Aster 'Jindai', one of Lynden Miller's favorites. In the annual beds, I am trying Angelonia 'Angelface Wedgewood Blue,' a blue and pale yellow bi-color flower, that already looks like a winner, and 'Fireworks' Globe Amaranth (Gomphrena) whose name looks like it might be a bit of an exaggeration, but it's very early in the season and time will tell.

column1: What is the most gratifying part of your job?
column2: The satisfaction comes from the fact that so many visitors, whether New Yorkers or non-New Yorkers, are so generous with their praise. When they see something they like, they go out of their way to let you know &mdash
column4: s a clean restroom or a beautiful flowering border.
column5: What question do you get asked most by Garden admirers?
column6: I'm always asked when is the best time, or my favorite season, to visit the Garden. It's impossible for me to say!
column7: Spring in the Conservatory Garden is magnificent &mdash
column8: with the crabapples allees, lilac, tulips and daffodils offering scent as well as color. That could be my favorite season if it weren't for the lushness of bloom we have even in the heat of the summer, or the explosion of multi-hued Korean chrysanthemums in mid-October and November.&nbsp
column10: So, once again, I think I've failed to answer the question!
column12: Can you share one of your best horticultural tips for the upcoming summer season?
column13: I always stress with gardeners that it really pays to pinch back some of the new growth on most annuals and many summer- and fall-blooming perennials early in the season. It promotes branching and additional bloom. Many such plants, just in from the nursery, are ""stretched"" in their growth, because they&rsquo
column14: ve been competing with their tightly-packed neighbors for space and light. The result is often a weak-stemmed plant, which will get top-heavy and flop. Pinching gives the plant another chance at developing lower branching stems and a sturdier base for future bloom, as well as a diversion of energy into the root system.
column15: People are understandably nervous about doing this! Believe me, it's a good idea, and done at the right time, won't delay any blooms much, if at all.

column2: ",Curator Diane Schaub makes Conservatory Garden spectacular in every season. Find out what inspires her and how she designs the most enchanting place in the Park.,jklimkiewicz@centralparknyc.org,"Jun 03, 2010 03:42 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,nature-horticulture,,,/assets/images/visit-images/diane-schaub-m.jpg,"conservatory garden, design, diane schaub, curator",,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/conservatory-garden.html,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/diane-schaub-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/diane-schaub-t.jpg,

The Reservoir Fountain Returns ,fountain-returns.html,"
column4: />It has only been turned on a handful of times in 93 years, but now the commemorative fountain at the Reservoir is back and flowing again.

column1: The Central Park Conservancy has updated the fountain, originally built in 1917 to celebrate the completion of the Ashokan Reservoir and the dedication of the City's first water tunnel. Instead of using City water, the modernized fountain recirculates water right from the Reservoir.

After the 1917 commemoration, the fountain lay dormant until 1998 when it was repaired to celebrate the City's Water Tunnel No. 3, which crosses underneath the Park at 79th Street. In 2003, the fountain was activated a third time to mark Central Park's 150th anniversary. It has been used only sporadically since then.
column2:
The Conservancy is pleased to have restored and returned this ornamental element to the Reservoir. The fountain will operate until the cold weather sets in, so be sure to check it out on your next visit to the Park.

","Activated only a handful of times in 93 years, the Reservoir fountain is back and turned on again.",jklimkiewicz@centralparknyc.org,"Jun 08, 2010 03:13 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,central-park-news,,,,"Reservoir, fountain, water, commemorative fountain",,,,,,,/assets/images/news-images/new-fountain-t.jpg,

column1: The scaffolding is down, the netting is off and the iconic Angel of the Waters sculpture is back in view in the heart of Bethesda Terrace.
Over several weeks this spring, Central Park Conservancy staff worked on the sculpture's bronze and masonry elements &ndash
column2: part of our program of cyclical conservation and maintenance. Our team stripped the statue's lacquer, conditioned the bronze, worked on the weathered patina and restored a sustainable hot wax coating to the piece.

column1: The Conservancy's masonry repair included ""repointing,"" which is replacing mortar in the joints of the masonry and the restoration of several sculptural elements in the bluestone base of the fountain. Staff also repaired the surrounding carved sandstone elements and worked on the bronze gonfalons that flank the Terrace.
Part of our program of cyclical conservation and maintenance, the work goes a long way in protecting the angel from the elements and preserving the celebrated fountain for future generations.

Did you know? Angel of the Waters dates to 1873 and is thought to be Central Park's most photographed monument. It commemorates the ""healing powers"" of the Croton water system, which first brought fresh water to New York City in 1842. Created by Emma Stebbins, it also marked the first time a woman received a public art commission in New York City.

","After weeks of conservation work, the iconic Angel of the Waters is back in view at Bethesda Terrace. Find out how the Conservancy's efforts help protect the fountain for future generations. ",jklimkiewicz@centralparknyc.org,"Jun 17, 2010 03:50 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,central-park-news,,,/assets/images/visit-images/bethesda-fountain-angel-m.jpg,"angel of the waters, bethesda fountain, bethesda terrace, conservation, preservation",,/visit/things-to-see/south-end/bethesda-fountain.html,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/bethesda-fountain-angel-t.jpg,
Water Play in the Park,water-play-in-the-park.html,"
As the temperature in New York City continues to rise, one of the coolest places kids can go is Central Park.
column2: Many of the Park's 21 playgrounds are equipped with water features &ndash
column3: from simple sprays to water sculptures and mushroom-shaped fountains. Check out these cool spots for water play in our three most recently reconstructed playgrounds, all handicap accessible.

column2: The playground's new water-play features keep kids cool while they explore Egyptian-themed climbing structures. Water flows from an obelisk across two bridges and onto raised play platforms, cascading from one level to another until it spills down like a mini-waterfall. Water also rains from two tall posts, and an area for tots features three wall-mounted spray heads.

column1:
Tarr Family Playground

Picnic in the Park,picnic-in-the-park.html,"
As the heat of summer eases into the crisp of autumn, now is one of the best times of year
column2: to grab a blanket and head to&nbsp
column5: the Park's most popular picnic spots&nbsp
column6: are Sheep Meadow and the Great Lawn. At 843 acres, the Park&nbsp
column7: has many great patches of lawn ripe for lounging.

column1:
Here, five Central Park Conservancy staff members share their favorite picnic spots in the
Park &mdash
column2: spots you might not first think of when you're packing your picnic basket. Just remember: Always properly dispose your trash in the Park's garbage and recycling bins. Even better? Carry in, carry out!

column3: />I have to go with the Great Hill. It has several lawn areas that never get too crowded and some lush, large trees. That way, I can get some shade while my wife bakes in the sun. It's also a prime destination for touch football games. All in the same location, I can spend quality time with my wife and participate in my favorite hobby &ndash
column4: competing against other athletes just a tad past their prime.

column1:
Jamaal King
Facility Manager, North Meadow Recreation Center

column5:
/>
My favorite spot in the park is the Hernshead landscape on the west side of the Lake at 77th Street. The Ladies' Pavilion and the rock outcrop are away from the main path and often feel secluded.
column6: The views represent what I love best about the Park: the melding of the natural and the urban world. If you look northeast, you see the beauty of the woodlands of Central Park. If you look south, you see a wonderful view of the Manhattan skyline. It's a lovely spot to have a picnic, read a book or sit and reflect.

column1:
Regina Alvarez
Director of Horticulture and Woodland Management

column3: />My favorite place to picnic is the Conservatory Garden.&nbsp
column4: It's right outside my front door at the Conservancy's 104th Street office. The Garden is always changing&nbsp
column6: its colors, its fragrance, its palette of flowers. And there's always plenty of seating, with both shady and sunny areas, depending on your taste.

column2: is right across from the Garden's entrance, and it has a great selection of tasty treats. All you need to do is grab some goodies to go, a friend or a good book, and you have the recipe for a perfect Park picnic.

column3: />It's hard to choose just one among all the great picnic spots in the Park, but the Turtle Pond landscape is certainly up there for me. Just south of the Great Lawn, it has views of the magnificent Belvedere Castle and Vista Rock in the foreground.

column1:
Douglas Blonsky
President, Central Park Conservancy
and Central Park Administrator

Conservancy staff share their favorite picnic spots in the Park.",sbuchanan@centralparknyc.org,"Jul 09, 2010 12:33 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,"kids-family-activities,nature-horticulture,recreation-sports",,,/assets/images/visit-images/people-at-the-pond-m.jpg,"picnic, central park staff, lawn",,"/visit/things-to-see/north-end/conservatory-garden.html,/visit/things-to-see/great-lawn/turtle-pond.html,/visit/things-to-see/great-lawn/ladies-pavilion.html,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/great-hill.html,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/pool.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/people-at-the-pond-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/people-at-the-pond-t.jpg,

The Central Park Conservancy Film Festival,cpc-film-festival.html,"

Thanks to everyone who has made it out to the Central Park Conservancy Film Festival 2012!
The 10th Annual Film Festival, presented by Bloomberg, kicked off on Tuesday, August 21, with an inspiring Q&
column2: A by Do the Right Thing Oscar Nominee Danny Aiello. Danny discussed growing up next to the Park at West 68th Street, how he started acting, and why he sings. The next night, over 4,000 movie-lovers came out to enjoy Pee-wee's Big Adventure. On Thursday, August 23, 7,500 people came to see The Big Lebowski. On Friday night, Delta Tau Chi took over the Park in
column3: Animal House. The Festival concluded with the Viewers' Choice Film, Clerks, featuring a Q&
column4: A with the film's star, Brian O'Halloran

column1:
We asked Film Festival attendees what brought them out to the Festival. Jose from the Bronx said he wanted to take his girlfriend Arjulis on a romantic date (Arjulis says he succeeded). Julia from the Lower East Side came for her son, a Spike Lee fan. Aglaguel from Moroco came to spend a special night with his wife. Asad from the Bronx said Do the Right Thing reminds him of growing up in New York. Perhaps Laurie from Manhattan summed it up best: ""Because how beautiful is this?"" Most visitors said they came out to see great movies outside in Central Park!

column1: Central Park Paws,index.html,"<!--t:set id=""srcCode"" value=""param.lbcode"" /> <t:if test=""!isNull(srcCode)"">
Central Park Paws, a program of the Central Park Conservancy, represents the thousands of
dog owners who enjoy the Park every day, and aims to foster and maintain a
dialogue between dog owners and the Conservancy on behalf of the Park. Through year-round events, an electronic
newsletter, and volunteers representing each dog-friendly area of the Park,
Central Park Paws provides a forum to address issues relating to dogs, dog
owners, and other Park users and to increase awareness of the privileges and
responsibilities of dog ownership in Central Park.
Central Park Paws hosts activities for dog owners and their dogs, including:
Monthly Bagel Barks: events for dog owners held at
different locations throughout the Park during off-leash hours. Get the schedule here.
My Dog Loves Central Park Country Fair: annual autumn event that includes
competitions for Best in Park dog, Canine Good Citizen certification testing,
microchipping, an agility course for dogs, live entertainment, giveaways, and
Dog Tales Archive: a collection of rich stories about
dogs in Central Park and the relationships that are built in this beloved green

The best way to find out about dog-related news and events in Central Park is to subscribe to Central Park Paws. Subscribers receive a monthly e-mail from Paws, as well as access to all the previous articles and information on dogs in the Park via the eBarker.

maintenance, including turf care, tree care, dog drinking fountains, and the

activities of Central Park Paws. Become a member today!

column1: On Sept. 18, Chess is King in Central Park,chess-is-king-in-central-park.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-172432574"" style=""float: left
Don't miss the last of the Central Park Conservancy's summer series of chess lectures and simultaneous games on Saturday, September 18. Geared toward the younger set of chess buffs, the event
A frequent player at the Marshall Chess Club in Manhattan, Sturt will teach his winning techniques to kids from K-12th grades in
column2: Central Park at this Chess Lecture/Youth Simul event. The lecture will culminate with an exciting ""simul"" in which Sturt will play as many as 30 opponents at once, moving from board to board, one move at a time.

Checkers House (mid-Park at 64th Street), the event runs rain or shine from 10 am to 3 pm. Youth simul sections will be filled on a first-come, first-served basis from 10 am to 10:30 am on the morning of the event. (That includes official ratings of 1,000 or better, under 1,000 and non-rated).

column1: All are welcome to attend the lecture and cheer on the simul participants. Simul spots unclaimed by a participant with the appropriate rating at the close of registration will be filled on a first-come, first-served basis by rated and recreational players of all abilities. If space runs out, the Conservancy's staff will arrange games between players.

*Special Perk for Members!
Advance Simul registration available for Central Park Conservancy members at any level. Official rating requirements for Simul participation will be waived. Please call 212-310-6607 or e-mail

Not yet a member? Learn more about membership and the benefits.

column1: Art in the Park,empire-1.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-219413311"" style=""margin-bottom: 15px
The Public Art Fund's newest art installation has been unveiled at the southeast corner of Central Park &mdash
column2: a steel sculpture by artist Eva Rothschild titled ""Empire.""
column3: The sculpture is meant to reference the role of the Doris C. Freedman Plaza as one of the most heavily used entrances of the Park. Rising nearly 20 feet over the Plaza, the sculpture takes the form of a multi-directional arched gateway.

column1: ""The Plaza is a threshold,"" says Rothschild, one of Great Britain's leading sculptors. ""The work aims&hellip
column2: to heighten awareness of the shift that takes place when one steps out of the street and into the Park. It should become another gateway between two different worlds of urban experience.""

column1:
The sculpture will stand on display daily until August 28, 2011 at the Doris C. Freedman Plaza, located at 60th Street at Fifth Avenue. The plaza, named for the founder of the Public Art Fund, has been the site of more than 50 such projects since 1977.

",The Public Art Fund's newest art installation has been unveiled at the southeast corner of Central Park.,jklimkiewicz@centralparknyc.org,"Sep 23, 2010 11:07 AM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,cultural-activities,,/assets/images/visit-images/rothschild-l.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/rothschild-m.jpg,"public art fund, empire, doris freedman plaza, sculpture, art, eva rothschild",,/visit/things-to-see/south-end/doris-c-freedman-plaza.html,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/rothschild-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/rothschild-t.jpg,
Flight of the Monarch,flight-of-the-monarch.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-177968964"" style=""float: left
Some of Central Park's most colorful visitors are making their annual stop to feed on the sweet nectar plants of its gardens and landscapes.
column2: Each fall, millions of Monarch butterflies make their way to the remote mountain valleys of south central Mexico. The four-inch, dark orange beauties are one of the few insects that migrate to warmer climates.
column3: The Monarchs can be spotted fluttering through the Park along their journey beginning in late summer, particularly in Shakespeare Garden, Conservatory Garden and even Strawberry Fields.

column1: ""You can also spot them in the plantings around the Harlem Meer,"" said Regina Alvarez, director of horticulture and woodland management.
Among the Monarchs' favorite plants in Central Park? Brazilian verbena (Verbena bonariensis), Catmint (Nepeta), Mexican sunflower (Tithonia), and Bloodflower (Asclepias curassavica) &mdash
column2: a sweet-smelling nectar and host plant for the butterflies.

column1: Butterfly weed (Asclepias tuberose) and Milkweed (Asclepias syriaca) are also big draws. Not only do they provide the nectar the Monarchs need, they're also the only plants the butterflies will lay their eggs on and the only food the Monarch caterpillars eat.
Be sure to get a peek at the Park's fleeting guests in the next few weeks. And don't forget your camera!

column2: ",Some of Central Park's most colorful visitors are making their annual stop to feed on the sweet nectar plants of its gardens. ,sbuchanan@centralparknyc.org,"Sep 30, 2010 01:04 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,"cultural-activities,nature-horticulture",,/assets/images/visit-images/monarch-l.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/monarch-m.jpg,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation, monarch, butterfly, butterflies",,"/visit/things-to-see/great-lawn/shakespeare-garden.html,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/conservatory-garden.html",,,,/assets/images/visit-images/monarch-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/monarch-t.jpg,

column1: ARCHIVE: Fall into Central Park,fall-into-central-park.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-179064966"" style=""float: left

As autumn settles over New York City, Central Park is one of the best places to see fall's foliage. The vibrant colors are expected to peak in the two-week stretch between the end of October and the start of November. From the stand of American Elms that turn the Mall a glorious yellow to the scarlet Pin Oaks of the Ramble, a walk in any nook of the Park won't disappoint.
We asked Neil Calvanese, the Conservancy's vice president for operations, for an insider's view. Here are his picks of some of the best spots to savor the Park in autumn's full color.

""This is a lovely area for fall color,"" says Calvanese. Come in through 72nd Street and head toward Conservatory Water for views of vibrant beech, red oak, Norway maple, and red-berried hawthorne trees. Opposite the Kerbs Boathouse you'll find a colorful collection of linden and cherry trees lining the western edge of the water.

With it's shoreline surrounded by oak, beech, gingko, and bald cypress trees, this 11-acre water body will be ablaze with color at the end of October. ""There's such a wonderful variety of trees here, and they really color up beautifully,"" says Calvanese. Circling the Meer, he points to the stand of gingkos at the nearby Bernard Family Playground at East 108th Street. ""They'll turn a beautiful, vibrant yellow that make their uniquely-shaped leaves really stand out.""

For a spectacular fall treat, be sure to stroll up to Fort Clinton, a historic fortification on a high cliff directly south of the Meer. The fort provides a wonderful vantage point across the water. ""In this spot you can come up here and see a whole spectrum of trees,"" says Calvanese. ""It's also a lovely spot to sit and read a book.""

West 100th Street Pool/Great Hill
(West Side from 103rd to 107th Streets)

This area of the Park was dramatically affected by a summer 2009 storm that destroyed more than 500 trees. While some of fall's brightest and best were lost, replanting has begun. Calvanese says this serene nook will still offer up some spectacular color.

Begin at the Pool, strolling down the steps near the West 100th Street entrance. Among the autumn canopy, you'll see the reddish-bronze of European beech trees and the brilliant scarlet of tupelos. The northern shoreline is home to vibrant Pin Oak, hickory and sweet gum trees, as well as bald cypress that Calvanese notes, ""color up to a spectacular russet."" Head north following the connecting path to the Great Hill for more leaf peeping. This is a perfect spot to take in the autumn colors of black cherry, elm, sugar maples and young tupelo trees.
Fall's colors are fleeting. So be sure to make time this season to savor Central Park's best and brightest on your next visit.

column2: ",From the CPC archives: Get your walking shoes on and get outside we've got the perfect spots for you to soak in autumn's golden beauty.,sbuchanan@centralparknyc.org,"Oct 05, 2010 11:10 AM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,"kids-family-activities,nature-horticulture",,/assets/images/visit-images/sailboats-fall-l.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/sailboats-fall-m.jpg,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation, strawberry fields, imagine, john lennon, carousel, fall, foliage, trees, leaves, leaf-peeping",,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/sailboats-fall-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/sailboats-fall-t.jpg,

column1: Fall Gardening Tips,fall-gardening-tips.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-179588397"" style=""float: left

As the autumn chill begins to set in, these next few weeks are a gardener's prime time for cleanup and preparation before the cold months ahead. Few know this better than Regina Alvarez, who has 843 lush Central Park acres to wind down for winter as the Conservancy's director of horticulture and woodlands management.
""The season is slowing down and the plants are going dormant,"" says Alvarez. ""This is the time for the gardener to put the garden to bed for the winter.""
A few simple tips from Alvarez will have your garden in top shape once spring comes back around.

column2: Raking is one of the most time-consuming jobs in Central Park, and one of the most important. Be sure to pile the leaves in a place where they can compost through the winter. In the spring, you'll be able to use that organic matter to nourish flowerbeds, helping to improve the fertility and water-holding capacity of the soil.

column1: This is the time to cut back browning perennials, but be sure to leave plants that provide winter interest: wispy grasses, shapely seed heads like asters, goldenrods and sedums. Cut the stems off near the ground to keep them clean and neat, and prepare them for spring regrowth.
This is also a good time to divide your perennials, and perhaps fill in your garden's blank spots &ndash

Don't forget to pull out annuals to make room for bulbs and next year's annuals: impatiens, begonias, ageratum and marigolds. Be sure to take cuttings of tender plants such as coleus for propagating next year.

Autumn is the also the time for planting bulbs, trees and shrubs. Daffodils, tulips, crocuses, hyacinths and scillas. Since these plants are going dormant, gardeners will want to be sure to get them planted now so they can develop a good root system and establish themselves before the heat of summer.

Hold off just a few more months on pruning shrubs and trees. Winter is actually the best time for this gardening task, since fall pruning can stimulate new growth that will die as soon as the frost arrives.
Once you have your leaves and annuals cleared and your bulbs planted, be sure to use organic matter such as compost and a layer of mulch to act as a protective blanket for the oncoming winter months.

And don't forget the ornamental structures in your garden. With the garden wound down and quiet, this is a great chance to do any repairs you've been meaning to all summer long.

","As the autumn chill begins to set in, these next few weeks are prime time for cleanup and preparation before the cold months ahead. ",sbuchanan@centralparknyc.org,"Oct 07, 2010 02:08 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,nature-horticulture,,/assets/images/visit-images/conservatory-garden-fall-l.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/conservatory-garden-fall-m.jpg,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation, strawberry fields, imagine, john lennon, carousel",,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/conservatory-garden-fall-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/conservatory-garden-fall-t.jpg,
Gathering the Parks Leaves,gathering-the-parks-leaves.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-181523725"" style=""float: left

Fall's peak foliage has cast a golden palette over Central Park. It's also left a scatter of leaves from the Park's 24,000 trees. ""We're in full leaf-raking mode right now,"" says Russell Fredericks, chief of operations for the Central Park Conservancy. ""And raking will actually continue all the way through New Year's.""

Conservancy staffers fan across the Park's 843-acres daily, working with a dedicated corps of volunteers to gather the mass of leaves. On any given autumn day, Fredericks estimates at least 40 Conservancy staff members are raking, mowing, vacuuming or hauling leaves.
Once they're collected, what happens to all those leaves?

Some actually aren't raked at all. Those in woodland areas such as the Ramble, for example, remain a part of the rustic landscape. Those that fall atop certain lawns are mulch mowed, chopped into tiny bits and deposited back into the turf.

column3: are raked or vacuumed, then transported to the Conservancy's composting operation at the Mount, inside the Park at East 102nd Street. There, the leaves are formed into long, narrow piles called windrows. The windrows are routinely turned and aerated to help break down leaves. The rich compost it creates is put to good use year-round in all planting and horticultural projects, essentially blended back into the Park landscape.

column1: ""With the trees shedding their leaves and essentially shutting down for the season, our staff is really busy,"" says Fredericks. Yet, he says, this is also a beautiful time to be out in the Park.

""You get to see a different aspect of the trees than during the summer,"" he says. ""As they lose their leaves, they take on a special character. It's really something everyone should get out and see.""

column2: ","Fall's peak foliage has cast a golden palette over Central Park. It's also left a scatter of leaves from the Park's 24,000 trees.",sbuchanan@centralparknyc.org,"Oct 15, 2010 04:03 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,nature-horticulture,,/assets/images/visit-images/raking-l.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/raking-m.jpg,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation, strawberry fields, imagine, john lennon, carousel",,,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/raking-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/raking-t.jpg,

column1: Autumn Blooms,autumn-blooms.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-184611994"" style=""float: left

Spring may be a spectacular time to visit the Conservatory Garden, but autumn brings a brilliant palette all its own when more than 2,000 Korean chrysanthemums bloom in the North Garden. They're peaking now, and scheduled to be on view through Wednesday, November 10.
Blooming in shades of burgundy, pink, white and apricot, the mums have been part of the Garden's planting design for decades.

""They have grace and movement and incredible variety. They're really quite special to Conservatory Garden,"" says Diane Schaub, curator of the Conservatory Garden. ""They're an old-fashioned plant that you just don't see around much anymore.""

The Conservatory Garden is open daily from 8:00 am to dusk. Enter east side from 104th to 106th Streets, at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, or through the 106th Street gate inside the Park.

","Spring may be a spectacular time to visit Central Park's Conservatory Garden, but autumn brings a brilliant palette all its own when more than 2,000 Korean chrysanthemums bloom in the North Garden.",sbuchanan@centralparknyc.org,"Oct 28, 2010 12:11 PM CDT",/visit/inside-central-park/,Default,TRUE,,,"central-park-news,nature-horticulture",,/assets/images/visit-images/garden-mums-l.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/garden-mums-m.jpg,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation, strawberry fields, imagine, john lennon, carousel, korean mums, chrysanthemums, conservatory garden",,/visit/things-to-see/north-end/conservatory-garden.html,,,,/assets/images/visit-images/garden-mums-s.jpg,/assets/images/visit-images/garden-mums-t.jpg,

column2: free live jazz music by The Winard Harper Group. Estimated time to greet runners: 11:35 am for the lead women

column1: Winard Harper was born in Baltimore, Maryland in 1962. Since securing his first major drumming gig at the age of 20, he has become one of the most celebrated drummers, composers and band leaders in jazz. When not touring nationally with his sextet, The Winard Harper Group, he records and performs with such artists including Wycliffe Gordon, Jimmy Heath, Ray Bryant and Joe Lovano.
The Marathon Concert is co-presented by the Central Park Conservancy and Jazzmobile. No advance registration. For more information, call 212-860-1370.

Central Park is Central to Your Business
column2: A clean, green and healthy Central Park:

column1: Most importantly, Central Park provides an escape from the strain of city life. As a venue for recreation, relaxation and community events that is free and accessible to everyone, Central Park makes New York City livable.

The Central Park Conservancy is Central to the Park
The Central Park Conservancy is responsible for the restoration, management and preservation of Central Park. Each year, the Conservancy provides the majority of Central Park's $58 million annual operating budget, and is responsible for all basic care of the Park. 843 acres of lawns, gardens, woodlands, water bodies, playgrounds, ballfields, pathways, buildings, bridges and sculptures.
To discuss membership in the Corporate Partners Program, please contact China Ziegenbein, Director of Corporate Development, at

or 212-310-6692.

The Central Park Conservancy's ""Day in the Dirt"" program is a unique opportunity for corporate groups to promote volunteerism and environmental stewardship while building employee cohesiveness and camaraderie.

To meet the demand for this popular program and provide all the necessary resources to maximize the value of the day's activities for both the volunteers and the Central Park Conservancy, a ""Day in the Dirt"" is an exclusive benefit of the Corporate Partners Program and the only volunteer opportunity in Central Park for corporate groups.
To schedule a ""Day in the Dirt"" program, Corporate Partners may contact China Ziegenbein, Director of Corporate Development, at corporate@centralparknyc.org
Join the Corporate Partners Program today to access a ""Day in the Dirt"" and other exclusive benefits.

column2:
Friday, 10am-1pm
The Conservancy requires a minimum of four weeks advance notice. The location and specific activity will be confirmed one to two weeks prior to the scheduled program.

column1:
Activities
Activities are assigned by the Conservancy based on the needs of the Park at the time of the scheduled program and may include:
• Planting ground cover, bulbs or other plantings

Supplies and Supervision
Sessions are supervised by our trained field staff, and the Conservancy provides all of the tools or equipment needed for the activity. Fresh water is provided, and companies may supply additional beverages or snacks, if they wish.

On-site Signage
Participating companies are acknowledged with their logo on signage that is displayed in the work area while activities are under way.

Entertain in Central Park,entertain-in-central-park.html,"

Solidify client relationships, reward high-performing associates or provide executives with high-quality networking opportunities through a variety of exclusive and memorable entertainment options available in Central Park through the Central Park Conservancy.

• Sponsor a table or purchase tickets to our special events, including our annual Taste of Summer, Autumn in Central Park or Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon, which are consistently ranked among New York City's top benefits.

• Schedule a private tour* of Central Park with author and photographer Sara Cedar Miller, Central Park Conservancy's official historian and the nation's foremost expert on Central Park, and provide your guest with a unique and unforgettable behind-the-scenes experience in Central Park.
• Host a reception or meeting** in one of the City's most unique venues, the Gallery at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, which overlooks the picturesque Harlem Meer.
To discuss entertainment options in Central Park, please contact China Ziegenbein, Director of Corporate Development, at cziegenbein@centralparknyc.org

Partner with the Central Park Conservancy on cause-related marketing programs and corporate advertising campaigns to benefit Central Park, your customers and your company. Whether you are launching a new product, sales promotion, or branding campaign
column2: celebrating a corporate achievement or milestone
column3: or raising awareness about corporate values, consider how a partnership with the Conservancy can advance your corporate objectives.

column1: Partnerships provide the Central Park Conservancy with an opportunity to reach out to a variety of audiences with important information about Central Park stewardship and to raise funds to support restoration, conservation, and maintenance in Central Park. In addition, the initiatives provide corporate supporters an opportunity to make a positive impact on the community and involve employees and consumers in the cause.

We welcome the opportunity to develop new partnerships with companies with a solid history and strong brand image who would like to make a contribution that is significant and clearly defined to the consumer. The Conservancy follows the Better Business Bureau's Standards for Charity Accountability when developing such partnerships.
To discuss promotional or cause-related marketing opportunities, please contact China Ziegenbein, Director of Corporate Development, at

It's not just financial donations that can support the Conservancy's mission to restore, preserve and manage Central Park. Through the contribution of in-kind gifts, companies can provide budget relief to the Central Park Conservancy while showcasing a product or service to attractive target markets, redirecting excess inventory or resources, supporting the communities where they do business and qualifying for a tax deduction.
Examples of products and services that may be accepted Central Park Conservancy include:
• Gourmet or luxury consumer goods or services (for silent auction, event door prize or gift bags)
To discuss promotional in-kind donation opportunities, please contact China Ziegenbein, Director of Corporate Development, at cziegenbein@centralparknyc.org

column1: The Central Park Conservancy is proud to have
column2: partnered with Bid to Save the Earth, an environmentally friendly fundraising initiative and auction presented by Christie's International.

column1: The live auction at Christie's took place on Tuesday, March 29 and raised nearly $1.4 million to benefit the Conservancy as well as our three partner non-profit organizations: Oceana, Conservation International and the Natural Resources Defense Council.
column3: highlights of the live auction was an ultimate culinary tour presented by renowned Chef, Alain Ducasse, taking epicureans on a tasting adventure through New York, Paris, Provence and Tuscany.&nbsp
column4: And to make getting around easy, Hertz provided an eco-friendly vehicle for the journey!

column1: The gallery above showcases the unique packages offered by the Conservancy for the online auction. From an exotic Patagonian excursion to a hiking adventure through the Italian Riviera, these auction items allowed winning bidders to enjoy memorable luxury experiences &ndash
column2:
all while supporting the world's most celebrated green space.

column4: />The Saturday ROOTS program is for individual teens in grades 9&nbsp
column6: provides a longer-term engagement and deeper level of education. It's a fun way for high school students to learn about the environment, meet teens with similar interests and develop leadership skills.

column1: Led by environmental educators, Saturday ROOTS students learn about urban forest and ecology by participating in the ecological restoration and management of Central Park's woodlands.
column2: Projects include the removal of invasive plants, planting native plants and trail maintenance. Students earn community service hours for their time and regular attendance is required.

column1: Acceptance into Saturday ROOTS is through a competitive application process. Applications are available in December for the spring semester and June for the fall semester. For more information or to receive an application, email youth@centralparknyc.org.

column2: more information or are interested in applying, please contact the Youth Programs department by calling 212-360-1439, or e-mail

Woodlands Youth Education Programs: ROOTS, Saturday ROOTS, and Woodlands Youth Crew are sponsored by The Heckscher Foundation for Children.

Keep an eye on our calendar to find out about Wednesday's Tavern Twilights, Fitness Fridays, Kids on the Scene, and other events that include outdoor music performances, film screenings, lectures, fitness events, walking tours and more. The mission of the Central Park Conservancy is to restore, manage, and enhance Central Park in partnership with the public.
The Conservancy aspires to build a great organization that sets the standard for and spreads the principles of world-class park management &mdash
column3: to improve the quality of open space for the enjoyment of all.

column1: The Conservancy is committed to sustaining this operating model to provide a legacy for future generations of park users.

Central Park is a masterpiece of landscape architecture created to provide a scenic retreat from urban life for the enjoyment of all and, in so doing, to establish New York's place among the great cities of the world. As the organization entrusted with the responsibility of caring for New York's most important public space, our work is founded on the belief that citizen leadership and private philanthropy are key to ensuring that the Park and its essential purpose endure.

The Central Park Conservancy is a private, not-for-profit organization founded in 1980 that manages Central Park under a contract with the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation. Thanks to the generosity of many individuals, corporations, foundations, and the City of New York, the Conservancy has invested $690 million to date into the Park, $536 million of which was privately funded, making it a model for urban parks worldwide. The Conservancy provides the majority of Central Park's $58.3 million annual operating budget, and is responsible for all basic care of the Park.
With 40 million visitors each year to its 843 acres, Central Park is the most frequently visited urban park in the United States. To manage the Park, Conservancy crews aerate and seed lawns
column8: and care for waterbodies and woodlands, controlling erosion, maintaining the drainage system, and protecting over 150 acres of lakes and streams from pollution, siltation, and algae.

column1: Originally signed in February 1998 and renewed in 2006, the City of New York awarded the Central Park Conservancy a management contract to ensure the continuing maintenance, public programming, and capital restoration of Central Park. This contract affirms the City's confidence in its more than thirty year partnership with the Conservancy. The Conservancy has invested nearly $650 million in Central Park operations, capital improvements, programs for visitors and volunteers. Under this agreement, the Conservancy receives an annual fee for services. The amount of the fee is determined by a formula from the City that requires the Conservancy to raise and spend a specified minimum amount of private funds in the Park on an annual basis.

Under this renewed eight-year agreement, the Conservancy provides for the Park's day-to-day care. Specified in the contract are: landscape maintenance, replacement of dead trees and plants, mowing and reseeding/resodding, graffiti removal, cleaning playgrounds and comfort stations, clearing walkways
column3: repairing benches, and maintaining and repairing structures and monuments. The Conservancy's responsibilities also include providing public programs to educate visitors about the Park's assets.

column1: <h4>THE CITY OF NEW YORK'S ROLE IN CENTRAL PARK

The City of New York retains control and policy responsibility for Central Park. Capital improvements in the Park continue to undergo public review at each stage of development, with advice and consent from the Commissioner of Parks & Recreation. In addition, the City of New York/ Parks & Recreation continues to have discretion over all events in the Park.

The Central Park Conservancy is uniquely qualified to manage Central Park. Since 1980, the Conservancy has restored and managed the Park with its partner, the City of New York. The Conservancy brought the Park back from its deteriorated state in the 1960s and 1970s to its present condition by restoring and maintaining major landscapes and historic structures. The Conservancy is a model for public-private partnerships for parks throughout the country and has developed an accomplished staff of park management professionals.

The Conservancy also has an impressive track record in raising private funds to improve and preserve Central Park. The Conservancy has invested more than $650 million in private dollars, which, combined with the City's investment, has turned Central Park into a living symbol of New York City's revitalization.

The Conservancy is accountable to the City of New York. The City of New York retains control and policy responsibility for Central Park. The Commissioner and officials of the City of New York/Parks & Recreation are involved in all Park planning and must approve all of the Conservancy's capital improvements in the Park. The Conservancy, however, as a private not-for-profit organization, has a separate Board of Trustees. The Board is comprised of 43 general trustees representing the community that uses the Park, four ex officio trustees including the Parks Commissioner, the Borough President of Manhattan, the Central Park Administrator, and the president of the Women's Committee, and five Trustees appointed by the Mayor of the City of New York. Additionally, there are currently 13 Life Trustees.

column5: >Central Park is a masterpiece of landscape architecture created to provide a scenic retreat from urban life for the enjoyment of all and, in so doing, to establish New Yorks place among the great cities of the world. As the organization entrusted with the responsibility of caring for New Yorks most important public space, our work is founded on the belief that citizen leadership and private philanthropy are key to ensuring that the Park and its essential purpose endure.

>COMMITMENT - We value commitment to our mission, Central Park and the visitor experience.

EXCELLENCE - We value innovation and the highest quality results in every aspect of our work.

INTEGRITY - We value ethical conduct in our business practices.

ADAPTABILITY - We value adaptability in our response to change and challenges.

COMMUNICATION We value clear, consistent communication, teamwork and an open dialogue both internally and with the public.

PUBLIC CONFIDENCE - We value the public and work to earn and maintain their confidence in our role as caretakers of Central Park.
column9:
>

Music will take center stage at the ninth annual Central Park Conservancy Film Festival, which brings free movies to the heart of Manhattan for five nights, Aug. 23-27. From rock to country, the films will celebrate great musicians and the best in popular music, with each night showcasing a different musical icon. Saturday night's movie will be Viewer's Choice!

All screenings begin at 8:00 pm, rain or shine. Gates open to the public at 6:30 pm. Guest DJs play at 6:30 pm. All movies will be closed captioned. Bring a picnic! Please note that alcoholic beverages, glass bottles, video cameras, tape recorders or flash cameras are not allowed. All bags are subject to search.

Tour Guide,tour-guide.html,"

Thank you for your interest in joining the Central Park Conservancy Tour Program. Please read the description of the Tour Guide volunteer position below. If you feel you meet the requirements, expectations and qualifications for the position, please submit your application. Only qualified candidates will be contacted for an interview.

Please note that, if selected to join the Tour Program, attendance at seven mandatory training sessions is required. Anyone not able to attend all training sessions will not be able to join the Tour Program. The dates of the training sessions are:

column2:
>Monday, September 26, 2011 (6:00 pm to 8:30 pm)
Saturday, October 22, 2011 (10:00 am to 1:00 pm)
Wednesday, November 2, 2011 (6:00 pm to 8:00 pm)
Saturday, November 12, 2011 (10:00 am to 1:00 pm)
Monday, November 21, 2011 (6:00 pm to 8:00 pm)
Saturday, December 3, 2011 (10:00 am to 1:00 pm)
Monday, December 12, 2011 (6:00 pm to 8:00 pm)

column1: In addition, for qualified candidates, a group interview for selection to the Tour Program will take place on Monday, September 19, 2011, from 6:00 pm to 8:00 pm. If your application is selected, you will be contacted to attend the group interview.
As a Central Park Conservancy Tour Guide you agree to:

column4:
Complete the training program by attending all sessions
&bull
column6:
Take one tour a week during training
&bull
column8: Commit to a minimum of four tours per month (two as Lead, two as&nbsp
column11:

column13:

column19:

column21:
A three-month probationary period starting once you've been scheduled to give tours
&bull

Attend continuing education classes offered by the Conservancy

column27: Make a minimum two-year commitment to the Tour Program

As the Lead walk the tour route prior to start

column14:

&bull
column18:

column20: Maintain open communication with the Conservancy's Volunteer Department and/or the Tour Program Steering Committee to keep current on new information, policies, and to address any issues or concerns.

column8:

Hurricane Cleanup in Central Park,hurricane-cleanup-in-central.html,"
Hurricane Irene swept through Central Park early Sunday morning with winds and heavy rain, uprooting at least 25 trees, downing thousands of branches and flooding paths.
column2: More than 50 Conservancy crew members and tree contractors responded to the damage during and after the hurricane. Flooded paths were pumped to nearby catch basins, and in less than 24 hours after the storm's conclusion, crews had removed the fallen trees and leveled their stumps. Over the next week, the Conservancy will continue the clean-up effort, including tree work and clearing, safety inspections, and assessing other damage sustained by the Park.

column1: Watch our tree crews clear damaged trees in the Park.
Support us in our clean-up efforts: give to the
column3:
