column1: Remarks of John Paulson and Doug Blonsky as Prepared for Gift Announcement,paulson-blonsky-remarks.html,,,sbuchanan@centralparknyc.org,,/about/news/press-releases/,Full body only - No right M. No Headline,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation",,,,,,,,
Remarks of John Paulson and Doug Blonsky as Prepared for Gift Announcement,paulson-blonsky-remarks-1.html,"
column7: >Media Contact: Dena Libner

column4: >DOUG BLONSKY AND JOHN A. PAULSON DELIVER REMARKS AT
column5: >ANNOUNCMENT OF LARGEST GIFT IN HISTORY OF PUBLIC PARKS

column4: >John A. Paulson and the Paulson Family Foundation&rsquo
column5: s Gift of $100 million sustains Central Park&rsquo
column6: s impact on the cultural, economic health of New York City

column4: s remarks as prepared for delivery this morning:

column6: Thank you everyone for joining us to be a part of a singular moment in the history of Central Park &ndash
column7: a moment in which its role as the extraordinary democratic space the public deserve is not only recognized but sustained for the long term.

column6: Beside me is my friend John Paulson, a Trustee and partner of the Central Park Conservancy who shares our vision of an exemplary public park that gives every man, woman and child free access to recreation, exploration, nature and incredible beauty. Today, we are thrilled to accept his extraordinary gift of $100 million dollars &ndash
column7: a donation that will touch literally every acre of the people&rsquo

column6: This is the largest gift ever made to any public park, and one of the largest to be made to a New York City cultural institution. It ushers Central Park and the Conservancy into their latest phase: long-term sustainability, unprecedented maintenance and management, and a model for other parks and public spaces worldwide.
More specifically, it will continue the Conservancy&rsquo
column7: s restoration and maintenance of its 21 playgrounds, 130 acres of woodlands, improvements to park-wide infrastructure and comfort stations, maintenance and upgrades to its five visitor centers and recreational facilities, and the enhancement of youth and family programming. It allows us to continue to surge ahead: while we&rsquo
column8: ve restored much of Central Park, the maintenance of our improvements is never-ending. This gift allows restoration to continue and past improvements to endure and for us to expand our work in assisting other public parks throughout New York City.

column6: The benefits of this gift won&rsquo
column7: t only be seen inside Central Park&rsquo
column9: s management practices will be developed as a model for public-private partnerships locally and worldwide.

column6: This gift is about more than the endurance of Central Park&rsquo
column8: s about recognizing the necessity and uniqueness of the Conservancy. For the past 33 years, the Conservancy has restored and maintained what was a neglected public park for the enjoyment of more than 40 million annual visitors and vigilantly maintains those improvements every hour of every day. As a result, Central Park has never been more beautiful or better managed than it has for the last three decades.

column6: John is a man who knows a good investment when he sees one. Central Park is fundamental to the economic and cultural health of New York City and the quality of life of its residents. Its 843 thoughtfully designed acres contribute more than $1 billion dollars to its economy annually and grants the most wonderful respite from the stress and chaos of urban life.
John has been a supporter of the Conservancy&rsquo
column7: s mission for more than 20 years. He shares the vision of the Park&rsquo
column8: s original creators, Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, as well as the vision of the Central Park Conservancy: that Central Park should be a celebration of the people.

column6: I remember a walk I took with John in Central Park&rsquo
column7: s North Woods last fall. It was around 6:00 in the morning, and the weather was chilly. I thought the walk would be a quick one, but John wanted to explore every path in those woods. When we passed by field staff at work, he wanted to understand what they were doing. That&rsquo
column8: s when I really got it: this is a guy who shares our sincere excitement about Central Park. He understands how far the Park has come and the organization responsible for its reawakening. And he wanted to help and be a part of it.

column6: John, on behalf of the Central Park Conservancy, its 300 employees, 900 volunteers and the more than 40 million annual visitors who will benefit from this gift each year: thank you, thank you, thank you. As steward of this park and curator of this cultural institution, the Conservancy is grateful for your acknowledgement of its role as a global leader in park restoration and management, as well as its role as one of New York City&rsquo
column7: s premier cultural institutions. Today is a day of gratitude and celebration: gratitude for your generosity, and a celebration on behalf of the infinite number of people this gift has the potential to touch. Thank you.
d like to introduce and welcome John Paulson to say a few words about his extraordinary gift to Central Park, the Conservancy and the people of New York.&rdquo

column6: s remarks as prepared for delivery this morning:

column5: Thank you for joining us today. This is an extraordinary honor: to give my support to the Central Park Conservancy, which is responsible for transforming Central Park into what it is today &mdash
column6: a magnificent space that does so much for so many every day.

column5: For over 150 years, the Central Park Conservancy has been among New York City&rsquo
column6: s most important cultural institutions. An urban oasis for visitors from all over New York City and the world, Central Park&rsquo
column7: s significance to New York cannot be overstated. It&rsquo
column8: s simply impossible to imagine what New York would be without Central Park.

column5: In the early morning, Central Park is a refuge of peaceful tranquility while on the weekends it&rsquo
column6: s a kaleidoscope of activity, excitement, and energy. This past weekend in the Park, I saw babies in carriages, children playing, couples holding hands, dogs running, musicians playing, and people from all over the world talking, laughing, and exercising. I thought to myself: Central Park is such a unique place, unlike anywhere else in the world.
t always been the oasis that it is today. In the 1970s and early 1980s, it was in serious disrepair &mdash
column7: its infrastructure was crumbling, its landscapes were in shambles and it was plagued with drugs and crime.&nbsp
column8: Thanks to an extremely successful partnership that began in 1980 between the City of New York and the Central Park Conservancy, Central Park has been magnificently restored. From Bethesda Fountain to Sheep Meadow, from the Harlem Meer to the Promenade, from Strawberry Fields to the Conservatory Gardens, the metamorphosis has been extraordinary. Today over 40 million people visit a year, up 200% since the Conservancy took over.

column5: We have many people to thank for this transformation and the continued maintenance and improvements, including the co-founders Betsy Rogers and Gordon Davis, current President Douglas Blonsky, the Conservancy Board of Trustees, the 374 full and part-time Conservancy staff who care for the Park every day, City Hall and Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Parks Commissioner Veronica White and the 35,000 Central Park Conservancy members.
People may ask why make such a gift to Central Park today. There are several reasons:

column13: >First, in contrast to what many people think, although Central Park is a public park, 85% of the operating budget for Central Park is funded by the Central Park Conservancy, a private organization. The operation of Central Park requires contributions from the private sector. A portion of today&rsquo
column14: s gift will go to the permanent endowment of the Central Park Conservancy to ensure it has the operating funds to pay for its upkeep.

column13: >Secondly, while Central Park is probably in the best shape it has ever been, more work needs to be done. Fifty percent of today&rsquo
column14: s gift will go to fund needed capital improvements to restore, rejuvenate, and enhance additional areas of Central Park. Two important projects include the restoration of the North Woods &mdash
column15: an unbelievable area filled with trees, streams, waterfalls, bridges, fields and scenic walkways that has been hidden from New York for decades, and the landscaping surrounding Merchant&rsquo
column16: s Gate in the Southwest corner of Central Park. That landscape is home to the Park&rsquo
column17: s most visited entrance and should reflect the beauty and quality of the Park&rsquo
column18: s entire 843 acres. Also included are refurbishment of playgrounds, capital projects in the Conservatory Garden, Tennis House Landscaping, continued improvement of the Ramble, bathroom restoration improvements and many other projects, large and small.

column13: >Thirdly, of all of New York City&rsquo
column14: s great cultural institutions, I believe Central Park is the most democratic. It&rsquo
column15: s open to people of all ages, income levels, race, religion and nationality. It&rsquo
column16: s open every day and all day. It&rsquo
column17: s enjoyed by millions of New Yorkers every year. And it is free. A contribution to Central Park Conservancy benefits all New Yorkers.

column13: >Lastly, I must admit there is also a bit of selfishness. I enjoy Central Park almost every day, particularly walking, cycling, and running through the Park. My children enjoy the carousel, the zoo, the row boats, and the playgrounds. I&rsquo
column14: m continually amazed at the incredible beauty of the Park and in awe of the work and talent of the Conservancy. And, I&rsquo
column15: m excited at the improvements that this gift will help make. &nbsp

column5: I wish this gift could meet all the capital and operating needs of the Park but it cannot. It&rsquo
column6: s a big space and there is a lot to do. I hope many of you will join me in helping to fund the operating expenses of the Park by becoming Central Park Conservancy members and for those that have the ability, to join me in helping fund capital improvements in the Park.

d also like to make a gift to everyone here of a book by Sara Cedar Miller entitled Central Park: An American Masterpiece. This is a beautiful book that fully captures the essence of Central Park in both its photos and its writings.

column5: I want to close with a quote from Olmsted and Vaux, the architects of the Park, written 150 years ago: &lsquo
column6: The primary purpose of the Park is to provide the best practicable means of healthful recreation for the inhabitants of the city, of all classes. It should have an aspect of spaciousness and tranquility, with variety of intricacy and arrangement, thereby affording the most agreeable contrast to the confinement, bustle and monotonous street division of the city&hellip
column7: The Park is intended to furnish healthful recreation for the poor and the rich, the young and the old, the vicious and the virtuous, so far as each can partake therein without infringing on the rights of others, and no further.&rsquo

column5: If they were living today, I think they would be thrilled that their 150-year-old creation is alive and well, every bit and more as the day it was created. It is my hope that today&rsquo
column6: s gift will ensure that all of us will be enjoying Central Park for many more years to come.&rdquo

column1: Central to Spring - Cocktails on the Park

There's no better place to welcome spring to New York City than in Central Park. So the Central Park Conservancy and our Ambassador hosts invite you to join us in honoring the season's gorgeous blooms and green meadows with a Park-wide toast to spring.
Cocktails parties will be taking in place in buildings all along the perimeter to show its residents' combined support.

Believe it or not, we estimate that only 15% of households in Park perimeter buildings are current supporters of the Central Park Conservancy. Building participation rates run the gamut, ranging from 0% to 70%. Click to find your building and RSVP today, and learn about the role you and your neighbors are playing in caring for YOUR Park.
Don't see your building listed? Contact Jordan Jacuzzi at jjacuzzi@centralparknyc.org to get more information about becoming an Ambassador host.

Conservancy staff is continuing its work following Hurricane Sandy. We currently estimate that more than 800 were destroyed or damaged by the storm. There has also been damage to the Park's benches, fencing and ballfield equipment. Conservancy staff has worked with twelve teams of contractors, paid for and supervised by the Conservancy, to expedite restoration of the Park.
For the latest updates, follow us on Facebook or Twitter.
Repairs to Central Park are possible thanks to the support of our members. We truly thank those who support us.

Believe it or not, only 15 percent of households in buildings along the Park are current donors to the Conservancy. That'
column2:
s why on this one special evening we are encouraging our friends in Park perimeter buildings to simultaneously host cocktail parties in their homes or building common areas to encourage an increase in support to at least 50% among our neighbors.

With a current annual budget of $45.8 million required for the Conservancy to care for the Park'

s 843 acres 85 percent of which we must raise from private sources our continued success in maintaining this historic, green treasure will depend upon galvanizing those who benefit from the Park every day.

Want to help support your Park? Become a host today and help us spread the word about the work of the Central Park Conservancy to your friends and residents in your building.

column1: The Central Park Conservancy has multiple levels of membership
column4: enjoy discounts at participating restaurants, hotels, spas and fitness centers and cultural institutions through our Central Park Perks Program. Members also have access to early registration and
column5: special giveaways at select public events
column10: yoga, summer chess and youth hockey
column11: and access to members-only content on the web, such as our Bloom Guide. With your membership, the Central Park Conservancy
column12: can continue to preserve everything you enjoy about&nbsp
column13: the Park and help us keep it&nbsp

column2: by becoming a Conservancy member or renewing your membership today.

>Individual Membership
From our Gardener level membership all the way up to major giving, the Central Park Conservancy has an individual
column3: membership to fit nearly any donor.

column2:
>Give a Gift Membership
Show you share a mutual love of Central Park with someone you care about by celebrating a holiday or special occasion with a gift membership to the Central Park Conservancy. The person you give the membership to will immediately receive a personalized
e-card - created by you - informing them of their gift membership, though the amount of the gift will not be disclosed.

>Family Membership
Central Park is made for families. Family membership includes membership for two adults and two children. Benefits include invitations to events among others. Join or renew today.

>Greensward Circle
We have made recruiting the next generation of Central Park supporters a top priority. The Greensward Circle is designed to increase support and awareness among the City's young professionals aged 21-39, while offering a unique opportunity to deepen their relationship with the Conservancy and become the next generation of Central Park's visionaries.

Join the Conservancy in celebrating the beauty of Central Park in spring!
Residents in buildings surrounding Central Park will gather to toast the season's gorgeous blooms and green meadows.
Be central to the Park by joining fellow residents and neighbors this spring!
For event questions please send an email to jjacuzzi@centralparknyc.org or call 212-446-2241.
Believe it or not, only 15 percent of households in buildings near the Park are current donors to the Conservancy.
That's why on this one special evening we
are encouraging our friends in Park perimeter buildings to simultaneously celebrate the Central Park Conservancy and help increase support (to at least 50 percent) among our neighbors.
With a current annual budget of $45.8 million required for the Conservancy to care for the Park's 843 acres &ndash
column2: 85 percent of which we must raise from private sources &ndash
column3: our continued success in maintaining this historic, green treasure will depend upon galvanizing those who benefit from the Park every day.

column1: Want to help support your Park? Join your friends and neighbors in raising funds and awareness on behalf of the Central Park Conservancy.

Come Party in Your Playground! On Wednesday, May 22, 2013, from 3:30pm-6:30pm, the Playground Partners of the Women&rsquo
column2: s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, hosts its Annual Playground Party at Heckscher Playground, inside the Park at Central

column1: Park South and 7th Avenue. The event is a family-friendly fundraiser with activities geared toward children six months to 10 years of age:
• A baseball activity hosted by Bulldog Baseball

column2: delicious buffet featuring many sweets and treats

column1: • A performance by the stars of the Broadway musical ""Rodgers + Hammerstein's CINDERELLA""
• Air Track and obstacle course from The Little Gym
• A soccer relay by Super Soccer Stars and Kick & Play

column2: Adelina Wong Ettelson, Jennifer Evans, Nina Garcia, Sarah Kurita, Jill Ross, and Sharon Teles

column1: Playground Partners Committee Chairmen: Nyssa Kourakos and Yesim Philip
The Playground Party is held rain or shine. Proceeds from the event help keep the Park's 21 playgrounds clean, safe, and well-maintained.

column4: >I would like to become a Playground Patron or renew my Patron Membership.

column1: (In addition to/instead of my ticket purchase for the party.)

column1: Evening in the Garden,evening-in-the-garden-2013.html,"<div class=""templateComponent"" id=""image-395044110"" style=""margin-bottom: 15px

The Greensward Circle, the Central Park Conservancy's junior committee, presents the 8th annual summer benefit, Evening in the Garden. This social calendar staple takes places in one of New York's most exclusive venues, the Conservatory Garden, located inside Central Park at Fifth Avenue and East 105th Street.

Wednesday, June 26
6:30 pm - 8:30 pm
The Conservatory Garden
(Inside the Park at Fifth Avenue and East 105th Street)
Attendees enjoy two hours of great food, cocktails and live music by Leroy Justice
column2: on the garden's pergola beneath a canopy of wisteria and overlooking six acres of gorgeous foundations, blooms and lush landscapes.

column1: This event is mainly attended by New York's socially active young professionals between the ages of 21 and 39. Tickets will be available for $100 at the door. Tickets are nonrefundable and you must be 21 to attend.

</center>","The Greensward Circle of the Central Park Conservancy presents Evening in the Garden, the highly anticipated annual summer kick-off in enchanting Conservatory Garden. Terms and Conditions for Central Play Memories,terms-and-conditions.html,"

Submissions made to the Conservancy may be published on the Conservancy's website, Facebook page, and Twitter account, as well as in print and digital formats of any kind whatsoever, and in any and all other types of media, whether currently known, or hereafter devised. Submissions made to the Conservancy may be edited, modified, published, removed, transmitted, and/or displayed by the Conservancy, and you waive any rights you may have in having the material altered or changed in a manner not agreeable to you.

You grant the Conservancy a perpetual, nonexclusive, world-wide, royalty free, sub-licensable license to use the Submissions, which includes, without limitation, the right of the Conservancy, or any third party it designates, to use, copy, transmit, excerpt, publish, distribute, publicly display, publicly perform, create derivative works of, host, index, cache, tag, encode, modify and adapt (including without limitation the right to adapt to streaming, downloading, broadcast, mobile, digital, thumbnail, scanning or other technologies) in any form or media now known or hereinafter developed, any Submission posted by you on or to any site owned by the Conservancy, including any Submission posted through a third party. You understand that you will not receive compensation for any use of the Submissions, and will not be given notice of if and/or when the Submissions may be used.

You are solely responsible for the content of your Submissions. However, the Conservancy reserves the right, in its sole discretion, to reject, delete, move, or edit Submissions that it deems abusive, defamatory, obscene, profane, lewd, or that are in violation of copyright or trademark laws, or are otherwise unacceptable.

",Terms and Conditions for Central Play Memories.,dblondell@centralparknyc.org,"Jan 29, 2013 12:06 PM CST",/central-play/,Full Body Section (NO right margin),TRUE,Printer Friendly,,none,no,,,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation",,,,,,,,

Release for Central Play Memories,release-for-central-play.html,"

For good and valuable consideration, the receipt and legal sufficiency of which is hereby acknowledged, I, on behalf of myself and each other individual portrayed or otherwise featured in the Submission(s) (as defined below) (each, a ""Subject""), hereby irrevocably and in perpetuity permit and grant to the Central Park Conservancy, Inc. (the ""Conservancy"") (including any third party that it designates) the perpetual, nonexclusive, world-wide, royalty free, sub-licensable right and license (but not the obligation) to use, reproduce, perform, distribute, display, prepare derivative works of, license, syndicate and otherwise exploit (i) the photographs, videos, stories, songs, audio recordings and other content posted or otherwise submitted by me on or to any website owned or operated by the Conservancy, including through a third party (each, a ""Submission"")
column2: and (ii) my name, voice, biographical information and likeliness (the items listed under (i) and (ii), hereinafter collectively referred to as the ""Media"") for any lawful purpose as the Conservancy (any third party that it designates) deems fit, in any manner and in any form, medium or forum (including, without limitation, the right to publish the Media on the Conservancy's website, Facebook page, and Twitter account, as well as in print and digital formats of any kind whatsoever and to adapt the Media to streaming, downloading, broadcast, mobile, digital, thumbnail, scanning or other technologies), whether now know or hereafter devised.

column1: I hereby acknowledge and agree that (i) I am responsible for the content of my Submission(s)
column2: (ii) my Submission(s) may be edited, modified, published, removed, transmitted, and/or displayed by the Conservancy in its sole discretion
column3: (iii) the Conservancy reserves the right, in its sole discretion, to reject, delete, move, or edit Submissions or other Media that it deems abusive, defamatory, obscene, profane, lewd, or that are in violation of copyright or trademark laws, or are otherwise unacceptable
column4: and (iv) to protect my (or any other Subject's) privacy, the Conservancy has the right to change my name or initials in association with the use of the Submission(s) or other Media.

column1: I, on behalf of myself and each Subject, hereby waive all rights, if any, to (a) inspect, review or approve the form or manner in which the Submission(s) or other Media are used
column2: (b) receive any compensation for use of the Submission(s) or other Media, or (c) be given notice of if and/or when the Submission(s) or other Media may be used.

column1: I, on behalf of myself and each Subject, hereby release Conservancy (including any third party that it designates), and each of their respective directors, officers, employees and agents from any privacy, defamation, publicity, infringement or other claim that I may have against them arising out of their use, publication, distribution or other exploitation of the Submission(s) or other Media, all as further described above.

I, on behalf of myself and each Subject, hereby release, discharge and agree to save harmless the Conservancy (including any third party that it designates), and each of their respective directors, officers, employees and agents and all persons acting under their authority or for whom they are acting, from any liability by virtue of any use or publication of the Submission(s) or other Media.

This Release shall be binding upon me, each Subject, and our family, heirs, personal representatives, agents, successors, assigns, and shall be governed by and construed under the laws of the State of New York, which shall be the venue for any legal action. This Release constitutes the entire agreement between me and the Conservancy with respect to the use of the Submission(s) and other Media and supersedes any and all such previous agreements relating to the subject matter hereof, whether written or oral.
I hereby represent and warrant that (i) I am 18 years old or older and have every right to enter into this Release
column2: and (ii) I have obtained a signed, written release consistent with the terms hereof from all other Subjects.

column1: I confirm that I have completely read the foregoing or it has been read and translated to me in my native language, understand its contents, and have voluntarily signed this Release. To the extent that the Submission(s) portrays or features any other Subject, I confirm that each such Subject has completely read the foregoing or it has been read and translated to such Subject in his/her native language, such Subject understand its contents, and have voluntarily agreed that I may sign this Release on behalf of such Subject.

Parent/Guardian Consent
I am the parent or legal guardian of each minor who is portrayed or otherwise featured in the Submission(s) or other Media. I have the legal right to consent, and do hereby consent, to the terms and conditions of this Release

",Release for Central Play Memories,dblondell@centralparknyc.org,"Jan 29, 2013 12:14 PM CST",/central-play/,Full Body Section (NO right margin),TRUE,Printer Friendly,,none,no,,,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation",,,,,,,,

Taste of Summer 2013,taste-of-summer-2013.html,"

Join us for Taste of Summer!

Taste of Summer will be held rain or shine. The event is accessible by taxi and vehicle or by foot by entering Central Park at 72nd Street and Fifth Avenue. For more information, please contact 212-310-6600.

.-->

This event features culinary delights prepared by renowned New York chefs, a luxury-filled silence auction and music by one of the City's hottest DJs. Held at the iconic Bethesda Terrace, this annual benefit for Central Park Conservancy brings together visionaries in support of its mission to restore and maintain the Park.
column2: , available exclusively to table buyers, will be hosted by Crown Group Hospitality featuring food from Crown, The Lion and recently launched Bill's Food &
column3: Drink. Don't miss out on this annual kick-off to summer!

column1:
The Taste of Summer online auction is now closed. For those who have already placed a bid, a CPC representative will contact you by Friday, June 21 if you are the winner of a featured online auction lot. For any questions regarding the Silent Auction, please e-mail eventconsultant@centralparknyc.org.

-->
2013 Trustee Chairmen: Jay Mandelbaum, Gillian Miniter, John Paulson, and Norman Selby
Spirits generously donated by William Grant & Sons.

Central to Spring Landing Page,index.html,"<!-- Central to Spring - 1 - Landing Page - v6 - 14 March 2013 -->
background: url(""http://cpc.convio.net/images/content/pagebuilder/nav-bg-flip.jpg"") no-repeat scroll center bottom transparent
<!-- the first div is unnecessary in production, as its function will be covered by the #contain div -->
In April 2013, residents in buildings surrounding the Park gathered to toast the season's gorgeous blooms and green meadows.
Together they celebrated spring and enjoyed a spectacular fireworks display in Central Park, while garnering support for the Central Park Conservancy.
You can be central to the Park by joining fellow residents and neighbors as a host in spring 2015. Take a look at the map below to see residences and corporate locations of our Ambassador hosts!
For event questions please send an email to jjacuzzi@centralparknyc.org or call 212-446-2241.

column14: text-align:left"">Central to Spring - April 10, 2013 in a larger map

column1: The Conservancy has set a goal to increase the percentage of current supporters in buildings near the Park.
That's why on this one special evening we
are encouraging our friends and neighbors in Park perimeter buildings to simultaneously celebrate spring in Central Park and help increase support of the Central Park Conservancy.
With a current annual budget of $58.3 million required for the Conservancy to care for the Park's 843 acres &ndash
column2: the majority of which we must raise from private sources &ndash
column3: our continued success in maintaining this historic, green treasure will depend upon galvanizing those who benefit from the Park every day.

column1: Want to help support your Park? Join your friends and neighbors in raising funds and awareness on behalf of the Central Park Conservancy.

As a special thank you for being a member of the Conservancy, we're offering you our exclusive Central Park Conservancy Bloom Guide! With our Bloom Guide, you can have an insider's look at the Park's most gorgeous landscapes and unique blooms, every day of the week.

Below you'll see a Google map of 22 different bloom sites. To find out more about each location, click on the green icon shown on the map. For a list of the beautiful blooms you'll be able to see at that site, click the location's name. From there, you'll find a list of blooms and their bloom dates.
We'll add to our Bloom Guide season after season, so don't forget to come back in a few months to see some stunning new fall blooms!

Central Park Circuit,central-park-circuit.html,"

The Conservancy's biweekly Central Park Circuit helps New Yorkers get fit, for free! The Circuit runs on Tuesdays and Thursdays from May 14 - June 20 (Session 1) and from July 9 - August 15 (Session 2). Tuesday classes meet at the Great Lawn
column2: at Delacorte Theater inside the Park at West 81st Street and
column3: Thursday classes meet at the Great Hill. Classes begin at 6:30 pm.
column4: Using Park resources such as boulders, trails, stairs, hills and lawns, certified personal trainers Richard Fortunat and Whitney Jacobs inspire New Yorkers to explore Central Park's beauty while getting in shape. Class size is limited to 20 participants. Conservancy members can reserve a space by presenting their membership card at the class
column5: non-members can join onsite or below to take advantage of this perk.

column1: Take advantage of all of the Park's resources by using the Central Park Circuit Official Workout, a guide to exercises that use benches, stairs, lawns, trails and more.
Every good workout begins with a warm-up. In this video, our trainers, Rich Fortunat and Whitney Jacobs teach you how to do the inch worm.
The moves in this video will help your body build more muscle, which in turn helps you metabolize more fat. You'll learn how to do clapping push-ups and the step-up jump.
Cardio exercise is an important part of any exercise routine. Here, Whitney and Rich talk about how even beginners can incorporate interval training into their workouts.
Don't forget to cool down! This video will teach you just one of the stretches covered in the Central Park Circuit classes.

","The Central Park Conservancy's Central Park Circuit fitness program inspires and enables New Yorkers to use Central Park to reach their fitness goals by using the Park's best natural resources: rocks, trails, stairs, hills and gorgeous open spaces. Celebrate Autumn in the Park with the Conservancy!

The Central Park Conservancy invites supporters to celebrate Autumn in Central Park for our annual event in November. Enjoy dinner and dancing under a clear-ceiling tent in the Park, with a beautiful nighttime view of the tree canopy and stars up above. Over five hundred guests are expected to come out in celebration of New York City&rsquo
column2: s most treasured green space. Most importantly, the event will raise vital funds that benefit the Conservancy's mission to restore and maintain the Park.

column1: 2012 Event Chairmen: Kitty and Tom Kempner
For more information, contact the Special Events department at

or 212-446-2242.

Nearly 2,000 lovers of Central Park braved a last-minute rainstorm to enjoy fireworks at Bethesda Terrace for Central to Spring on April 10. Conservancy staff members kept the area clean and greeted visitors, letting them know what it takes get the Park ready for spring, including planting 57,000 flowers and shrubs, mowing 250 acres of lawn, and laying 850 tons of mulch on flower beds. The City Bakery served cookies and delicious springtime refreshments. In midtown, the Empire State Building was lit up in Conservancy green to celebrate Central to Spring.
Thanks to everyone who came out to Central to Spring! If you missed it, check out the slideshow above.
You can be Central to Spring as well as summer, fall, and winter by becoming a member of the Central Park Conservancy today.

Nearly 2,000 lovers of Central Park braved a last-minute rainstorm to enjoy fireworks at Bethesda Terrace for Central to Spring on April 10. Conservancy staff members kept the area clean and greeted visitors, letting them know what it takes get the Park ready for spring, including planting 57,000 flowers and shrubs, mowing 250 acres of lawn, and laying 850 tons of mulch on flower beds. The City Bakery served cookies and delicious springtime refreshments. In midtown, the Empire State Building was lit up in Conservancy green to celebrate Central to Spring.
Thanks to everyone who came out to Central to Spring! If you missed it, check out the slideshow above.
You can be Central to Spring as well as summer, fall, and winter by becoming a member of the Central Park Conservancy today.

column5:
>With Your Help, a Cleaner,
Greener Central Park

column1: The Central Park Conservancy is always developing innovative ways to improve your experience in the Park. We're launching a new trash management system that will reduce rats, result in fewer vehicles on paths, and increase recycling. Here's how:
• Strategic removal and relocation of cans, resulting in fewer rats in Central Park.
• This strategic placement of fewer can locations means fewer pickup vehicles on paths, and a safer Park for children and pets.
• Installation of more recycling cans, leading to a projected 30 percent increase in recycling in the Park.

The Conservancy is introducing 700 newly designed trash and recycling cans to the Park. Made from partially recycled aluminum donated by Alcoa Inc., these cans are more durable than the plastic ones you're used to and their one-of-a-kind design was inspired by the slats of the Park's iconic benches! This new trash strategy was made possible by the Alcoa Foundation, which generously donated $500,000 toward its development, and Landor Associates, who custom-designed the new trash cans.
Visitors like you will be our most important partners in making this new plan a success. With your help, the Park will be cleaner and more sustainable than ever.

</body>",Trash Management,cperez@centralparknyc.org,"Apr 17, 2013 02:57 PM CDT",/visit/general-info/trash/,Full Body Lightbox,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Central Park, New York, parks, recreation, care, trash, recycle",,,,,,,,

column4:
/>Nyssa Kourakos and Yesim Philip, Co-Chairs
The essential mission of Central Park Playground Partners is to consistently improve our 21 beloved playgrounds, and maintain their overall quality. Our playgrounds embody the highest standards of safety, innovation, and creativity, but these standards cannot be sustained without donations like yours.
column5: 1300.donation=form1"">Being a Playground Partner is a wonderful way to directly engage in your community of families and neighbors. We seek to promote stewardship and environmentalism throughout the Park, bringing unique opportunities for camaraderie and friendship for you and your children. The funds we receive go directly towards the preservation, care, and daily inspection of these cherished play spaces. With your generosity, our Playgrounds can continue to enrich the quality of life for present and future generations of children and be an essential part of a healthy childhood for all families living in New York City.

column1: PGP TOTS is a subcommittee of the Playground Partners specifically for moms with children under three years old. PGP TOTS offers moms the opportunity to network, share resources, and discover all that Central Park has to offer its youngest visitors through informal gatherings such as play dates, stroller walks, and informational lectures.
For more information about Playground Partners and/or PGP TOTS, please call 212.310.6655 or email playgrounds@centralparknyc.org.

</center>","The Playground Partners was formed to keep the Park's play areas clean, safe and well-maintained. All donations to the program goes toward the care and maintenance of Central Park's playgrounds.",devnull@convio.com,"Oct 01, 2009 04:36 PM CDT",/test/,Section page,TRUE,Default wrapper test,,kids-family-activities,no,,,"playground, kids, children, donate, donation",,"/about/womens-committee/playground-captains.html,/about/womens-committee/womens-committee.html",,,"/assets/images/slides/donation-slides/playground-partners/pgp1-l.jpg,/assets/images/slides/donation-slides/playground-partners/pgp2-l.jpg,/assets/images/slides/donation-slides/playground-partners/pgp3-l.jpg,/assets/images/slides/donation-slides/playground-partners/pgp4-l.jpg,/assets/images/slides/donation-slides/playground-partners/pgp5-l.jpg",,,

Join the Conservancy in celebrating the beauty of Central Park in spring!
Residents in buildings surrounding Central Park will gather to toast the season's gorgeous blooms and green meadows.
Be central to the Park by joining fellow residents and neighbors this spring!
Believe it or not, only 15 percent of households in buildings near the Park are current donors to the Conservancy.
That's why on this one special evening we
are encouraging our friends in Park perimeter buildings to simultaneously celebrate the Central Park Conservancy and help increase support (to at least 50 percent) among our neighbors.
With a current annual budget of $45.8 million required for the Conservancy to care for the Park's 843 acres &ndash
column2: 85 percent of which we must raise from private sources &ndash
column3: our continued success in maintaining this historic, green treasure will depend upon galvanizing those who benefit from the Park every day.

column1: Want to help support your Park? Join your friends and neighbors in raising funds and awareness on behalf of the Central Park Conservancy.
For event questions please send an email to jjacuzzi@centralparknyc.org or call 212-446-2241.

All members of the Central Park Conservancy receive complimentary admission to up to 4 sessions of our members-only programs throughout the year. Family and dual Greensward level memberships include admission for one additional person. If you are not yet a member, we reserve a limited number of spaces for new members that sign-up the day of the event.

If you are a member and would like to register for one of the programs in the calendar below, simply select the event and complete the online registration process. If you are not yet a member of the Conservancy, you can become one online.
Visit the Park's extensive woodlands on these intimate, members-only tours led by the Conservancy's Woodland Zone Gardeners. Advance registration required. For questions, call

column2: >People's Park, People's Choice: Vote for Your Favorite Movies!

column1: Central Park is known as the ""People's Park"" &mdash
column2: so this year, the people will choose which movies are screened each night of the Conservancy Film Festival!

column1: Each of the festival's five nights features a different movie genre. Vote for your favorites below, then get friends to rally for your movie choice by sharing your vote on Facebook or Twitter. Voting will end June 23, 2013.

The Central Park Conservancy Film Festival is free to attend, thanks to founding sponsor Bloomberg. The festival is held in the landscape between Sheep Meadow and the 72nd Street Cross Drive. Gates open at 6:30 pm, and movies begin at 8:00 pm.

column1: Each of the festival's five nights features a different movie genre. Vote for your favorites below, then get friends to rally for your movie choice by sharing your vote on Facebook or Twitter. Voting will end June 23, 2013.

The Central Park Conservancy Film Festival is free to attend, thanks to founding sponsor Bloomberg. The festival is held in the landscape between Sheep Meadow and the 72nd Street Cross Drive. Gates open at 6:30 pm, and movies begin at 8:00 pm.

Reporting to the President, Mr. Nolan has primary responsibility for the leadership of the organization&rsquo
column2: s physical planning effort and the execution of its restoration / renovation program.

column1: His responsibilities include providing leadership and direction for: all physical planning, project development, public and regulatory approvals, project design and construction, and project management and administration. He is responsible for establishing and maintaining departmental and project controls and is the principal contract officer on contracts for the renovation, restoration and operations program.
Mr. Nolan collaborates with the President and other Vice Presidents to develop the organization&rsquo
column2: s strategic and operational objectives, and as a corporate officer, works directly with the Board of Trustees on committees including the Park & Visitor Experience, Strategic Planning, and other committees, as required.

column1: Mr. Nolan works with the President and senior management team to develop strategic goals and operational objectives, providing input grounded in the historic context, design appropriateness, technical feasibility, and public approval and regulatory framework.  He leads the physical planning efforts to develop short and long term plans for restoration and renovation programs that are consistent with the Conservancy&rsquo

Mr. Nolan implements the corporate mission statement as it relates to the work of his division. He collaborates with senior management peers to ensure all planning, design, and construction efforts support the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s strategic objectives and operational needs.

column1: Mr. Nolan oversees the preparation of annual and multi- year program budgets and monitors efficiency and the progress of work. He provides the Board, President and peers on the senior management team with information required to report on and assess the performance of planning, restoration and renovation programs.

Mr. Nolan negotiates consultant and construction contracts, executes contracts within authorized limits, oversees all contract administration, negotiation and authorization of change orders, and authorization of contract payments. He negotiates and administers publicly funded contracts with the City of New York.

Mr. Nolan provides leadership and direction to program and project planning, establishes restoration and design goals, and ensures that the goals are met. In addition to the planned program of work, he directs repair and restoration efforts in response to unanticipated events that impact Park landscapes and infrastructure. He is responsible for the design, technical quality, production, management, and overall efficiency of restoration and construction projects, and conservation of the Park&rsquo
column2: s monuments and architectural/decorative features. Mr. Nolan develops and implements effective systems for work planning and financial control to ensure that the division and its projects operate within the approved budgets and financial policies. He strives continually to ensure that work is completed on time and within the allocated budget, reporting to the Board, President, and peers on the senior management team as appropriate when unanticipated circumstances impact project budgets and schedules.

column1: Mr. Nolan directs internal and external communications related to outreach efforts for securing community support and regulatory approvals. He acts as the primary organizational contact for public and regulatory agencies, and represents the organization&rsquo
column2: s interests at public hearings. He monitors proposed and current laws, ordinances, and regulations that affect or might affect the organization. Mr. Nolan develops effective relationships and alliances with community groups, public agencies, and professional organizations. He takes action required to maintain and enhance the organization&rsquo
column3: s reputation for excellence in design, preservation, restoration and management.

column1: Mr. Nolan collaborates with the President and other Vice Presidents in development efforts to ensure the organization achieves its funding goals. He develops program and project proposals that are consistent with the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s long-range objectives and support the organization&rsquo
column3: s funding model. He participates in development and fundraising activities in order to represent the organization&rsquo
column4: s goals, capabilities, and track record in restoring the Park, thereby helping to secure the confidence and commitment of donors and ensure that funding goals are met.

column1: Since joining the Conservancy in 1989, Mr. Nolan has successfully managed over $75 million in capital improvements, including the restoration of the Bethesda Terrace Minton Tile Ceiling, Literary Walk, the Reservoir Fence, the 59th Street Pond, and the Great Lawn. Many of these projects have received national and local awards for construction, design, and preservation.

column2: s degree in Landscape Architecture from Cornell University. He is a registered landscape architect in New York State.

column1: ,Vice President for Planning, Design and Construction

,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,Nov 06, 2009 09:49 AM CST",/about/inside-the-conservancy/management-board/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Christopher Nolan, Vice President, Planning, Design, Construction, leadership",,,,,,,,

Reporting to and partnering with the President, Mr. Calvanese oversees and develops all operational strategy for Central Park, and ensures that the Conservancy is fulfilling its contractual obligations to the City of New York. He is responsible for oversight of daily Park operations, including horticulture, special events and Conservancy relations with the Department of Parks and Recreation, the NYPD, Department of Transportation, and Department of Environmental Protection, staffing, staff development and training. Partnering with Department of Parks and Recreation, he develops an annual plan for special events that take place in the Park for the purpose of minimizing their impact on the landscape. He is responsible for developing strategy for adopting and applying the most advanced technology in pest control practices. He oversees the field volunteers programs, including training and utilization.

As a member of the senior management team, Mr. Calvanese partners with leaders in Planning, Design and Construction to develop the strategic planning of major renovations, restorations, and other projects in the Park, and works directly with the Chief of Operations to review, analyze and develop an annual budget and long-term budget plans.

Mr. Calvanese develops and oversees the annual operations budget. He also develops and oversees long-term budgetary planning and cost management in alignment with the Operations budget and the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s strategic plan. He participates in the ongoing strategic planning process as an integral member of the senior management team.

column1: Mr. Calvanese oversees the development and maintenance of the volunteer program. He provides guidance towards the goal of a continued strong volunteer base for operations.

Mr. Calvanese works closely with the NYC Department of Parks and Recreation, the NYPD, and Urban Park Service regarding safety and enforcement needs in the Park. He plans and implements strategies for ensuring special events have minimal impact on landscapes. He engages with a variety of Park user groups and governmental entities.
Working closely with the Chief of Operations, Mr. Calvanese oversees the development and execution of all horticultural and environmental design and maintenance plans.

Mr. Calvanese works with the Development team to stay informed of donor expectations and develop plans to meet commitments arising from donor relationships. He participates in fundraising as needed and supports Development efforts for long-term funding and project development.

Mr. Calvanese works closely with the Chief of Operations and directors to make sure all staff are well informed about and compliant with expectations set forth in the Employee Handbook and all Conservancy policies. He manages and oversees all operations activities to ensure compliance with the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s contract with the City. He keeps the Chief of Operations and Directors aware of compliance obligations in contracts, most significantly, the Park Inspection Program. Mr. Calvanese also negotiates and oversees all contracts with third parties engaged to perform maintenance services in the Park.

column1: Mr. Calvanese develops operation plans for the long- range sustainability of new landscapes. He identifies current Park uses and develops appropriate landscape plans. He oversees Operations staff support of, and works with, Planning, Design and Construction for the planning and implementation of capital work.

Mr. Calvanese has worked in Central Park since 1981, when he started as a climber with the tree crew. Since then, he has held the positions of Tree Care Coordinator, Deputy Director of Horticulture, Director of Horticulture, Deputy Chief of Operations, and Chief of Operations. Having worked with the Conservancy in its early days, and through many of its ambitious restoration projects, Mr. Calvanese has played an active role in Central Park&rsquo

column2: s Degree in Biology from Arkansas College as well as an Associate&rsquo
column3: s Degree in Arboriculture from SUNY Farmingdale

column1: ,Vice President for Operations,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,Nov 06, 2009 09:49 AM CST",/about/inside-the-conservancy/management-board/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Neil Calvanese, Vice President, Operations, leadership",,,,,,,,
Reporting to the President and partnering with the other Vice Presidents, Ms. Hall is responsible for the management, strategic planning, financials, marketing, and future growth of the Women&rsquo
column2: s Committee and the Special Events department including:
s Commi ttee Board and Advisory Board

column1: • The Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon fundraiser
• The Playground Partners Annual Party in Your Playground and Winter Lunch fundraisers
Partner and work closely with the Women&rsquo
column2: s Committee President, Executive Committee, Board of Directors, Committee Chairmen, and Volunteers

column1: Ms. Hall provides leadership, support, and guidance to 45 Women&rsquo
column2: s Committee Board members and over 150 volunteers. She fosters and encourages financial support from these individuals, and promotes the mission and priorities of the Conservancy.
s Committee standing committees and events

column1: Ms. Hall works with staff to ensure the success and growth of each committee and event. She strategizes on ways to keep these events and committees current and relative.
Ms. Hall oversees the Special Events department which organizes the Autumn in Central Park dinner dance, Taste of Summer, the Film Festival as well as dedications and cultivation events.
Increase the number of supporters of the Conservancy

Ms. Hall gains supporters through events, personalized mailings, and social press. She creates a sense of community to encourage prospects to get involved and financially support the Conservancy. She seeks new partnerships with small businesses and corporations.

Ms. Hall has an extensive background in fundraising and special event planning. Prior to joining the staff at Central Park Conservancy in 2007, she was Executive Director of The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering. She also ran her own consulting firm and planned many of New York&rsquo
Ms. Hall was raised in Manhattan and graduated from the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill. She currently resides in Connecticut.

,Vice President for Development, Women's Committee and Special Events",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Nov 06, 2009 09:49 AM CST",/about/inside-the-conservancy/management-board/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Laura Hall, Vice President, Development, Womens Committee,  leadership",,,,,,,,

Reporting to and partnering with the President, Mr. LoCastro works closely with the Vice President for Operations and other members of the Conservancy leadership team to develop and implement a series of strategic initiatives related to the Conservancy&rsquo

Mr. LoCastro collaborates to organize and direct all daily operations for Central Park and is responsible for the overall administration and business performance of Operations, Horticulture, Technical Services, Volunteer and Visitor Services Departments.

column2: s senior management team, Mr. LoCastro partners with leaders in Planning Design and Construction to review all planned renovations, restorations and capital projects being considered for Central Park, in order that maintenance protocols, staffing plans and budgets may be developed to provide for the proper care and upkeep all newly created spaces and landscapes in the Park.

column1: Mr. LoCastro acts as a strategic partner with the President and CFO in the planning, design and implementation of systems, processes and procedures in a proactive fashion. He establishes annual operating budgets for the Park in accordance with the established standards of the Conservancy. He assesses Park-based staffing levels and organizational structure on an ongoing basis to assure alignment with Conservancy goals and objectives.

Mr. LoCastro handles corporate managerial functions concurrent with Park-based operational management, focusing on the disciplines of risk management, occupational health & safety, procurement, managing to budget, documenting / recording of all operations activities, development of policies and procedures and making recommendations for required systems support.
Mr. LoCastro collaborates with the Vice President for Operations, Chief of Operations and all site management personnel to strategically develop and implement an operational plan for the Park &mdash
column2: a plan that maintains the Park in the best possible fashion, operates within approved budgetary parameters, is sustainable and supports the long-range strategic vision of the Conservancy.

column1: Along with the Vice President for Operations and Vice President for Planning Design & Construction, Mr. LoCastro reviews all planned capital projects for Central Park for the purpose of developing an integrated, programmatic transition process between departments as capital projects near completion. He leads a process that prepares the Operations Department to properly staff and maintain newly constructed landscapes and spaces throughout the Park. He develops a systematic process that provides for the sharing of all construction related documents such as: site plans, equipment specifications, maintenance manuals, warranties, etc. In collaboration with the Vice President for Planning Design & Construction, he routinely performs reviews of Capital Projects that aid in the creation of appropriate levels of preventive maintenance in Central Park.

Mr. LoCastro works to foster a collaborative partnership between Development and Operations, one that provides a support apparatus which enhances and strengthens our responsibilities to existing donors, as well provides a platform from which new donor relationships may be built. He participates in all fundraising and development efforts as required. He documents and reviews any suggestions and recommendations that may improve and/or strengthen development efforts.
Mr. LoCastro collaborates with the President, CFO and other Vice Presidents in an effort to achieve the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s goals and objects for fundraising, as well the fulfillment of its mission.

column1: Mr. LoCastro joined the Conservancy in May of 2011 in this newly created position. Prior to joining the Conservancy, Mr. LoCastro has managed systems, technology, large scale facilities and construction projects in both the private sector and higher education.

column2: s Degree in Real Estate Sciences from New York University.

column1: ,Vice President for Operations Management,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,Nov 06, 2009 09:49 AM CST",/about/inside-the-conservancy/management-board/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Frank LoCastro, Vice President, Operations, Management, Experience, leadership",,,,,,,,
Vice President for Development and Visitor Experience
Reporting to the President and partnering with the other Vice Presidents, the Vice President for
Development and Visitor Experience is responsible for the oversight of all development and communications efforts designed to:
<li>Engage the public in Conservancy activities/communications and
• Convert users and the general public into supporters of the Conservancy
• Develop stewards of Parks through educational programming
Create and institutionalize a comprehensive brand message and voice that will be used organization-wide to increase awareness of the breadth and depth of the Conservancy&rsquo
Insure adherence to brand guidelines while developing new and appropriate opportunities to present the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s message. Work closely with the VP of Philanthropy, Operations, Planning, Design and Construction, Finance and Administration to insure that all areas of the Conservancy are working together to present a unified and cohesive Brand message.

column1: Ongoing communication through various channels such as web site, social media, mail, events and one-on-one meetings/tours are intended to increase the dialogue about the Conservancy and role as Park stewards.
Broaden the group of people who support the Conservancy and its mission through multiple channel such as on-line and text donations, donation boxes and tours/program fess.
Enhance the Visitor Experience and Develop Urban Park Professionals through the Central Park Conservancy Institute for Urban Parks

Through the efforts of the Institute for Urban Parks, programs will be developed to elevate the visitor experience and engage the visitor with the Central Park Conservancy to develop responsibility and respect for Central Park and urban parks, globally.

Additionally, the Institute for Urban Parks will enable us to leverage our leadership position to provide professional development opportunities and create a forum of best practice exchange and information sharing with the goal of keeping the Conservancy at the forefront of urban Park Management know- how and practices.
Engage the corporate community to support the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s efforts through financial and volunteer support. Additionally, work with community partners to help the Conservancy expand its reach to their current and prospective user base.

column1: Explore new revenue sources in an effort to create viable and sustaining annual channels of revenue. The goal is to increase assured revenue for the Conservancy. In addition to growing current in-Park and on-line retails efforts, the Conservancy is engaging in strategic alliances with third parties to diversify its revenue portfolio and uncover new earned revenue opportunities.

Prior to joining the team of the Central Park Conservancy, Ms. Coppersmith spent eight years in museum development for area institutions, including the Whitney Museum. She began her career in advertising. Ms. Coppersmith has a B.S. in Communications from Boston University.

",Vice President for Development and Visitor Experience,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Nov 06, 2009 09:49 AM CST",/about/inside-the-conservancy/management-board/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Terri Coppersmith, Vice President, Development, Visitor Experience, leadership",,,,,,,,

Reporting to the Board of Trustees, Mr. Blonsky directs the overall strategic planning, park operations, capital programming, public programming, development and marketing and communication strategies for the organization. He works with the Board of Trustees on all governance issues, board development and on financial planning and budgeting strategy to ensure a strong stable organization. He is responsible for fostering relationships with donors at all levels, park users, senior Parks Department officials and other public officials. Mr. Blonsky directly supervises area VPs as well as provides leadership to all levels of the organization. As Administrator of the Park, he is directly responsible for all day to day operations and strategic matters concerning all aspects of park maintenance, operations and management.

Mr. Blonsky partners with the Board on all operational and strategic issues as they arise. He provides strategic recommendations to the Board based on the direction from the Strategic Planning Committee. He engages the Committee around issues, trends, and changes that would affect the operational model and delivery of the strategic plan.

Mr. Blonsky partners with the Board, the VP for Design, Planning, and Construction, the VP for Operations, and the senior development team in creating an appropriate capital and operational program that meets the needs of the restoration, management and operation of the Park, while taking advantage of the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s strong fundraising capabilities. He partners with all senior operations managers to increase the use of environmentally friendly and sustainable management, operational and horticultural practices that promote environmental stewardship and best practices, while continuing the high level of maintenance standards that the Conservancy is renowned for. Mr. Blonsky supports and increases the use of technology to create greater efficiencies while increasing standards.

column1: Mr. Blonsky provides leadership, clear vision and mission priorities to the organization. He identifies, retains and develops talented staff, Board members and future leaders of the Conservancy. He creates and implements sound management practices and performance measures that facilitate effective decision- making, a cohesive and effective structure as well as a healthy organizational structure. Mr. Blonsky develops a strong senior management team that is capable of creating and implementing organizational objectives.
He encourages cross-departmental collaboration that supports the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s mission and strategic plan. He provides leadership to all levels of the organization, seeking out and encouraging individuals who exhibit qualities that position them for future organizational leadership. He is continually seeking out and cultivating potential external candidates that exemplify the culture and mission of the Conservancy.

column1: Relationship with the City of New York

Mr. Blonsky develops and manages relationships with the Parks Department and City government (e.g. regulatory agencies / commissions, City Council, etc.) to ensure the public / private partnership between the Conservancy and the City is effective and adaptive to changes in the political landscape. He meets and cultivates relationships with City officials to ensure that the partnership between the City and the Conservancy remains strong, and that the Conservancy is viewed as a leader in the world of public / private partnerships.

Mr. Blonsky has been with the Central Park Conservancy since 1985. He was appointed President in 2004. He is also Central Park Administrator, appointed by the City in 1998 when the Conservancy formalized its partnership with the City of New York by signing the historic management contract.

Mr. Blonsky oversees a staff of more than 250 and over 3,000 volunteers who contribute 52,000 hours of service each year. As a result of the proven track record of the Conservancy in renovation and supervision, the Conservancy assumed responsibility as general contractor and project manager for all Central Park capital projects, including those that are City-funded. Mr. Blonsky has been directly responsible for the effective management of $350 million in capital projects, including a number that have received prestigious design awards.

column2: s leadership, the Conservancy has completed such noteworthy restoration projects as the Great Lawn, the Harlem Meer, the Merchants&rsquo
column3: Gate, the Mall, the Conservatory Water, the Pond, the Pool, and the Reservoir fence. He has developed several innovative Park management and preservation practices, which have set the standard for park management nationwide. The zone management system, for example, divides Central Park into 49 zones, each with a dedicated gardener who provides a uniformed presence and is held accountable for his or her zone. This system creates accountability for cleanliness and productivity improvements throughout the Park. In addition, Mr. Blonsky developed and implemented a program to train and mentor NYC Parks Department gardeners from underserved parks in all five boroughs (Neighborhood Parks Initiative). These individuals are trained by Conservancy staff in Central Park in horticulture, maintenance, and management.

column1: During his tenure, Mr. Blonsky has also managed the operational logistics of some of the largest events in the Park, including The Gates
column4: annual performances by the New York Philharmonic and Metropolitan Opera
column5: concerts by Garth Brooks, Sheryl Crow, Sting, and Dave Matthews
column8: and a Mass given by Pope John Paul II.

column1: A graduate of the University of Delaware and Cook College at Rutgers University, Mr. Blonsky holds Bachelor of Science degrees in both Plant Science and Landscape Architecture, and is a registered landscape architect in New York State.
Vice President for Finance and Administration
Reporting to and partnering with the President & CEO, Mr. Spinelli sets the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s financial policy and direction while also serving as an active participant in and driver of, the organization&rsquo
column3: s overall strategy. He leads all financial administration, business planning, human resources, information technology, and compliance functions. He is responsible for establishing and maintaining internal control, which provide reasonable assurance that the Conservancy assets are safeguarded
column4: all transactions are properly authorized and recorded
column5: and financial statements are free of misstatement and fairly present the financial position of the Conservancy.

column1: As a member of the senior management team, Mr. Spinelli works directly with the Finance, Investment, Audit, Compensation and Management Development, Strategic Planning and Executive Committees of the Board of Trustees.

Mr. Spinelli partners with the President & CEO on all operational and strategic issues as they arise, and provides strategic recommendations to the President based on financial analysis and projections, cost identification and allocation, and revenue/expense analysis. He participates in the ongoing strategic planning process as an integral member of the senior management team. He oversees long-term budgetary planning and cost management in alignment with the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s strategic plan. Mr. Spinelli engages the Vice Presidents for Planning, Design and Construction, Operations, and Development & Visitor Experience to align financial management with short and long-term financial planning and projections.  He engages Board committees with respect to issues, trends, and changes in the organization&rsquo
column3: s operating model and operational delivery.

column1: Mr. Spinelli oversees preparation of annual and multi-year budgets, and monitors the progress of budget implementation and present operational metrics both internally and externally. He works with the President to ensure that revenue targets are reason- able and that the expense budget is controllable. He ensures that finance staff maintains the financial record systems in accordance with Conservancy policies and Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, and monitors the use of all funds. Mr. Spinelli oversees the preparation and approval of all financial reporting materials and metrics for organizations and the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s Board of Trustees, and prepares and communicates monthly, quarterly and annual financial statements. He manages cash flow and fore- casting, and directs all financial, project-based, and departmental accounting. He coordinates all audit and tax activities. He develops and monitors all Finance, Administration, HR, and IT related controls, procedures, and processes.

column1: Mr. Spinelli evaluates, at the corporate level, the deployment and efficacy of all Conservancy resources to ensure: programmatic and administration expenses support strategic mission of the Conservancy, all economic and human resources are used efficiently, and donor intent is honored.
Mr. Spinelli manages corporate governance policy development / implementation, legal and regulatory compliance. He oversees the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s insurance program, including coordination with the NYC Corporation Counsel on all litigation related to the Conservancy and its contract with the City. He manages Human Resources functions including: recruiting, training, employee relations and benefits administration. He manages IT functions including: technology planning and deployment of networking resources, infrastructure, and enterprise / application software and policy development.
s tenure as CFO, the Central Park Conservancy&rsquo
column3: s assets have nearly tripled, increasing by more than $240 million. This change has been instrumental in ensuring that the organization&rsquo
column4: s mission remains insulated from economic cycles.

column1: Prior to his role as CFO, he held the positions of Vice President for Finance, Director of Capital Projects, and Deputy Chief of Operations.
Mr. Spinelli holds a B.B.A in Management from Hofstra University.

Copy of About the Central Park Conservancy,inside-cpc-1.html,"

A Public/Private Partnership
In 1998, the City of New York awarded the Central Park Conservancy a management contract that ensured the continuing maintenance, public programming, and capital restoration of Central Park. This contract confirmed the City's confidence in its nearly twenty-year partnership with the Conservancy. Both the Conservancy and the City of New York had invested nearly $350 million in Central Park operations, capital improvements, programs for visitors and volunteers, and endowment
column2: it also had played an increasingly active role in Park management.

column1: Under this agreement, the Conservancy receives an annual fee for services. The amount of the fee was determined by a formula that requires the Conservancy to raise and spend a specified minimum amount of private funds in the Park on an annual basis. The minimum Conservancy annual expenditure &mdash
column2: which can include maintenance, programming and landscape improvements &mdash
column3: is $5 million. The annual fee from the City depends on the Conservancy's expenditures in the Park and on the revenues generated by concessions in Central Park.

column1: On April 27, 2006, the contract was renewed for another eight years. The new contract maintains the City's baseline allocation for the maintenance of the Park, but it lifts the cap on the amount of funding the Conservancy receives based on concession revenues generated in the Park. Under the previous contract, the Conservancy received an amount equal to 50% of concession revenues beyond the first $6 million generated in the Park, not to exceed $2 million. As more of the Park is restored and the cost of caring for it continues to grow, removing this cap will ensure that the Park will continue to benefit from increasing revenues that are directly related to its successful management.

column2: eight-year agreement, the Conservancy will provide for the Park's day-to-day care. Specified in the contract are: landscape maintenance, replacement of dead trees and plants, mowing and reseeding/resodding, graffiti removal, cleaning playgrounds and comfort stations, clearing walkways
column4: repairing benches, and maintaining and repairing structures and monuments. The Conservancy's responsibilities also include providing public programs to educate visitors about the Park's built and natural assets. Over the term of its partnership with the City, the Conservancy has expanded its activities to include all of the above activities
column5: the management contract ratifies those activities.

column1:
The City of New York's Role in Central Park
The City of New York retains control and policy responsibility for Central Park. Capital improvements in the Park will continue to undergo public review at each stage of development with advice and consent from the Commissioner of Parks &
column2: Recreation. The City of New York/ Parks &amp
column3: Recreation has discretion over all events in the Park, and that will continue. At present, all revenues generated from concessions in the Park go into the City of New York's general fund, and that will continue.

column1:
The Conservancy's Qualifications
The Central Park Conservancy is uniquely qualified to manage Central Park. The Conservancy has a proven track record in restoring and managing the Park. With its partner, the City of New York, it brought the Park from its deteriorated state in the late 1970s to its present condition, with major landscapes and historic structures restored and well-maintained. The Conservancy is a model for public-private partnerships for parks throughout the country and has developed an excellent staff of park management professionals.

The Conservancy also has a track record in raising private funds to improve and preserve Central Park. Since its founding in 1980, the Conservancy has raised $350 million in private dollars, which, combined with the City's investment, turned Central Park into a living symbol of New York City's revitalization. Further, of every $1 the Conservancy raises, more than $.80 goes toward direct spending on horticulture, operations, maintenance, education, recreation, and public programs.

The Conservancy's Governance
The Conservancy is and will be accountable to the City of New York. The City of New York retains control and policy responsibility for Central Park. The Commissioner and officials of the City of New York/Parks &
column2: Recreation Department are involved in all Park planning and must approve all of the Conservancy's capital improvements in the Park. In addition, the Conservancy's 52-member Board of Trustees includes the Parks Commissioner and the Borough President of Manhattan (both ex officio), five Trustees appointed by the Mayor of the City of New York, and private sector members representing the City's business and philanthropic communities.&nbsp

column1:
The Conservancy's Community Outreach and Public Review Process
Central Park will always be a public park. The Conservancy will continue to involve the public in the planning of any improvements to the Park. Starting with approval by the Commissioner of Parks &
column2: Recreation, the Conservancy's community outreach on capital projects is one of the most extensive and inclusive in the City. For any project, the Conservancy consults with Park users and surrounding communities to help develop its plans. The Conservancy then presents its plans to Community Boards, the Landmarks Preservation and Art Commissions for their review and approval. This process will continue unaltered.

column1:
Advisory boards comprised of community residents work with the Conservancy on a range of projects and issues. They include the following, and will be expanded as projects and programs create the need: The Upper Park Community Advisory Committee, the Woodlands Advisory Board, the Great Lawn Advisory Committee, the Central Park Recreation Roundtable, the North Meadow Recreation Center Advisory Committee, the Public Programs Community Advisory Committee, and the Frederick Douglass Circle Community Advisory Committee.

This contract confirmed the City's confidence in its nearly twenty-year partnership with the Conservancy.",devnull@convio.com,"Oct 01, 2009 03:41 PM CDT",/about/inside-the-conservancy/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"management, contract, maintenance, public programming, capital restoration, projects",,,,,,,,
The Perimeter Association provides funding for the improvement and maintenance of Central Park's six-mile perimeter which runs from the Park's wall to the street curb.
column2: Over 100 residential buildings, clubs, and community organizations around the Park support the program with contributions from $1,500 to $7,000. Contributions to the Perimeter Association allow Conservancy staff to:

column1: • Keep the six-mile perimeter clean seven days a week, year-round
• Install plantings along the wall and at entrances
Without the support of the Perimeter Association's cooperating buildings, it would be difficult to keep the perimeter clean and maintained.
For more information on or to donate to the Perimeter Association, please call 212-310-6655 or
The map below indicates those buildings that have contributed to the Perimeter Association during the current fiscal year (donations made between July 1, 2012 - June 30, 2013).
A special thank you to The Beresford (211 Central Park West) and the Rudin Management Company for their loyal and generous support.
