column3: >The Hampshire House, situated at 150 Central Park South between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, has been a symbol of elegant New York-living since its doors opened in 1938. The 36 story building was designed by A. Rollin Caughey and William F. Evans, Jr. and features interiors by Dorothy Draper. Regency and Art Deco styles come to life in the building&rsquo
column5: ade, from the gleaming white brick base to the signature pyramidal copper roof. In addition to amenities including a luxury health club and spa, residents enjoy close proximity to the finest theaters, restaurants, shopping destinations, museums, and of course, Central Park.

column2: >The Hampshire House has been a generous supporter of the Central Park Conservancy for many years. In 2012, shareholders were presented with the Conservancy&rsquo
column5: award in recognition of their partnership with the organization. Through contributions to the Perimeter Association, the Hampshire House helps ensure that their residents&rsquo
column6: front yard echoes the beauty of the building they call home. The Women&rsquo
column7: s Committee of The Central Park Conservancy extends its sincere appreciation to the Board of Directors of the Hampshire House for their continued and loyal support.

The Adopt-A-Bench program was established in 1986 as a permanent fund to maintain and endow the care of Central Park's more than 9,000 benches and their surrounding landscapes. To date, more than 3,000 benches have been adopted. In recognition of contributions to the fund, the Conservancy installs a personalized plaque on a park bench of the donor's choosing. Most benches can be adopted for $7,500. Custom-made rustic benches can be adopted for $25,000 and placed in a woodland or rustic area of the Park.
A bench is a wonderful way to memorialize or honor a loved one. Adopt-A-Bench for a birthday, anniversary, new baby, graduation &ndash
column2: it is the perfect gift for any occasion! While the plaques take about 8 weeks for production and installation, a personalized certificate can be provided immediately upon adoption to notify the recipient that a bench has been adopted in their honor. You can write the plaque inscription yourself or let the recipient write their own. For more information on how you can select and personalize your bench, please call 212-310-6617.

column1: If you are interested in more information, please call 212-310-6617, or e-mail us at: benches@centralparknyc.org. To adopt a bench, click on the button above and return the completed form (PDF).

column2: >The Central Park Conservancy reserves the right to temporarily or permanently alter or relocate benches.

The mission of Central Park Playground Partners is to maintain the quality and cleanliness of Central Park&rsquo
column2: s 21 playgrounds. Our playgrounds embody the highest standards of safety, innovation, and creativity, but these standards cannot be sustained without donations like yours. <a href=""https://secure2.convio.net/cpc/site/Donation2?df_id=1300&amp
column3: 1300.donation=form1"">Being a Playground Partner is a wonderful way to directly engage in your community of families and neighbors. We seek to promote stewardship and environmentalism throughout the Park, bringing unique opportunities for camaraderie and friendship for you and your children. The funds we receive go directly towards the preservation, care, and daily inspection of these cherished play spaces. With your generosity, our Playgrounds can continue to enrich the quality of life for present and future generations of children and be an essential part of a healthy childhood for all families living in New York City.

column2: s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, hosts its Annual Family Party at Heckscher Playground, inside the Park at Central Park South and 7th Avenue the third Wednesday of May. column1: PGP TOTS is a subcommittee of the Playground Partners specifically for moms with children under three years old. column7:
>The Beresford
at 81st and 82nd Streets on Central Park West

column4: "">Some of the most recognizable icons of Central Park aren't inside the Park &mdash
column5: they're the buildings that surround it. One of these landmark neighbors is the Beresford, located between 81st and 82nd Streets on Central Park West.

column3: "">""The Beresford is clearly meant to be seen from Central Park,"" said architecture critic Paul Goldberger. Though it may appear to be square, the Beresford is shaped like a U, with the U's right side at 82nd Street. Ornate, baroque towers sit atop three of the building's four corners, all except the northwest corner, which faces away from the Park. The best view of the building looks toward the southeast corner, as one does from the Lake in Central Park. The Beresford's three towers suggest a V shape that forms an arrow pointing directly toward Bethesda Terrace, the heart of Central Park.

"">In the Beresford, architect Emery Roth brought together a variety of styles, including Art Deco, Beaux-Arts, and baroque. Goldberger calls the Beresford an ""interpretation of Italian architecture and other styles"" that simultaneously fulfills the demands of a large New York City apartment building. ""Roth was an assembler of various architectural elements,"" Goldberger said. In the Beresford, these various styles, ""form eclectic, free-flowing mixes."" The result is a building that is distinctly Emery Roth and distinctly New York.
"">The Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy sincerely appreciates The Beresford's ongoing, loyal support of the Perimeter Association.

• American Museum of Natural History
• New York City Audobon Society
BioBlitz Results Show a Very Diverse Central Park

column2: >The initial results of the Central Park BioBlitz are in! They indicate that the Conservancy's long-time management has encouraged greater wildlife diversity throughout Central Park.
>The BioBlitz was an intensive 24-hour survey of the Park conducted in summer 2013. Here are a few of the most exciting BioBlitz discoveries:

column1: <li>The eastern chipmunk was identified in Central Park for the first time in many years. Experts attribute its resurgence to the Conservancy's 2009 removal of trash cans from the Park&rsquo
column2: s woodlands, which took away an important food source from the competing, non-native rat population. When the rats left the woodlands, the chipmunks returned.

column1: • The bullhead catfish and black crappie were identified in Central Park's ponds for the first time. Dr. John Waldman, who led fish identification throughout the Park, said that the quality of the Park's water bodies were similar to those found in upstate, remote areas thanks to the Conservancy's Soil & Water Lab, which is dedicated to the care of the Park's lakes.

<li>A multitude of insects were identified for the first time, particularly in the Hallett Nature Sanctuary and other woodlands. In these areas, Conservancy crews are more likely to allow fallen limbs and trees to remain on the ground, creating a habitat for native insects. Insects feed the Park&rsquo
column2: s large bird population and are a healthy part of any ecosystem.

column1: • Many lichens were observed in the north end of the Park, but we were surprised to find nearly as many in the south end, which receives 75 percent of the Park's 40 million annual visitors. In addition, researchers found lichens on almost every tree in the Park, compared to the 1970s when nearly no lichens were present. Experts attributed this to the improved air quality in Central Park, thanks to the cultivation of trees and plant life.

column2: >The Central Park BioBlitz was organized by the Central Park Conservancy and Macaulay Honors College. From August 26 to August 27, more than 500 Macaulay sophomores and scientists from leading research institutions surveyed Central Park for 24 hours, identifying as many species as possible.

>The complete results will be shared next spring in a series of public programs to teach you more about the Park and its wildlife. Follow us on <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/centralparknyc"" style=""text-decoration:underline
column4: >Twitter, or sign up for
column5: >our free e-newsletter, to keep up on the latest BioBlitz news.

column1: ",The initial results of the Central Park BioBlitz are in! They indicate that the Conservancy's long-time management has encouraged greater wildlife diversity throughout Central Park.,cperez@centralparknyc.org,"Aug 07, 2013 08:34 AM CDT",/about/news/,Full body only - No right M. No Headline,TRUE,No-Ad,,none,no,,,"Central Park, New York, BioBlitz, bioblitz, bio, species, investigation",,,,,,,,

Each year in Central Park, thousands of daffodils and tulips mark the arrival of spring, while mums herald the beginning of autumn. What better gift than to have flowers planted in someone's honor in Central Park?

With a minimum donation of $50, the Conservancy will plant your daffodils, tulips or mums in the Park. For your donation, you or the person(s) you are honoring will receive an eCard or physical certificate indicating the flowers planted and the date of the gift.
Please Note: Locations for plantings cannot be specified and no plaques will be placed in the Park.
If you wish to send a physical card instead of an ecard, please visit our other Daffodil and Tulips gifts page.
For more information about flower donations, please call 212-310-6668, or e-mail us at: wcommittee@centralparknyc.org

","Each year in Central Park, thousands of daffodils and tulips mark the arrival of spring, while mums herald the beginning of autumn. Member Programs and Perks,member-programs-test.html,"	<!--Here start the wrapper script-->

As a way of thanking members for their support, the Central Park Conservancy hosts exclusive member programs throughout the year, in addition to offering special perks at public programs and discounts with partners in and outside the Park. See what&rsquo
column2: s on offer for fall 2013 below!

column1: As a way of thanking members for their support, the Central Park Conservancy hosts exclusive member programs throughout the year, including special tours in the Park that give an inside view of its beauty through the seasons . See what&rsquo
column2: s on offer for fall 2013 below!

column1: Visit the Park's extensive woodlands on these intimate, members-only tours led by Conservancy Woodland Zone Gardeners. Pre-registration is required by specified date below:
Take a break from the City streets with this insider's tour of the Ramble, one of the Park's most intricate landscapes.
Take a step into Manhattan's Adirondacks and experience the peaceful streams and gentle cascades in this serene space.
Meet inside the Park at 103rd Street and Central Park West
Travel from Central Park to Black Rock Forest in the Hudson Highlands. 	Learn about the region&rsquo
column2: s geology, biodiversity, and stunning fall foliage on this urban to rural adventure. Transportation provided. Ages 16+. Space is limited.

column1: Meet at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center
Members enjoy free registration to this otherwise paid hiking your with the Conservancy and the Appalachian Mount Club Appalachian Mountain Club through Central Park&rsquo
column2: s diverse landscapes while you learn about urban horticulture, woodlands, and conservation. Ages 16+. Space is limited, arrive early to sign in.

column1: the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center
Hosted by Central Park Paws, a program of the Central Park Conservancy. Please bring water for you and your dog.
Leave your dog crate at home &mdash
column4: gives you and your canine friend a chance to see (but not swim in) beautiful waterfalls and picturesque pools.

column1: Meet at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center

column2: re in Central Park all of the time with your pooch, but do you know the history of this American masterpiece of art? What&rsquo
column3: s the story of the Dairy? Bethesda Fountain? The Arcade? This fascinating art history class with your hound will give you the inside scoop!

column1: Meet at the Dairy Visitor Center and Gift Shop

Along with exclusive members-only events, members can take advantage of special benefits offered at public programs, including discounts on Park tours. To see a full listing of Conservancy programs, including those with member benefits, visit our calendar.

Borrow a Woodland Discovery Kit equipped with binoculars, a hand lens, and flora/fauna guides for a unique adventure in the Ramble or North Woods. An optional Discovery Journal will guide your woodland exploration and includes suggested activities and a large kid-friendly map to help you get around.

column2: >MEMBERS: Bring your membership card to receive a complimentary Discovery Journal.

column1: Take the kids on a walk through one of New York City&rsquo
column3: the North Woods. Learn how to spot and identify our feathered neighbors in their natural surroundings as guided by the NYC Audubon Society and a Conservancy Discovery Guide. Binoculars available to borrow, limited to 20 participants. Ages 5+.

column1: Meet at The Charles A. Dana Discovery Center

column2: >MEMBERS: Enjoy pre-registration to secure your spot!

column1: Bring your canine companions (on leash, please) for our annual celebration of the dog community in Central Park, including Best in Park events, an agility course, Canine Good Citizen testing, and micro-chipping. Come dressed for period-specific photo opportunities that commemorate &ldquo
column2: dogs in the Park through 	the decades.&rdquo
>MEMBERS: Bring your membership card to the Conservancy tent to receive a special treat! Not a member? Become one at the Fair and receive a gift for your Central Park dog.

column1: Wear your costume and bring a carved jack-o&rsquo
column2: -lantern for a celebration with spooky music, crafts, live entertainment, a parade, and New York City&rsquo
column3: s largest pumpkin flotilla at twilight!

column1: Meet at The Charles A. Dana Discovery Center

column3: -lantern off by 5:00 pm and show your membership card to enjoy guaranteed entry in the Pumpkin Sail.

column1: Conservancy members enjoy discounts in and around Central Park at restaurants, cultural institutions, retail stores, spas, fitness centers, and online retailers, including
Le Pain Quotidien, Wollman Rink, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Hilton Times Square, Sarabeth&rsquo
column2: s Kitchen, Aveda, FACE Cosmetics, and Tourneau. More info: centralparknyc.org/perks.

column1: Not a member? Become one today by signing up
column4: s a quick and easy way to support the Central Park Conservancy&rsquo

Join the Conservancy in celebrating the beauty of Central Park in spring!
Residents in buildings surrounding Central Park will gather to toast the season's gorgeous blooms and green meadows.
Be central to the Park by joining fellow residents and neighbors this spring!
Believe it or not, only 15 percent of households in buildings near the Park are current donors to the Conservancy.
That's why on this one special evening we
are encouraging our friends in Park perimeter buildings to simultaneously celebrate the Central Park Conservancy and help increase support (to at least 50 percent) among our neighbors.
With a current annual budget of $58.3 million required for the Conservancy to care for the Park's 843 acres &ndash
column2: the majority of which we must raise from private sources &ndash
column3: our continued success in maintaining this historic, green treasure will depend upon galvanizing those who benefit from the Park every day.

column1: Want to help support your Park? Join your friends and neighbors in raising funds and awareness on behalf of the Central Park Conservancy.
For event questions please send an email to jjacuzzi@centralparknyc.org or call 212-446-2241.

column1: Visit Central Park, wherever you are, with this guided, virtual walk across 72nd Street. Our Central Park Conservancy Discovery Guide will walk you through some of the Park's most beloved landmarks and landscapes. The virtual tour includes stunning 360 degree panoramas of notable areas as well as historic before and after photos showing what landscapes looked like before restoration. Along the way, learn about the notable trees that make these areas so beautiful.
We hope you enjoy this 72nd Street Virtual Walk. Let us know what you think! Email us with your feedback.
• For best experience, use browser such as a Firefox or Google Chrome.

You can view the tour on your desktop, tablet, or smart phone. You don't have to download an app, just click the image below to begin.You don't have to download an app, just click the image below to begin. For the best experience, use a modern browser such as Firefox or Google Chrome.

-->

The tour can be enjoyed at home or in the Park as a guide for your walk. If you're in the Park, begin inside the Park at West 72nd Street Entrance and Central Park West. Stops include Strawberry Fields, Cherry Hill, Bethesda Terrace, and Conservatory Water (the model boat pond). The tour takes approximately 25 minutes, but we encourage you to take your time and discover even more in areas that interest you.

column1: Park South and 7th Avenue. The event is a family-friendly fundraiser with activities geared toward children six months to 10 years of age:
• A baseball activity hosted by Bulldog Baseball

column2: delicious buffet featuring many sweets and treats

column1: • A performance by the stars of the Broadway musical ""Rodgers + Hammerstein's CINDERELLA""

column2: Adelina Wong Ettelson, Jennifer Evans, Nina Garcia, Sarah Kurita, Jill Ross, and Sharon Teles

The Playground Party is held rain or shine. Proceeds from the event help keep the Park's 21 playgrounds clean, safe, and well-maintained.

TEST- Honor Someone Special,honor-memorial-gifts-1.html,"

The Central Park Conservancy has several ways to give in honor of someone you care about. Give a gift membership for a birthday, make a donation in honor of a new college graduate, plant daffodils or tulips for Mother's Day or choose one of our other giving options for any other occasion. Your contribution is a great way to mark life's milestones while helping to

column2:
>Give a Gift Membership
Show you share a mutual love of Central Park with someone you care about by celebrating a holiday or special occasion with a gift membership to the Central Park Conservancy. The person you give the membership to will immediately receive a personalized
e-card - created by you - informing them of their gift membership, though the amount of the gift will not be disclosed.

column3:
3320.donation=form1"">Send an Honor or Memorial E-card
Make a gift honoring or memorializing someone special by sending an e-card. Your contribution will be acknowledged through your own personalized e-card sent to the honoree, or their family, informing them of your generous gift, though the amount will always remain confidential.

column2:
>Plant Daffodils, Tulips or Mums
Each year in Central Park, thousands of flowers are planted. With a minimum donation of $50, the Conservancy will plant your daffodils, tulips or mums in the Park to mark an anniversary, birth or other occasion. For your donation, the individual(s) you are honoring, or their family, will receive an e-card with your own personalized note.

>Gilder Run
Gilder Run, located on the steps of beautiful, Bridge No. 24, is a beloved location by all Central Park runners and walkers as it connects the East Drive with the Reservoir&rsquo
column3: s 1.5 mile running track. A paving stone on Gilder Run offers the opportunity to engrave your name, in stone, in Central Park.

column2:
>Adopt a Bench
The Adopt-A-Bench program was established in 1986 as a permanent fund to maintain and endow the care of Central Park&rsquo
column3: s more than 9,000 benches and their surrounding landscapes. In recognition of contributions to the fund, the Conservancy installs a plaque engraved with a personalized inscription on a park bench in a location of the donor&rsquo

column2:
>Endow a Tree
The Central Park Conservancy's Tree Trust provides for the permanent care of Central Park's approximately 24,000 trees. From flowering cherries to statuesque elms, contributions to the Tree Trust ensure the Park's trees are pruned, fertilized and kept healthy and strong.

column1: ",There may be no better way to remember a loved one or honor someone special than by making a memorial or tribute gift in support of the Central Park Conservancy.,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Jan 11, 2010 12:03 PM CST",/donate/honor-someone-special/,No Ad Member-No right Margin,TRUE,Default - No Ad Member-No Right Margin,,none,no,,,"donate, give, support, honorary, memorial, truibute, in honor, in memory",,,,,,,,
Virtual Walk

Visit Central Park, wherever you are, with this guided, virtual walk across 72nd Street. Our Central Park Conservancy Discovery Guide will walk you through some of the Park's most beloved landmarks and landscapes. The virtual tour includes stunning 360-degree panoramas of notable areas as well as historic before and after photos showing what landscapes looked like before restoration. Along the way, learn about the notable trees that make these areas so beautiful.
We hope you enjoy this 72nd Street Virtual Walk. Let us know what you think! Email us with your feedback.
• For best experience, use browser such as a Firefox or Google Chrome.
• Slow connection speeds, at home or in the Park, may cause long loading times.

You can view the tour on your desktop, tablet, or smart phone. You don't have to download an app, just click the image below to begin.You don't have to download an app, just click the image below to begin. For the best experience, use a modern browser such as Firefox or Google Chrome.

-->

The tour can be enjoyed at home or in the Park as a guide for your walk. If you're in the Park, begin inside the Park at West 72nd Street Entrance and Central Park West. Stops include Strawberry Fields, Cherry Hill, Bethesda Terrace, and Conservatory Water (the model boat pond). The tour takes approximately 25 minutes, but we encourage you to take your time and discover even more in areas that interest you.

Give a gift that will help support Central Park, including the wildlife who call it home. Proceeds from this symbolic adoption will help keep the Park ecologically healthy for all of the species that depend on it. Choose one of these adorable plush Pals (each comes with an official certificate of adoption) as a reminder that you have helped keep the Park flourishing for generations to come. Recommended for ages 3 and up.

Guided Tour Information,guided-tours-info.html,"

Learn the full story of the Park's history, design and ecology on the Official Central Park Tours. The Conservancy's expert guides provide an insider's view and unique access to this masterpiece of landscape architecture and the world's greatest urban park. Space is limited, arrive early for check in.

All tours take place rain or shine, except in extreme weather conditions (heavy rain, sustained winds of 30mph or more, snowstorms, and a wind chill below 25 or heat index above 95 degrees). Groups of seven or more should email tours@centralparknyc.org or call 212-360-2726 to schedule a Custom Tour.

We're sorry, but online ticket purchases require Internet Explorer version 9 or newer, Google Chrome, Safari, or Firefox. Please visit a Park visitor center to purchase tickets for ticketed tours. View the full tour schedule: centralparknyc.org/calendar

${medium}

Reporting to and partnering with the President and the other Vice Presidents, the Vice President for Philanthropy is responsible for developing and executing a fundraising strategy that supports the Conservancy&rsquo
column2: s contributed income goals. In particular, Ms. McIntosh directs and manages principle and major gifts, planned giving, and institutional giving for both annual activities and capital projects.

column1: Ms. McIntosh collaborates with the senior team on operational and strategic issues. She also works with the board on a range of development initiatives and offers guidance and support to the Nominating and Development Strategy Committees.
• Work collaboratively with Board and senior management to strengthen fundraising leadership.
• Design and implement a comprehensive plan for maintaining and/or increasing support from current patrons and attracting new donors who will offer significant contributions to the Conservancy.

column2: s base of institutional supporters for both annual and capital programs.

column1: • Ensure that donor stewardship is at the highest level of excellence.
<li>Continue to capitalize on recent fundraising successes and help the organization to create and seize on new opportunities that will support the Conservancy&rsquo

Ms. McIntosh recently joined the Conservancy staff after an eight year tenure at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts where she was Senior Director, Individual Giving and Membership Services. She was also Director of Development at the Museum of the Moving Image and the National Academy of Design and held several development positions at the American Folk Art Museum. She earned her B.A. in English from Binghamton University and an M.A. from the Program in Arts Administration at Teachers College, Columbia University where she taught for nine years. Jane is currently an adjunct lecturer at Marymount Manhattan College where she teaches Fundraising and Marketing for the Arts.

,Vice President for Philanthropy,rlynn@centralparknyc.org,Nov 06, 2009 09:49 AM CST",/about/inside-the-conservancy/management-board/,Default,TRUE,,,none,,,,"Jane McIntosh, vice president, philanthropy",,,,,,,,

This past April, residents in buildings surrounding the Park gathered to toast the season's gorgeous blooms and green meadows.
We're now preparing for 2014! On Wednesday, April 9, 2014 we will once again be celebrating spring and enjoying another exciting visual presentation in Central Park.
Please be central to the Park by joining fellow residents and neighbors as a host next spring. Take a look at the map below to see locations already confirmed for 2014!
For event questions please send an email to jjacuzzi@centralparknyc.org or call 212-446-2241.
The Conservancy has set a goal to increase the percentage of current supporters in buildings near the Park.
That's why on this one special evening we
are encouraging our friends and neighbors in Park perimeter buildings to simultaneously celebrate spring in Central Park and help increase support of the Central Park Conservancy.
With a current annual budget of $58.3 million required for the Conservancy to care for the Park's 843 acres &ndash
column2: the majority of which we must raise from private sources &ndash
column3: our continued success in maintaining this historic, green treasure will depend upon galvanizing those who benefit from the Park every day.

Taste of Summer 2014,taste-of-summer-2014.html,"

Join us for Taste of Summer

This event features culinary delights prepared by renowned New York chefs, a luxury-filled silent auction and music by one of the City's hottest DJs. Held at the iconic Bethesda Terrace, this annual benefit for Central Park Conservancy brings together visionaries in support of its mission to restore and maintain the Park.
For more information or to purchase tickets or tables, please contact the Special Events Department at 212.446.2242 or tasteofsummer@centralparknyc.org.

Taste of Summer: In the Press
New York Social Diary (2013 Taste of Summer Kickoff) (PDF)
The New York Times (PDF)
New York Social Diary (PDF)
New York Post (PDF)
New York Observer (PDF)
Town &

Avenue Magazine (PDF)

Party in Your Playground 2014,playground-party-2014.html,"

Adventure in your Playground 2014
Come have an Adventure in Your Playground! On Wednesday, May 21, 2014, from 3:30pm-6:30pm, the Playground Partners of the Women&rsquo
column2: s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, hosts its Annual Playground Party at Heckscher Playground, inside the Park at Central Park South and 7th Avenue. The event is a family-friendly fundraiser with activities geared toward children six months to 10 years of age:

column1: • Music of The Little Gym, performed by Robin Wes and Randy McCoy
• Golf hitting bubble by the Golf Club at Chelsea Piers
• A delicious buffet featuring many sweets and treats
Party Co-Chairmen: Shirin Christoffersen, Jennifer Evans, Samantha Topping Gellert, Kimberly Klimczak, and Michelle Marra
Grandparents Committee Co-Chairmen: Patsy and Jeff Tarr
Playground Partners Committee Chairmen: Paige Hardy, Sarah Kurita, and Sharon Teles
The Playground Party is held rain or shine. Proceeds from the event help keep the Park's 21 playgrounds clean, safe, and well-maintained.

About,index.html,"

Central Park is the 843-acre masterpiece of landscape architecture designed in the 19th century by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux and designated New York City's first scenic landmark in 1974. As one of America's average works of art and the nation's first public park, Central Park has become the most famous and beloved urban park in the world
Learn all about the history of the Park with our Central Park Timeline.

Central Park Conservancy raises 75% of Central Park's annual Parkwide expense budget and is responsible for the day-to-day maintenance and operations of the Park. Our success can be measured by the 40 million people who visit Central Park annually and by parks around the world who consider Central Park Conservancy to be the leader and the inspiration of urban park management and restoration.
Learn more about Central Park Conservancy and our work in the Park.

column1: <!--/.row-->",2014 redesign - description goes here,bbell@centralparknyc.org,"Feb 05, 2014 02:24 PM CST",/2014/support/,2014 Default Sidebar Nav,FALSE,,,none,no,,,,,,,,,,,
Virtual Walk

Visit Central Park, wherever you are, with this guided, virtual walk across 72nd Street. Our Central Park Conservancy Discovery Guide will walk you through some of the Park's most beloved landmarks and landscapes. The virtual tour includes stunning 360-degree panoramas of notable areas as well as historic before and after photos showing what landscapes looked like before restoration. Along the way, learn about the notable trees that make these areas so beautiful.
We hope you enjoy this 72nd Street Virtual Walk. Let us know what you think! Email us with your feedback.
• For best experience, use browser such as a Firefox or Google Chrome.
• Slow connection speeds, at home or in the Park, may cause long loading times.

The tour can be enjoyed at home or in the Park as a guide for your walk. If you're in the Park, begin inside the Park at West 72nd Street Entrance and Central Park West. Stops include Strawberry Fields, Cherry Hill, Bethesda Terrace, and Conservatory Water (the model boat pond). The tour takes approximately 25 minutes, but we encourage you to take your time and discover even more in areas that interest you.

","Visit Central Park, wherever you are, with this guided, virtual walk across 72nd Street. Custom & Group Tours,custom-tours.html,"

The Conservancy offers one-of-a-kind, private tours of the world's greatest urban park. Whether you&rsquo
column2: re visiting New York or are a local resident, see the City&rsquo
column3: s backyard from a new perspective through a custom tour designed to suit your needs. Walking tours led by Conservancy Guides are $150 for 1 to 10 people. Duration, capacity, and prices vary on staff-led and van tours. Premium tours with the Conservancy&rsquo
column4: s official historian and celebrated photographer, Sara Cedar Miller, or Conservatory Garden Curator, Diane Schaub, are also offered. At least three weeks advance booking required. Gift certificates are available.

column1:
Conservatory Garden Tour with Diane Schaub, Central Park Conservancy Conservatory Garden Curator
Tour the Park's formal Conservatory Garden, known for its extraordinary floral displays, through the eyes of its Curator, Diane Schaub. With twenty years of experience managing and designing for the Garden, Schaub offers a singular perspective on its history and design, as well as plantings unique to this six-acre urban gem. Hundreds of annual and perennial varieties, eighty-year old crabapple allé
column2: es, and exceptional fountain sculptures are among the Garden&rsquo
column3: s treasures. Tours start at $250 for up to 10 people.

column1:
Van Tour with Sara Cedar Miller, Central Park Conservancy Historian and Photographer
Learn stories and secrets from the Park's amazing history and appreciate some little-known landscapes and sculptures as you tour the Park with Sara Cedar Miller, Central Park Conservancy's historian and photographer for more than twenty-five years. Miller has shot thousands of photographs of Central Park and has had her work featured in the Central Park Photography Collection as well as her bestselling book, Central Park, An American Masterpiece.
column2:
In addition to seeing the Park through the eyes of the award-winning photographer, you will receive one of Miller's autographed books as a keepsake. Tours start at $500, including van transportation for a maximum of 6 people.
More information: 212.310.6679

","The Central Park Conservancy offers one-of-a-kind, private tours of one of the world's great urban spaces. Both walking tours and tours by vehicle are available with a donation.",rlynn@centralparknyc.org,"Dec 08, 2009 03:55 PM CST",/2014/tours/guided-tours/,2014 Default Sidebar Nav,TRUE,,,tours,no,/assets/images/tour/Supporttours-l.jpg,/assets/images/news-images/customtour-m.jpg,"tour, tours, custom, walking",,,,,,/assets/images/tour/custom-tours2013-s.jpg,/assets/images/news-images/customtour-t.jpg,

column1: Central Park Conservancy, a private, not-for-profit organization, was formed in 1980 by a group of concerned citizens determined to improve Central Park. Today, we manage Central Park under a contract with the City of New York. Over its 160-year history, the Park has experienced a cycle of improvements and decline. The latest decline was in the 1960s and 70s, which led to Central Park Conservancy's formation. Central Park Conservancy is uniquely qualified to break this cycle, to prevent future declines, and to ensure the Park's care for current and future generations.

Thanks to the generosity of many individuals, corporations, foundations, and the City of New York, Central Park Conservancy has invested nearly $700 million to date into the Park, making it a model for urban parks worldwide. We provide 75% of Central Park's $58.3 million annual operating budget, and we are responsible for all basic care of the Park.
With 40 million visits each year to its 843 acres, Central Park is the most frequently visited urban park in the United States. To manage the Park, Conservancy crews aerate and seed lawns
column8: and care for waterbodies and woodlands, controlling erosion, maintaining the drainage system, and protecting over 150 acres of lakes and streams from pollution, siltation, and algae.

column1: Learn about Central Park Conservancy's management and Board of Trustees.
The mission of Central Park Conservancy is to restore, manage, and enhance Central Park in partnership with the public.
Central Park Conservancy aspires to build a great organization that sets the standard for and spreads the principles of world-class park management &mdash
column3: to improve the quality of open space for the enjoyment of all.

column1: Central Park Conservancy is committed to sustaining this operating model to provide a legacy for future generations of park users.

Central Park is a masterpiece of landscape architecture created to provide a scenic retreat from urban life for the enjoyment of all and, in so doing, to establish New York's place among the great cities of the world. As the organization entrusted with the responsibility of caring for New York's most important public space, our work is founded on the belief that citizen leadership and private philanthropy are key to ensuring that the Park and its essential purpose endure.

column4: Our Contract with the City of New York

column1: In 2013, the City of New York awarded Central Park Conservancy a new management agreement to ensure the continued maintenance of Central Park. Originally signed in 1998 and renewed in 2006, the 2013 contract affirms the City's confidence in its more than thirty-three year partnership with Central Park Conservancy.

Under the current ten-year agreement, Central Park Conservancy provides for the Park's day-to-day care, as well as certain maintenance work outside Central Park. Specified in the contract are: landscape and lawn maintenance, tree care, horticultural work, graffiti removal, cleaning playgrounds and comfort stations, repairing benches, clearing walkways, cleaning drains and sewers, and maintaining and repairing monuments and certain Park structures.

Central Park Conservancy receives an annual fee for the services it provides. The amount of this fee is determined using a formula that requires Central Park Conservancy to raise and spend a specified minimum amount of private funds in the Park on an annual basis. Since 1980, Central Park Conservancy has invested nearly $700 million in Central Park operations, capital improvements, and programs for visitors and volunteers.

The City of New York retains control and policy responsibility for Central Park. Capital improvements in the Park continue to undergo public review at each stage of development, with advice and consent from the Commissioner of Parks &
column2: Recreation. In addition, the City of New York and Parks &amp
column3: Recreation continues to have discretion over all events in the Park.

column1: Central Park Conservancy is accountable to the City of New York. The City of New York retains control and policy responsibility for Central Park. The Commissioner and officials of the City of New York/Parks &
column2: Recreation are involved in all Park planning and must approve all of Central Park Conservancy's capital improvements in the Park. Central Park Conservancy, however, as a private not-for-profit organization, has a separate Board of Trustees. The Board is comprised of 43 general trustees representing the community that uses the Park, four ex officio trustees including the Parks Commissioner, the Borough President of Manhattan, the Central Park Administrator, and the president of the Women's Committee, and five Trustees appointed by the Mayor of the City of New York. Additionally, there are currently 13 Life Trustees.

column1: ","Central Park Conservancy, founded in 1980, works to restore, manage, and enhance Central Park in partnership with the public.",bbell@centralparknyc.org,"Feb 04, 2014 06:15 AM CST",/2014/about/about-cpc/,2014 Default Sidebar Nav,TRUE,,,none,no,,,,,,,,,,,

This section provides an overview of the Central Park Conservancy's governance policies and practices. This section summarizes existing policies, committee responsibilities, and by-laws adopted by the Board of Trustees. This overview applies to Trustees, Committee members, senior officers, and employees of Central Park Conservancy and how they carry out their respective responsibilities.
Central Park Conservancy is a publicly-supported tax exempt 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization.
The mission of Central Park Conservancy is to restore, manage, and enhance Central Park in partnership with the public.
Central Park Conservancy aspires to build a great organization that sets the standard for and spreads the principles of world-class park management &mdash
column3: to improve the quality of open space for the enjoyment of all.

column1: Central Park Conservancy is committed to sustaining this operating model to provide a legacy for future generations of park users.
Central Park Conservancy is a private, not-for-profit organization founded in 1980 that manages Central Park under a contract with the New York City Department of Parks &
column2: Recreation. Thanks to the generosity of many individuals, corporations, foundations, and the City of New York, Central Park Conservancy has invested $700 million to date into the Park, $536 million of which was privately funded, making it a model for urban parks worldwide. Central Park Conservancy provides the majority of Central Park's $58.3 million annual operating budget, and is responsible for all basic care of the Park.

column1: With 40 million visits each year to its 843 acres, Central Park is the most frequently visited urban park in the United States. To manage the Park, Conservancy crews aerate and seed lawns
column8: and care for waterbodies and woodlands, controlling erosion, maintaining the drainage system, and protecting over 150 acres of lakes and streams from pollution, siltation, and algae.

column1: Central Park is a masterpiece of landscape architecture created to provide a scenic retreat from urban life for the enjoyment of all and, in so doing, establishes New York&rsquo
column2: s place among the great cities of the world. As the organization entrusted with the responsibility of caring for New York's most important public space, our work is founded on the belief that citizen leadership and private philanthropy are key to ensuring that the Park and its essential purpose endure.

column4: We value commitment to our mission, Central Park, and the visitor experience.
We value innovation and the highest quality results in every aspect of our work.
We value ethical conduct in our business practices.
We value adaptability in our response to change and challenges.

column3: We value clear, consistent communication, teamwork and an open dialogue both internally and with the public.&nbsp
column8: We value the public, and work to earn and maintain their confidence in our role as caretakers of Central Park.

column1: The Board acts as the fiduciary and the steward of the organization and as a guardian of Central Park Conservancy's mission. All Trustees are fully expected to carry out the following duties:

column2: Acting in good faith, participating in governance, and exercising the ordinary and reasonable care in decision-making that can be expected of all prudent persons in a like position would use under similar circumstances
Faithfulness to Central Park Conservancy's mission and consistently acting in the best interest of Central Park Conservancy
Acting in accordance with the organization's articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other governing documents, as well as applicable laws and regulations.&nbsp
Responsibilities of the Board of Trustees

column1: The Board of Trustees is responsible for oversight of the management of Central Park Conservancy to ensure that the resources, financial assets, and staff are properly and effectively used in support of the mission and in accordance with the Organization's by-laws, applicable laws and regulations, and the Management Contract with the City of New York. Primary Board responsibilities:
<li>Approving the mission of Central Park Conservancy and setting appropriate strategic goals

column2: CEO and Senior Management, and ensuring that an appropriate succession plan exists

column1: <li>Reviewing compensation practices and policies, and overseeing the performance of Senior Management
<li>Reviewing and approving the annual operating budget and capital construction program
<li>Ensuring that general operating procedures and controls are in place

<li>Ensuring that Central Park Conservancy's financial statements are fairly presented and free from material misstatement, including assessing the integrity of Central Park Conservancy's accounting and financial reporting policies and practices
column2: adequacy of Central Park Conservancy's internal controls
column3: and compliance with applicable laws and regulations

column1: <li>Monitoring the management of Central Park Conservancy's endowment to ensure compliance with Central Park Conservancy's Investment Policy, as well as overseeing the real estate, monies, securities and other assets of Central Park Conservancy, with the authority to invest and re-invest the same
<li>Overseeing the activities of the Benefits Committee with respect to matters relating to insurance and other benefits for employees of Central Park Conservancy
<li>Recommending replacements as vacancies occur in committee memberships
<li>Recommending new Trustee candidates and reporting to the Board on the adequacy of the size and structure of the Board and the committees to conduct the business of Conservancy
<li>Identifying and cultivating individuals willing to contribute to Central Park Conservancy the experience, skills and resources needed by the Board and committees
<li>Supervising the overall fund-raising efforts of Central Park Conservancy, including developing Trustee contacts, assisting in fundraising activities, and cultivating new and existing donors
• Reviewing the strategic direction of the organization and participate in strategic planning processes, as needed.
The By-laws provide that there are fifty-two (52) Trustees.
<li>Four (4) Trustees are Ex-officio Trustees, and include the Borough President of Manhattan
column2: the Commissioner of the Department of Parks &amp
column3: Recreation of the City of New York
column6: the Central Park Administrator (if a different individual than the person holding the title of President and CEO)
column7: and the President of the Women's Committee

column1: <li>Five (5) Trustees are appointed by the Mayor of the City of New York

column2: General Trustees,"" none of whom are employees of, nor hold office in, the City of New York.

column1: A fourth category of Life Trustees are entitled to attend meetings. However, their presence is not counted towards quorum, they are not entitled to vote, nor are they considered Trustees for any other purpose. Life Trustees shall hold office until death or resignation.
General Trustees are divided into two (2) annual classes. Each class serves for two (2) years, and may be re-elected. There are no term limits.
A substantial majority of the Board of Trustees are independent directors, defined as individuals:
<li>Who are not compensated by the organization as employees or independent contractors
<li>Whose compensation is not determined by individuals who are compensated by the organization
<li>Who do not receive, directly or indirectly, material financial benefits from the organization, except as a member of the charitable class served by the organization
• Who are not related to (as a spouse, sibling, parent or child), or do not reside with, any individual described above.
The Officers of the Board include the Board Chair
column5: and Secretary, Treasurer, and such additional officers that the Board may from time to time elect. Officers hold office for one (1) year. There are no term limits. No ex-Officio Trustee shall be an Officer. Officers may be removed with or without cause by the Board.

column1: The Board of Trustees has four (4) regularly scheduled meetings annually. All scheduled Board and Committee meetings include an agenda and materials are provided to Trustees and Committee members in advance of such meetings. Trustees are expected to prepare for all meetings by reviewing the materials and to attend all meetings. Standing Committees are scheduled to meet four times annually in conjunction with the Board meeting, with the exception of the Audit Committee that has two scheduled meetings each year to coincide with the independent audit. Additional Committee meetings are scheduled as needed.

The Nominating Committee reviews any individuals proposed to the board as candidates for membership and makes recommendations to the full Board, in addition to reviewing the Board's composition and performance on an annual basis. The Committee takes into account the Board's overall composition in relation to the organization's short and long term goals and needs and considers the presence of appropriate combination of professional experience, skills, knowledge, perspectives, and backgrounds on the Board as a whole. The number of Trustees varies depending on resignations, retirement, or removals and the availability of appropriate qualified candidates. Vacancies of General Trustees are filled by a majority vote of the remaining General, Ex-officio, and Appointed Trustees. The Chairman, in consultation with the President &
column2: CEO, appoints the Chairs for all Committees.

column1: The Compensation and Management Development Committee meets annually to formally review the performance of the President &
column2: CEO and senior management and establish compensation and management development initiatives. The President &amp
column3: CEO does not attend or participate in the discussions, deliberations, or voting on his or her compensation.

column1: Central Park Conservancy is committed to maintaining the highest standards of conduct and ethics, and the organization's success is dependent upon the public's trust that Conservancy Trustees, Officers, Employees will conduct business in compliance with applicable laws, using sound judgment, and in an honest and ethical manner. Central Park Conservancy's Code of Conduct includes guidelines with respect to business ethics, financial accounting and recordkeeping, confidentiality of Conservancy records, anti-harassment, and substance abuse.

Members of Central Park Conservancy's Board of Trustees, as well as Conservancy officers and employees have a fiduciary duty to carry out the mission of Central Park Conservancy and conduct themselves without conflict to the interests of the organization. An actual or potential conflict of interest arises when an individual in a position to influence a decision concerning Central Park Conservancy's operations may result in a pecuniary benefit to that person, or to his or her family. All Trustees, Officers, and Employees have a duty to disclose actual or potential conflicts of interest regarding themselves, as well as other Trustees, Officers, and/or Employees.

Central Park Conservancy accepts unrestricted gifts, as well as gifts designated for specific programs and purposes from individuals, corporations, and foundations that fulfill and further the mission of Conservancy. ""Standard Contributions,"" which are generally accepted in the ordinary course of business, include cash, publicly traded securities, charitable gift annuities, life insurance and retirement plan beneficiary designations, and matching gifts. ""Non-standard Contributions"", such as tangible personal property, real estate, closely held securities, remainder interests in property, charitable remainder trusts, and charitable lead trusts are subject to review by Central Park Conservancy's Gift Acceptance Committee prior to acceptance to determine whether (a) accepting the property fulfills Central Park Conservancy's mission, (b) the property is marketable, (c) there are liabilities associated with the property, and/or (d) the property will generate undesirable tax consequences for the organization.

Central Park Conservancy's Whistleblower Policy is intended to encourage and enable employees and others to report fraudulent, dishonest, or illegal conduct. No officer, director, or employee who in good faith reports a violation of Central Park Conservancy's Code of Conduct shall suffer harassment, retaliation, or adverse employment consequences. Reports of improper conduct may be confidentially submitted to Central Park Conservancy through a confidential portal found on the organization's intranet at
column2:
http://intranet.e-cpc.centralparknyc.org.

column3: Central Park Conservancy, through this policy, strives to adhere to the principles set forth by the Donor Bill of Rights created by the Association of Fund Raising Professionals.

Adopt-A-Bench,adopt-a-bench.html,"

The Adopt-A-Bench program was established in 1986 as a permanent fund to maintain and endow the care of Central Park's more than 9,000 benches and their surrounding landscapes. To date, more than 3,000 benches have been adopted. In recognition of contributions to the fund, Central Park Conservancy installs a personalized plaque on a park bench of the donor's choosing. Most benches can be adopted for $7,500. Custom-made rustic benches can be adopted for $25,000 and placed in a woodland or rustic area of the Park.

A bench is a wonderful way to memorialize or honor a loved one. Adopt-A-Bench for a birthday, anniversary, new baby, graduation &ndash
column2: it is the perfect gift for any occasion! While the plaques take about 8 weeks for production and installation, a personalized certificate can be provided immediately upon adoption to notify the recipient that a bench has been adopted in their honor. You can write the plaque inscription yourself or let the recipient write their own. For more information on how you can select and personalize your bench, please call 212.310.6617.

Endow a Tree,endow-a-tree.html,"

Create a Living Memory
The Tree Trust of Central Park Conservancy offers you the unique opportunity to support the care of Central Park&rsquo
column2: s 19,000 trees. All contributions to the Tree Trust are placed in an endowment for existing trees and to fund the planting of new trees. Your gift will help ensure that Central Park&rsquo
column3:
s trees are well-maintained.

For important milestones in your life, endow a tree and create a living memory that will last for generations to come. Many donors choose to make a contribution as a gift in honor or in memory of someone, or to celebrate a joyous occasion.

With the endowment of a tree, the gift is honored with an engraved paving stone at the southern end of Literary Walk in the heart of Central Park.

column2:
>About Flower Donations

Each year in Central Park, thousands of daffodils and tulips mark the arrival of spring, while mums herald the beginning of autumn. What better gift than to have flowers planted in someone's honor in Central Park?

With a minimum donation of $50, the Conservancy will plant your daffodils, tulips or mums in the Park. For your donation, you or the person(s) you are honoring will receive an eCard or physical certificate indicating the flowers planted and the date of the gift.

Please Note: Locations for plantings cannot be specified and no plaques will be placed in the Park.

Playground Partners,playground-partners.html,"

The mission of Central Park Playground Partners is to maintain the quality and cleanliness of Central Park&rsquo
column2:
s 21 playgrounds. Our playgrounds embody the highest standards of safety, innovation, and creativity, but these standards cannot be sustained without donations like yours. Being a Playground Partner is a wonderful way to directly engage in your community of families and neighbors. We seek to promote stewardship and environmentalism throughout the Park, bringing unique opportunities for camaraderie and friendship for you and your children. The funds we receive go directly towards the preservation, care, and daily inspection of these cherished play spaces. With your generosity, our Playgrounds can continue to enrich the quality of life for present and future generations of children and be an essential part of a healthy childhood for all families living in New York City.

The Playground Partners of the Women&rsquo
column3:
s Committee of Central Park Conservancy hosts its Annual Family Party at Heckscher Playground, inside the Park at Central Park South and 7th Avenue, the third Wednesday of May. The event is a family-friendly fundraiser with activities geared toward children six months to 10 years of age.

PGP TOTS is a subcommittee of the Playground Partners specifically for moms with children zero to three years old. PGP TOTS offers moms the opportunity to network, share resources, and discover all that Central Park has to offer its youngest visitors through informal gatherings such as play dates, stroller walks, and informational lectures.

Perimeter Association,perimeter-association.html,"

The Perimeter Association provides funding for the improvement and maintenance of Central Park's six-mile perimeter which runs from the Park's wall to the street curb. Over 100 residential buildings, clubs, and community organizations around the Park support the program with contributions from $1,500 to $7,000. Contributions to the Perimeter Association allow Conservancy staff to:
• Keep the six-mile perimeter clean seven days a week, year-round
• Install plantings along the wall and at entrances

Without the support of the Perimeter Association's cooperating buildings, it would be difficult to keep the perimeter clean and maintained.

The map below indicates those buildings that have contributed to the Perimeter Association during the 2013 fiscal year (donations made between July 1, 2013 - June 30, 2014).

A special thank you to the Rudin Management Company for their loyal and generous support.

I want to organize an event in Central Park. How do I reserve space?

Any event that will include 20 or more attendees requires a permit from the New York City Department of Parks &
column4: Recreation. For a picnic, wedding, field day, celebration, or other special event, apply for a Special Events Permit on the NYC Department of Parks &amp
column5: Recreation web site or by calling 212.408.0226. To reserve an athletic field, apply for an Athletic Field Permit on the NYC Department of Parks &amp
column6:
Recreation web site or by calling 212.408.0209.

When is the Park open?
Central Park is open to visitors 365 days a year. The Park opens at 6:00 am and closes at 1:00 am.

When and where are vehicles allowed in Central Park?
Vehicles are only allowed on the Park&rsquo
column7: s designated drives at the following times:

column1: <li>Terrace Drive (cross-Park at 72nd Street): Monday through Friday, 8:00 am to 10:00 am. &nbsp

Are dogs allowed in Central Park? Where and when?
Dogs are allowed in most sections of Central Park whenever the Park is open to the public. They may be off-leash between the hours of 9:00 pm and 9:00 am, but must be under the control of their owner at all times. They must always be leashed in the Arthur Ross Pinetum, Bridle Path, Cedar Hill, Children's Glade (Great Hill area), Conservatory Garden, East Green, East Meadow Oval, Kerbs Boathouse Plaza, the North Woods and the Ravine, the Ramble, Shakespeare Garden, Strawberry Fields, Turtle Pond Lawn, and any other areas where signs requiring dogs to be leashed are posted. Dogs are prohibited in all ballfields and recreational courts, playgrounds, water bodies, streams, ornamental fountains, elm islands at the Mall and the Great Lawn Oval, Lilac Walk, and Reservoir running track.

Where can I find something I lost?
The Conservancy does not keep a Lost and Found
column2:
all items of value are turned into the Central Park Police Precinct [LINK], located mid-Park at the 86th Street Transverse Road. You can contact them at 212.570.4820.

Is alcohol allowed in the Park?
No. The New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, which establishes the rules and regulations for all City parks, prohibits alcohol in all parks including Central Park.

Is grilling or barbecuing allowed in the Park?
Grilling, barbecuing, other activities involving fire in the Park are not allowed.

column1: Central Park is the 843-acre masterpiece of landscape architecture designed in the 19th century by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux and designated New York City&rsquo
column2: s first scenic landmark in 1974. As one of America&rsquo
column3: s average works of art and the nation's first public park, Central Park has become the most famous and beloved urban park in the world

column1: Learn all about the history of the Park with our Central Park Timeline.

Central Park Conservancy raises 75% of Central Park's annual Parkwide expense budget and is responsible for the day-to-day maintenance and operations of the Park. Our success can be measured by the 40 million people who visit Central Park annually and by parks around the world who consider Central Park Conservancy to be the leader and the inspiration of urban park management and restoration.

column1: Central Park, the first major landscaped public space in urban America, was created in the 1850s as an antidote to the turbulent social unrest, largely as the result of the country's first wave of immigration, and a serious public health crisis, caused by harmful environmental conditions. Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the winners of the 1858 design competition for Central Park, along with other socially conscious reformers understood that the creation of a great public park would improve public health and contribute greatly to the formation of a civil society. Immediately, the success of Central Park fostered the urban park movement, one of the great hallmarks of democracy of nineteenth century America.

By the early twentieth century, vicissitudes of the social, political and economic climate threatened the fabric of the Park and caused its first serious decline. Robert Moses, park commissioner from 1934 to 1960, received federal funding for the restoration of many eroded landscapes and crumbling structures, and embarked on massive public programming for the post-Depression populace. When he left office, however, there was no management strategy for maintaining those improvements or educating Park visitors in proper stewardship, and for the next two decades the second &mdash
column3: decline took its toll on the fragile 843-acre Park. &nbsp

column1: Physically the Park was in a chronic state of decay. Meadows had become barren dustbowls
column2: benches, lights, and playground equipment were broken, and the one-hundred-year-old infrastructure was crumbling. Socially, the Park bred a careless, even abusive attitude towards the Park evidenced by unchecked amounts of garbage, graffiti, and vandalism. Positive use had increasingly been displaced by illicit and illegal activity. The perception &mdash
column3: and in many cases, the reality&mdash
column4: of Central Park was of a lawless and dangerous ruin. Despite a workforce of over three hundred Parks Department employees assigned to Central Park, there was no accountability. New York City had abdicated their responsibility as Park stewards and, as a result, this national treasure became a national disgrace.

column1: To help remedy this troubled situation, George Soros and Richard Gilder, under the aegis of the Central Park Community Fund, underwrote a management study of Central Park in 1974 by E.S. Savas, who was at that time the Columbia University School of Business, Professor of Public Systems Management. The groundbreaking study proposed that two important initiatives be implemented to ameliorate the conditions in Central Park: one, that a Chief Executive Officer be given ""clear and unambiguous managerial authority"" for all Park operations, and two, a Central Park Board of Guardians be created to oversee strategic planning and policy, thereby instituting private citizen involvement in their public park.

The study's first proposal resulted in the appointment in 1979 of Elizabeth ""Betsy"" Barlow (now Rogers), a Yale-educated urban planner and writer, who became the newly created Central Park administrator, charged with overseeing all aspects of the Park's daily operations, in essence the Chief Executive Officer recommended in the Savas study. For four years before her appointment, Betsy had been overseeing the Central Park Task Force's program for summer youth interns, eventually becoming the head of that small, private organization, financially separate from the City but existing under the aegis of the Parks Department.

Given her new official status and responsibilities as administrator, Betsy first conceived of and then helped to create a revolutionary public/private partnership with the support of then park commissioner Gordon Davis that would bring private monies and expertise in partnership with the City of New York to manage and restore Central Park. In 1980, the two most prominent private advocacy groups &mdash
column2: the Central Park Task Force and the Central Park Community Fund &mdash
column3: merged to become the Central Park Conservancy &mdash
column5: the citizen-based Board of Guardians that the Savas study had essentially recommended.

column1: Under a Conservancy-funded master plan, the gradual restoration of those decrepit landscapes evolved, and success bred success. As the Conservancy showed its ability to protect and maintain its investment, many more private individuals, foundations and corporations put their trust and their money into the restoration of the Park. To date, the Conservancy has had three successful capital campaigns towards rebuilding Central Park. The first campaign was launched in 1987
column2: the second, ""The Wonder of New York Campaign,"" was launched when I made a personal challenge grant to the Conservancy and the City in 1993, and the most recent ""Campaign for Central Park,"" which ended in 2008 has ensured the completion of the Park's transformation within the next few years. Most importantly, for the first time in the Park's turbulent history, the Conservancy has created an endowment that will ensure a sustainable green and healthy future for Central Park.

column1: In 1998 a historic management agreement between the Conservancy and the City of New York formalized the then 18-year public-private partnership. With that contract Douglas Blonsky, who began his career in 1985 in the Conservancy's Capital Projects office as a landscape architect supervising construction projects, assumed Betsy's title of Central Park administrator. In 2004 he assumed the additional role of president of the Conservancy and CEO, responsible for not only the Park's management but also all fundraising and administrative duties.

Blonsky created innovative management practices to ensure that those healthy new landscapes would have a skilled and dedicated staff to maintain them in a professional manner. His clear vision for a well-managed and well-maintained Park took the Conservancy's design and restoration vision one step further with the implementation of Zone Management System, which brought accountability, pride of workmanship, and clear and measurable results to the Conservancy and Parks Department staff under his jurisdiction. Under this pioneering system, the Park is divided into 49 geographic zones for managerial purposes, each headed by a zone gardener, who in turn supervises grounds technicians and volunteers. In this way, it is possible immediately to assess the gardener's skills and accomplishments, reward success, provide help and training if deemed necessary and, when advisable, reassign him or her to another location or, as last resort, dismiss the employee.

The Park's restorations gradually fostered important social changes in public behavior that returned the sanctity of public space to Central Park and ultimately to New York City at large. The American ideal of a great public park and its importance as a place to model and shape public behavior and enhance the quality of life for all its citizens once again defines the measurement of a great municipality. Towards this goal, the Conservancy was first in its demonstration of zero tolerance for both garbage and graffiti. An immediate call to action came when even the slightest sign of vandalism appeared in the Park &mdash
column2: a busted lamppost or broken bench, for example&mdash
column3: and became the tipping point, that turned public opinion of Central Park from one of dire repulsion to one of deep respect.

column1: Today Central Park has never been more beautiful or better managed in the Park's 156-year history, and the Conservancy is proud to be the leader of the Park's longest period of sustained health and beauty. To date the Conservancy has raised $700 towards the restoration, programming and management of Central Park and is responsible for 75 percent of this year's annual operating budget of $58.3million. Furthermore, just as Central Park was the leader in the birth of urban parks, so today Central Park, through the Conservancy's innovative care and expertise, is the leader in the rebirth of urban parks, public spaces and the quality of life movement. City officials and park professionals from across America and around the world come to the Central Park Conservancy Institute for Urban Parks
column2: to learn of its best practices to restore and manage their local parks.

Women's Committee,index.html,"

The Women's Committee is a group of dynamic women who are dedicated to the beautification and preservation of Central Park. Founded in 1983 by four visionary women, the Women's Committee has been instrumental in increasing awareness and raising funds for many Park projects including the reconstruction of the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, the renovation of Safari Playground, and recreation of the urns at Bow Bridge. The Women's Committee raises nearly 15 percent of Central Park Conservancy's $58.3 million annual, Park-wide budget.

The Women&rsquo
column2: s Committee is proud to host four of New York&rsquo
column3:
s premier charitable events: the Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon, the Fall Luncheon, the Annual Family Party in Hecksher Playground, and the Playground Partners Winter Luncheon. With a membership of over 1,000, the Committee is responsible for the operation of many Park-wide programs including Adopt-A-Bench, Tree Trust, Playground Partners, Tulips and Daffodils, Perimeter Association, and Conservancy Docents.

For further information, please call 212-310-6675 or e-mail wcommittee@centralparknyc.org.

The Board of Directors of the Women's Committee of Central Park Conservancy is delighted to have Anne S. Harrison serving as the Women's Committee President beginning in June 2011. A member of the Women's Committee Board since 1994, Anne has shown her devotion to the Park through her involvement in various Women's Committee programs, including the Conservancy Docents, Membership Committee, and the Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon. She served as Co-Chairman of the FLO Luncheon four times, and has most recently served on the Executive Committee as the Executive Vice President. Anne's passion for Central Park is shared by her husband, Bill Harrison, who has served as a Trustee of the Central Park Conservancy since 1994. Both originally from North Carolina, they currently live in Connecticut and have two daughters.

Rules & Regulations,rules-and-regulations.html,"

Central Park is enjoyed by more than 40 million visitors each year. To ensure that everyone can enjoy the Park safely, the New York City Department of Parks &
column3:
(external link) for all New York City parks. Officers from the New York Police Department and Parks Enforcement Patrol are responsible for enforcing all rules and regulations.

Alcohol in the Park
Per the New York City Department of Parks &
column4:
Recreation, which establishes the rules and regulations for all City parks, alcohol is prohibited in Central Park.

Wildlife in the Park
Respect the wildlife. Never feed or approach a wild, stray or injured animal. If you see something, say something: call 311 or notify a Conservancy employee.

Filming and Photography in Central Park
Some film and photography requires a permit and coordination with the Central Park Conservancy's Operations Team. Learn more at our Film and Photography page.

Dogs in the Park
Dogs are welcome in Central Park. They may be off-leash between the hours of 9:00 pm and 9:00 am in most sections of the Park, but must be under the control of their owner at all times. Dogs are prohibited in all ballfields and recreational courts, playgrounds, water bodies, streams, ornamental fountains, elm islands at the Mall and the Great Lawn Oval, Lilac Walk, and Reservoir running track.

Weddings,weddings.html,"

Central Park's 843 acres offer many romantic locations for wedding ceremonies and photography. The most popular venue is the Conservatory Garden.

Wedding Ceremonies at Conservatory Garden
The Conservatory Garden, located at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, is the location of numerous ceremonies and photo sessions each year. The six-acre Garden is made up of three smaller gardens, each with its own particular charm. Extensive displays of flowers, shrubs, and trees are in bloom from early spring through late October.

Ceremonies and photography sessions at Conservatory Garden require permits from the Central Park Conservancy
column2:
permit fees directly support the maintenance and cultivation of Conservatory Garden. You may print out and complete the permit application form and return it by mail along with a money order payable to Central Park Conservancy. Your date will be reserved and confirmed immediately, providing there is no conflict with a previously reserved party. If a conflict exists, you will have the opportunity to choose another date and time. When your date is confirmed, a permit will be mailed to you one month before your date.

Wedding Ceremonies

column1: • There is a cancellation fee of $200. However, if you choose to reschedule within one year from the original date, we will hold your payment and apply it to the new date. This offer is valid for one year only from the date of your wedding, after which time no portion of your payment will be refunded.
• Date, time (one hour maximum), and location within the Garden must be reserved.
• Use of the lawn in the Central Garden is prohibited (see exception for wedding photography below).

column2: Amplification for musical instruments, sound systems or other purposes is not permitted.

column1: • Rules and directives of Park employees must be followed.
• Only scheduled, half-hour wedding photography sessions are allowed on the lawn area.
• Wedding receptions are not permitted in the Garden.
• Chairs, tents, tables, podiums, rugs, runners or other props are not permitted.
• Floral pieces, balloons, ribbons, ropes, banners or draping around plantings are not permitted.
• Throwing rice, birdseed, real/artificial flower petals or confetti is not permitted.
• Late Arrivals must check in with security staff before proceeding to their event or photo session.

<li>The visiting public has access to the Garden and can only be requested to stay clear of the immediate area of the wedding or photography session. Wedding parties/planners may not demand that other visitors leave the area.&nbsp
column2: Only staff or security can request that the public stay clear of the immediate area.

column1: • Non-refundable permit fee is $100, but you may reserve another date upon cancellation of the original date.
• Date and time (30 minutes) must be reserved in advance.
• Wedding parties may use the lawn in the Central Garden for 30 minutes only and are limited to no more than 25 total guests.

Rules and Regulations for Ceremony
Bring your permit with you on the day of your event.
column3:
Park or security personnel will ask to see it.

The permittee is liable for all damage or injury to property or persons that may occur or be caused by use of the permit, and by accepting the permit, the permittee agrees to save the City of New York, the Parks Department and the Central Park Conservancy, Inc. harmless from any claim whatsoever which may result from such use.

Mail your permit application and money order (no personal checks) to the address shown at the bottom of the application.

Questions? Call 212-360-2766, Monday through Friday.

Information on Elsewhere in Central Park
Other popular wedding and photography locations include the Pond, Cherry Hill, Bow Bridge, Shakespeare Garden, East Green, Cedar Hill, the Mall, Hernshead, 100th Street Pool and Harlem Meer. For events including more than 20 people in Central Park, permits are required and carry a fee of $25. For more information, please contact the Special Events &
column4: Permits Office of the NYC Department of Parks &amp

Recreation at nyc.gov/parks.
